mathematics. Of importance is his memoir (\textit{Phil.\
Trans.}, 1809) in which the problem of the attraction of a
homogeneous ellipsoid upon an external point is reduced to
\index{Ellipsoid!(attraction of)}%
the simpler problem of the attraction of a related ellipsoid
upon a corresponding point interior to it. This is known as
``Ivory's theorem.'' He criticised with undue severity Laplace's
\index{Ivory's theorem}%
\index{Laplace!ref.\ to}%
solution of the method of least squares, and gave three proofs
\index{Least squares}%
of the principle without recourse to probability; but they are
\index{Probability}%
far from being satisfactory.

\Subsection{The Origin of Modern Geometry}
\index{Geometry!modern synthetic|(}%

By the researches of Descartes and the invention of the calculus,
the analytical treatment of geometry was brought into
great prominence for over a century. Notwithstanding the
efforts to revive synthetic methods made by Desargues, Pascal,
\index{Desargues!ref.\ to}%
\index{Pascal!ref.\ to}%
De~Lahire, Newton, and Maclaurin, the analytical method
\index{Delahire@{De Lahire}}%
\index{Maclaurin!ref.\ to}%
\index{Newton!ref.\ to}%
retained almost undisputed supremacy. It was reserved for
the genius of Monge to bring synthetic geometry in the
foreground, and to open up new avenues of progress. His
\textit{Géométrie descriptive} marks the beginning of a wonderful
development of modern geometry.

Of the two leading problems of descriptive geometry, the
one---to represent by drawings geometrical magnitudes---was
brought to a high degree of perfection before the time of
%% -----File: 300.png---Folio 286-------
Monge; the other---to solve problems on figures in space
\index{Monge|(}%
by constructions in a plane---had received considerable attention
before his time. His most noteworthy predecessor
in descriptive geometry was the Frenchman Frézier (1682--1773).
\index{Descriptive geometry|(}%
\index{Frezier@{Frézier}}%
\index{Geometry!descriptive|(}%
But it remained for Monge to create descriptive
geometry as a \emph{distinct} branch of science by imparting to it
geometric generality and elegance. All problems previously
treated in a special and uncertain manner were referred
back to a few general principles. He introduced the line
of intersection of the horizontal and the vertical plane as
the axis of projection. By revolving one plane into the
other around this axis or ground-line, many advantages were
gained.\Reference{54}

\textbf{Gaspard Monge} (1746--1818) was born at Beaune. The construction
of a plan of his native town brought the boy under
the notice of a colonel of engineers, who procured for him an
appointment in the college of engineers at Mézières. Being
of low birth, he could not receive a commission in the army,
but he was permitted to enter the annex of the school, where
surveying and drawing were taught. Observing that all the
operations connected with the construction of plans of fortification
were conducted by long arithmetical processes, he substituted
a geometrical method, which the commandant at first
refused even to look at, so short was the time in which it
could be practised; when once examined, it was received with
avidity. Monge developed these methods further and thus
created his descriptive geometry. Owing to the rivalry
between the French military schools of that time, he was not
permitted to divulge his new methods to any one outside of
this institution. In 1768 he was made professor of mathematics
at Mézières. In 1780, when conversing with two of his
pupils, S.~F. Lacroix and Gayvernon in Paris, he was obliged
\index{Lacroix}%
to say, ``All that I have here done by calculation, I could have
%% -----File: 301.png---Folio 287-------
\index{Imaginary quantities}%
done with the ruler and compass, but I am not allowed to
reveal these secrets to you.'' But Lacroix set himself to
\index{Lacroix}%
examine what the secret could be, discovered the processes, and
published them in 1795. The method was published by Monge
himself in the same year, first in the form in which the short-hand
writers took down his lessons given at the Normal School,
where he had been elected professor, and then again, in revised
form, in the \textit{Journal des écoles normales}. The next edition
occurred in 1798--1799. After an ephemeral existence of only
four months the Normal School was closed in~1795. In the
same year the Polytechnic School was opened, in the establishing
of which Monge took active part. He taught there
descriptive geometry until his departure from France to accompany
\index{Geometry!analytic}%
Napoleon on the Egyptian campaign. He was the first
president of the Institute of Egypt. Monge was a zealous
partisan of Napoleon and was, for that reason, deprived of all
his honours by Louis~XVIII\@. This and the destruction of the
Polytechnic School preyed heavily upon his mind. He did
not long survive this insult.

Monge's numerous papers were by no means confined to descriptive
geometry. His analytical discoveries are hardly less
remarkable. He introduced into analytic geometry the methodic
\index{Analytic geometry}%
use of the equation of a line. He made important
contributions to surfaces of the second degree (previously
\index{Surfaces, theory of}%
studied by Wren and Euler) and discovered between the
\index{Euler!ref.\ to}%
\index{Wren!ref.\ to}%
theory of surfaces and the integration of partial differential
\index{Partial differential equations}%
equations, a hidden relation which threw new light upon both
subjects. He gave the differential of curves of curvature,
established a general theory of curvature, and applied it to the
ellipsoid. He found that the validity of solutions was not
impaired when imaginaries are involved among subsidiary
quantities. Monge published the following books: \textit{Statics},
1786; \textit{Applications de l'algèbre à la géométrie}, 1805; \textit{Application
%% -----File: 302.png---Folio 288-------
\index{Brianchion}%
\index{Carnot, Lazare}%
de l'analyse à la géométrie}. The last two contain most of
his miscellaneous papers.

Monge was an inspiring teacher, and he gathered around
him a large circle of pupils, among which were Dupin, Servois,
\index{Dupin}%
\index{Servois}%
Brianchon, Hachette, Biot, and Poncelet.
\index{Biot}%
\index{Hachette}%
\index{Poncelet!ref.\ to}%

\textbf{Charles Dupin} (1784--1873), for many years professor of
mechanics in the Conservatoire des Arts et Métiers in Paris,
published in 1813 an important work on \textit{Développements de
géométrie}, in which is introduced the conception of conjugate
tangents of a point of a surface, and of the indicatrix.\Reference{53} It
contains also the theorem known as ``Dupin's theorem.''
Surfaces of the second degree and descriptive geometry were
successfully studied by \textit{Jean Nicolas Pierre Hachette} (1769--1834),
who became professor of descriptive geometry at the
Polytechnic School after the departure of Monge for Rome and
Egypt. In 1822 he published his \textit{Traité de géométrie descriptive}.

Descriptive geometry, which arose, as we have seen, in
technical schools in France, was transferred to Germany at
the foundation of technical schools there. G.~Schreiber,
\index{Schreiber}%
professor in Karlsruhe, was the first to spread Monge's
\index{Monge|)}%
geometry in Germany by the publication of a work thereon
in 1828--1829.\Reference{54} In the United States descriptive geometry was
\index{Descriptive geometry|)}%
\index{Geometry!descriptive|)}%
introduced in 1816 at the Military Academy in West Point
by Claude Crozet, once a pupil at the Polytechnic School in
\index{Crozet}%
Paris. Crozet wrote the first English work on the subject.\Reference{2}

\textbf{Lazare Nicholas Marguerite Carnot} (1753--1823) was born at
Nolay in Burgundy, and educated in his native province.
He entered the army, but continued his mathematical studies,
and wrote in 1784 a work on machines, containing the earliest
proof that kinetic energy is lost in collisions of bodies. With
the advent of the Revolution he threw himself into politics,
and when coalesced Europe, in 1793, launched against France
a million soldiers, the gigantic task of organising fourteen
%% -----File: 303.png---Folio 289-------
\index{Brianchion}%
\index{Carnot, Lazare}%
\index{Differential calculus!philosophy of}%
\index{Dupin}%
armies to meet the enemy was achieved by him. He was
banished in 1796 for opposing Napoleon's \textit{coup d'état}. The
refugee went to Geneva, where he issued, in 1797, a work
still frequently quoted, entitled, \textit{Réflexions sur la Métaphysique
du Calcul Infinitésimal}. He declared himself as an ``irreconcilable
enemy of kings.'' After the Russian campaign he
offered to fight for France, though not for the empire. On
the restoration he was exiled. He died in Magdeburg. His
\textit{Géométrie de position}, 1803, and his \textit{Essay on Transversals},
1806, are important contributions to modern geometry. While
Monge revelled mainly in three-dimensional geometry, Carnot
confined himself to that of two. By his effort to explain
the meaning of the negative sign in geometry he established
a ``geometry of position,'' which, however, is different from
the ``Geometrie der Lage'' of to-day. He invented a class
of general theorems on projective properties of figures, which
have since been pushed to great extent by Poncelet, Chasles,
\index{Chasles!ref.\ to}%
\index{Poncelet}%
and others.

\textbf{Jean Victor Poncelet} (1788--1867), a native of Metz, took
part in the Russian campaign, was abandoned as dead on the
bloody field of Krasnoi, and taken prisoner to Saratoff. Deprived
there of all books, and reduced to the remembrance
of what he had learned at the Lyceum at Metz and the Polytechnic
School, where he had studied with predilection the
works of Monge, Carnot, and Brianchon, he began to study
mathematics from its elements. He entered upon original
researches which afterwards made him illustrious. While
in prison he did for mathematics what Bunyan did for
literature,---produced a much-read work, which has remained
of great value down to the present time. He returned to
France in 1814, and in 1822 published the work in question,
entitled, \textit{Traité des Propriétés projectives des figures}. In it
he investigated the properties of figures which remain unaltered
%% -----File: 304.png---Folio 290-------
by projection of the figures. The projection is not
effected here by parallel rays of prescribed direction, as with
Monge, but by central projection. Thus perspective projection,
used before him by Desargues, Pascal, Newton, and Lambert,
\index{Desargues!ref.\ to}%
\index{Lambert!ref.\ to}%
\index{Newton!ref.\ to}%
\index{Pascal!ref.\ to}%
was elevated by him into a fruitful geometric method.
In the same way he elaborated some ideas of De~Lahire,
\index{Delahire@{De Lahire}}%
Servois, and Gergonne into a regular method---the method
\index{Gergonne!ref.\ to}%
\index{Servois}%
of ``reciprocal polars.'' To him we owe the Law of Duality
\index{Duality}%
\index{Reciprocal polars}%
as a consequence of reciprocal polars. As an independent
principle it is due to Gergonne. Poncelet wrote much on
\index{Poncelet}%
applied mechanics. In 1838 the Faculty of Sciences was
\index{Mechanics!more recent work}%
enlarged by his election to the chair of mechanics.

While in France the school of Monge was creating modern
geometry, efforts were made in England to revive Greek
geometry by \textbf{Robert Simson} (1687--1768) and \textbf{Matthew Stewart}
\index{Simson}%
\index{Stewart}%
(1717--1785). Stewart was a pupil of Simson and Maclaurin,
\index{Maclaurin!ref.\ to}%
and succeeded the latter in the chair at Edinburgh. During
the eighteenth century he and Maclaurin were the only prominent
mathematicians in Great Britain. His genius was ill-directed
by the fashion then prevalent in England to ignore
higher analysis. In his \textit{Four Tracts, Physical and Mathematical},
1761, he applied geometry to the solution of difficult
\index{Geometry!modern synthetic|)}%
astronomical problems, which on the Continent were approached
analytically with greater success. He published, in
1746, \textit{General Theorems}, and in 1763, his \textit{Propositiones geometricæ
more veterum demonstratæ}. The former work contains
sixty-nine theorems, of which only five are accompanied
by demonstrations. It gives many interesting new results
on the circle and the straight line. Stewart extended some
theorems on transversals due to Giovanni Ceva (1648--1737),
\index{Ceva}%
an Italian, who published in 1678 at Mediolani a work containing
the theorem now known by his name.
%% -----File: 305.png---Folio 291-------
\index{Bolyai, Johann!ref.\ to}%
\index{Bolyai, Wolfgang!ref.\ to}%


\Chapter{Recent Times}

\First{Never} more zealously and successfully has mathematics
been cultivated than in this century. Nor has progress, as
in previous periods, been confined to one or two countries.
While the French and Swiss, who alone during the preceding
epoch carried the torch of progress, have continued to develop
mathematics with great success, from other countries whole
armies of enthusiastic workers have wheeled into the front
rank. Germany awoke from her lethargy by bringing forward
Gauss, Jacobi, Dirichlet, and hosts of more recent men;
\index{Dirichlet!ref.\ to}%
\index{Gauss!ref.\ to}%
\index{Jacobi!ref.\ to}%
Great Britain produced her De~Morgan, Boole, Hamilton,
\index{Boole!ref.\ to}%
\index{Demorgan@{De Morgan}!ref.\ to}%
\index{Hamilton, W.~R.!ref.\ to}%
besides champions who are still living; Russia entered the
arena with her Lobatchewsky; Norway with Abel; Italy with
\index{Abel!ref.\ to}%
\index{Lobatchewsky!ref.\ to}%
Cremona; Hungary with her two Bolyais; the United States
\index{Cremona!ref.\ to}%
with Benjamin Peirce.
\index{Peirce, B.!ref.\ to}%

The productiveness of modern writers has been enormous.
``It is difficult,'' says Professor Cayley,\Reference[]{56} ``to give an idea of
\index{Cayley!ref.\ to}%
the vast extent of modern mathematics. This word `extent'
is not the right one: I mean extent crowded with beautiful
detail,---not an extent of mere uniformity such as an objectless
plain, but of a tract of beautiful country seen at first in
the distance, but which will bear to be rambled through and
studied in every detail of hillside and valley, stream, rock,
wood, and flower.'' It is pleasant to the mathematician to
think that in his, as in no other science, the achievements of
%% -----File: 306.png---Folio 292-------
every age remain possessions forever; new discoveries seldom
disprove older tenets; seldom is anything lost or wasted.

If it be asked wherein the utility of some modern extensions
of mathematics lies, it must be acknowledged that it is
at present difficult to see how they are ever to become applicable
to questions of common life or physical science. But
our inability to do this should not be urged as an argument
against the pursuit of such studies. In the first place, we
know neither the day nor the hour when these abstract
developments will find application in the mechanic arts, in
physical science, or in other branches of mathematics. For
example, the whole subject of graphical statics, so useful
\index{Graphical statics}%
to the practical engineer, was made to rest upon von Staudt's
\index{Von Staudt!ref.\ to}%
\textit{Geometrie der Lage}; Hamilton's ``principle of varying action''
\index{Action!varying}%
\index{Hamilton, W.~R.!ref.\ to}%
\index{Varying action, principle of}%
has its use in astronomy; complex quantities, general integrals,
\index{Complex quantities}%
and general theorems in integration offer advantages in
the study of electricity and magnetism. ``The utility of such
researches,'' says Spottiswoode,\Reference[]{57} ``can in no case be discounted,
\index{Spottiswoode!ref.\ to}%
or even imagined beforehand. Who, for instance, would have
supposed that the calculus of forms or the theory of substitutions
\index{Calculus!of operations}%
\index{Substitutions, theory of}%
would have thrown much light upon ordinary equations;
or that Abelian functions and hyperelliptic transcendents
\index{Abelian functions}%
\index{Hyperelliptic functions}%
would have told us anything about the properties of curves;
\index{Curves!theory of}%
or that the calculus of operations would have helped us in
\index{Operations, calculus of}%
any way towards the figure of the earth?'' A second reason
\index{Earth!figure of}%
\index{Figure of the earth}%
in favour of the pursuit of advanced mathematics, even when
there is no promise of practical application, is this, that mathematics,
like poetry and music, deserves cultivation for its
own sake.

The great characteristic of modern mathematics is its generalising
tendency. Nowadays little weight is given to isolated
theorems, ``except as affording hints of an unsuspected
new sphere of thought, like meteorites detached from some
%% -----File: 307.png---Folio 293-------
\index{Invariant}%
undiscovered planetary orb of speculation.'' In mathematics,
as in all true sciences, no subject is considered in itself alone,
but always as related to, or an outgrowth of, other things.
The development of the notion of continuity plays a leading
\index{Continuity}%
part in modern research. In geometry the principle of continuity,
\index{Geometry!modern synthetic|(}%
the idea of correspondence, and the theory of projection
\index{Correspondence, principle of}%
constitute the fundamental modern notions. Continuity
asserts itself in a most striking way in relation to the circular
points at infinity in a plane. In algebra the modern idea finds
\index{Infinity}%
expression in the theory of linear transformations and invariants,
and in the recognition of the value of homogeneity and
\index{Homogeneity}%
symmetry.


\Section{Synthetic Geometry}
\index{Synthetic geometry|(}%

The conflict between geometry and analysis which arose
near the close of the last century and the beginning of the
present has now come to an end. Neither side has come
out victorious. The greatest strength is found to lie, not in
the suppression of either, but in the friendly rivalry between
the two, and in the stimulating influence of the one upon the
other. Lagrange prided himself that in his \textit{\DPtypo{Mecanique}{Mécanique} Analytique}
\index{Lagrange!ref.\ to}%
he had succeeded in avoiding all figures; but since his
time mechanics has received much help from geometry.

Modern synthetic geometry was created by several investigators
about the same time. It seemed to be the outgrowth
of a desire for general methods which should serve as threads
of Ariadne to guide the student through the labyrinth of theorems,
corollaries, porisms, and problems. Synthetic geometry
was first cultivated by Monge, Carnot, and Poncelet in France;
\index{Carnot, Lazare!ref.\ to}%
\index{Monge!ref.\ to}%
\index{Poncelet!ref.\ to}%
it then bore rich fruits at the hands of Möbius and Steiner in
\index{Mobius@{Möbius}!ref.\ to}%
\index{Steiner!ref.\ to}%
Germany and Switzerland, and was finally developed to still
%% -----File: 308.png---Folio 294-------
\index{Anharmonic ratio}%
higher perfection by Chasles in France, von Staudt in Germany,
\index{Chasles!ref.\ to}%
\index{Von Staudt!ref.\ to}%
and Cremona in Italy.
\index{Cremona!ref.\ to|(}%

\textbf{Augustus Ferdinand Möbius} (1790--1868) was a native of
\index{Mobius@{Möbius}}%
Schulpforta in Prussia. He studied at Göttingen under
Gauss, also at Leipzig and Halle. In Leipzig he became, in
\index{Gauss!ref.\ to}%
1815, privat-docent, the next year extraordinary professor of
astronomy, and in 1844 ordinary professor. This position he
held till his death. The most important of his researches
are on geometry. They appeared in \textit{Crelle's Journal}, and in
his celebrated work entitled \textit{Der Barycentrische Calcul}, Leipzig,
1827. As the name indicates, this calculus is based upon
properties of the centre of gravity.\Reference{58} Thus, that the point~$S$
is the centre of gravity of weights $a$,~$b$, $c$,~$d$ placed at the
points $A$,~$B$, $C$,~$D$ respectively, is expressed by the equation
\[
(a + b + c + d)S = aA + bB + cC + dD.
\]
His calculus is the beginning of a quadruple algebra, and contains
the germs of Grassmann's marvellous system. In designating
\index{Grassmann!ref.\ to}%
segments of lines we find throughout this work for the
first time consistency in the distinction of positive and negative
by the order of letters $AB$,~$BA$. Similarly for triangles
and tetrahedra. The remark that it is always possible to give
three points $A$,~$B$,~$C$ such weights $\alpha$,~$\beta$,~$\gamma$ that any fourth point~$M$
in their plane will become a centre of mass, led Möbius
to a new system of co-ordinates in which the position of a
\index{Co-ordinates}%
point was indicated by an equation, and that of a line by
co-ordinates. By this algorithm he found by algebra many
geometric theorems expressing mainly invariantal properties,---for
example, the theorems on the anharmonic relation.
Möbius wrote also on statics and astronomy. He generalised
spherical trigonometry by letting the sides or angles of triangles
\index{Spherical trigonometry}%
\index{Trigonometry!spherical}%
exceed~$180°$.
%% -----File: 309.png---Folio 295-------
\index{Salmon}%

\textbf{Jacob Steiner} (1796--1863), ``the greatest geometrician since
\index{Steiner}%
the time of Euclid,'' was born in Utzendorf in the Canton of
Bern. He did not learn to write till he was fourteen. At
eighteen he became a pupil of Pestalozzi. Later he studied
at Heidelberg and Berlin. When Crelle started, in 1826, the
celebrated mathematical journal bearing his name, Steiner and
Abel became leading contributors. In 1832 Steiner published
his \textit{Systematische Entwickelung der Abhängigkeit geometrischer
Gestalten von einander}, ``in which is uncovered the organism
by which the most diverse phenomena (\textit{Erscheinungen}) in
the world of space are united to each other.'' Through the
influence of Jacobi and others, the chair of geometry was
\index{Jacobi!ref.\ to}%
founded for him at Berlin in~1834. This position he occupied
until his death, which occurred after years of bad health. In
his \textit{Systematische Entwickelungen}, for the first time, is the
principle of duality introduced at the outset. This book and
von Staudt's lay the foundation on which synthetic geometry
\index{Von Staudt!ref.\ to}%
in its present form rests. Not only did he fairly complete the
theory of curves and surfaces of the second degree, but he
\index{Surfaces, theory of}%
made great advances in the theory of those of higher degrees.
In his hands synthetic geometry made prodigious progress.
New discoveries followed each other so rapidly that he often
did not take time to record their demonstrations. In an
article in \textit{Crelle's Journal} on \textit{Allgemeine Eigenschaften Algebraischer
\index{Crelle's Journal}%
Curven} he gives without proof theorems which were
declared by Hesse to be ``like Fermat's theorems, riddles to
\index{Hesse!ref.\ to}%
the present and future generations.'' Analytical proofs of
some of them have been given since by others, but Cremona
finally proved them all by a synthetic method. Steiner discovered
synthetically the two prominent properties of a surface
of the third order; viz.~that it contains twenty-seven
straight lines and a pentahedron which has the double points
for its vertices and the lines of the Hessian of the given surface
\index{Hessian}%
%% -----File: 310.png---Folio 296-------
for its edges.\Reference{55} The first property was discovered analytically
somewhat earlier in England by Cayley and Salmon,
\index{Cayley!ref.\ to}%
and the second by Sylvester. Steiner's work on this subject
\index{Steiner}%
\index{Sylvester!ref.\ to}%
was the starting-point of important researches by H.~Schröter,
\index{SchroterH@{Schröter, H.}!ref.\ to}%
F.~August, L.~Cremona, and R.~Sturm. Steiner made investigations
\index{August}%
\index{Cremona!ref.\ to|)}%
\index{Sturm, R.}%
by synthetic methods on maxima and minima, and
arrived at the solution of problems which at that time altogether
surpassed the analytic power of the calculus of variations.
\index{Calculus!of variations}%
He generalised the \textit{hexagrammum mysticum} and also
\index{Hexagrammum mysticum}%
Malfatti's problem.\Reference{59} Malfatti, in 1803, proposed the problem,
\index{Malfatti}%
\index{Malfatti's problem}%
to cut three cylindrical holes out of a three-sided prism in
such a way that the cylinders and the prism have the same
altitude and that the volume of the cylinders be a maximum.
This problem was reduced to another, now generally known
as Malfatti's problem: to inscribe three circles in a triangle
that each circle will be tangent to two sides of a triangle and
to the other two circles. Malfatti gave an analytical solution,
but Steiner gave without proof a construction, remarked that
there were thirty-two solutions, generalised the problem by
replacing the three lines by three circles, and solved the
analogous problem for three dimensions. This general problem
was solved analytically by C.~H. Schellbach (1809--1892)
\index{Schellbach}%
and Cayley, and by Clebsch with the aid of the addition
\index{Clebsch!ref.\ to}%
theorem of elliptic functions.\Reference{60}
\index{Elliptic functions}%

Steiner's researches are confined to synthetic geometry. He
hated analysis as thoroughly as Lagrange disliked geometry.
\index{Lagrange!ref.\ to}%
Steiner's \textit{Gesammelte Werke} were published in Berlin in 1881
and 1882.

\textbf{Michel Chasles} (1793--1880) was born at Epernon, entered
\index{Chasles|(}%
the Polytechnic School of Paris in 1812, engaged afterwards
in business, which he later gave up that he might devote all
his time to scientific pursuits. In 1841 he became professor of
geodesy and mechanics at the Polytechnic School; later,
%% -----File: 311.png---Folio 297-------
\index{Cubic curves}%
``Professeur de Géométrie supérieure à la Faculté des Sciences
de Paris.'' He was a voluminous writer on geometrical subjects.
In 1837 he published his admirable \textit{Aperçu historique
sur l'origine et le développement des méthodes en géométrie}, containing
a history of geometry and, as an appendix, a treatise
``sur deux principes généraux de la Science.'' The \textit{Aperçu
historique} is still a standard historical work; the appendix
contains the general theory of Homography (Collineation) and
of duality (Reciprocity). The name \emph{duality} is due to Joseph
\index{Duality}%
Diaz Gergonne (1771--1859). Chasles introduced the term
\index{Gergonne}%
\emph{anharmonic ratio}, corresponding to the German \textit{Doppelverhältniss}
\index{Anharmonic ratio}%
and to Clifford's \emph{cross-ratio}. Chasles and Steiner
\index{Clifford!ref.\ to}%
\index{Steiner!ref.\ to}%
elaborated independently the modern synthetic or projective
geometry. Numerous original memoirs of Chasles were published
later in the \textit{Journal de l'École Polytechnique}. He gave
a reduction of cubics, different from Newton's in this, that the
\index{Newton!ref.\ to}%
five curves from which all others can be projected are symmetrical
with respect to a centre. In 1864 he began the publication,
in the \textit{Comptes rendus}, of articles in which he solves
by his ``method of characteristics'' and the ``principle of correspondence''
\index{Characteristics, method of}%
\index{Correspondence, principle of}%
\index{Method of characteristics}%
an immense number of problems. He determined,
for instance, the number of intersections of two curves
in a plane. The method of characteristics contains the basis
of enumerative geometry. The application of the principle of
\index{Enumerative geometry}%
correspondence was extended by Cayley, A.~Brill, H.~G. Zeuthen,
\index{Brill, A.}%
\index{Cayley!ref.\ to}%
\index{Zeuthen!ref.\ to}%
H.~A. Schwarz, G.~H. Halphen (1844--1889), and others.
\index{Halphen!ref.\ to}%
\index{Schwarz!ref.\ to}%
The full value of these principles of Chasles was not brought
out until the appearance, in 1879, of the \textit{Kalkül der Abzählenden
Geometrie} by Hermann Schubert of Hamburg. This
\index{Schubert}%
work contains a masterly discussion of the problem of enumerative
geometry, viz.~to determine how many geometric figures
of given definition satisfy a sufficient number of conditions.
Schubert extended his enumerative geometry to $n$-dimensional
space.\Reference{55}
%% -----File: 312.png---Folio 298-------

To Chasles we owe the introduction into projective geometry
of non-projective properties of figures by means of the infinitely
distant imaginary sphero-circle.\Reference{61} Remarkable is his
\index{Imaginary points, lines, etc}%
complete solution, in 1846, by synthetic geometry, of the
difficult question of the attraction of an ellipsoid on an external
\index{Ellipsoid!(attraction of)}%
point. This was accomplished analytically by Poisson in
\index{Poisson!ref.\ to}%
1835. The labours of Chasles and Steiner raised synthetic
\index{Steiner!ref.\ to}%
geometry to an honoured and respected position by the side
of analysis.

\textbf{Karl Georg Christian von Staudt} (1798--1867) was born in
\index{Von Staudt}%
Rothenburg on the Tauber, and, at his death, was professor
in Erlangen. His great works are the \textit{Geometrie der Lage},
Nürnberg, 1847, and his \textit{Beiträge zur Geometrie der Lage}, 1856--1860.
The author cut loose from algebraic formulæ and from
metrical relations, particularly the anharmonic ratio of Steiner
and Chasles, and then created a geometry of position, which
\index{Chasles|)}%
is a complete science in itself, independent of all measurements.
He shows that projective properties of figures have
no dependence whatever on measurements, and can be established
without any mention of them. In his theory of what
he calls ``Würfe,'' he even gives a geometrical definition of
a number in its relation to geometry as determining the position
of a point. The \textit{Beiträge} contains the first complete and
general theory of imaginary points, lines, and planes in projective
geometry. Representation of an imaginary point is
sought in the combination of an involution with a determinate
direction, both on the real line through the point.
While purely projective, von Staudt's method is intimately
related to the problem of representing by actual points and
lines the imaginaries of analytical geometry. This was systematically
undertaken by C.~F. Maximilien Marie, who worked,
\index{Marie, C. F. M.}%
however, on entirely different lines. An independent attempt
has been made recently (1893) by F.~H. Loud of Colorado
\index{Loud}%
%% -----File: 313.png---Folio 299-------
\index{Funicular polygons}%
College. Von~Staudt's geometry of position was for a long
\index{Von Staudt}%
time disregarded, mainly, no doubt, because his book is
extremely condensed. An impulse to the study of this subject
was given by Culmann, who rests his graphical statics upon
\index{Culmann}%
\index{Graphical statics}%
the work of von~Staudt. An interpreter of von~Staudt was
at last found in Theodor Reye of Strassburg, who wrote a
\index{Reye}%
\textit{Geometrie der Lage} in 1868.

Synthetic geometry has been studied with much success by
\textbf{Luigi Cremona}, professor in the University of Rome. In
\index{Cremona}%
his \textit{Introduzione ad una teoria geometrica delle curve piane}
he developed by a uniform method many new results and
proved synthetically all important results reached before that
time by analysis. His writings have been translated into
German by M.~Curtze, professor at the gymnasium in Thorn.
\index{Curtze, M}%
The theory of the transformation of curves and of the correspondence
of points on curves was extended by him to three
dimensions. Ruled surfaces, surfaces of the second order,
\index{Surfaces, theory of}%
space-curves of the third order, and the general theory of
surfaces have received much attention at his hands.

\textbf{Karl Culmann}, professor at the Polytechnicum in Zürich,
published an epoch-making work on \textit{Die graphische Statik},
Zürich, 1864, which has rendered graphical statics a great
rival of analytical statics. Before Culmann, \textit{B.~E. Cousinery}
\index{Cousinery}%
had turned his attention to the graphical calculus, but he
made use of perspective, and not of modern geometry.\Reference{62} Culmann
is the first to undertake to present the graphical calculus
as a symmetrical whole, holding the same relation to the new
geometry that analytical mechanics does to higher analysis.
He makes use of the polar theory of reciprocal figures as
expressing the relation between the force and the funicular
polygons. He deduces this relation without leaving the plane
of the two figures. But if the polygons be regarded as projections
of lines in space, these lines may be treated as reciprocal
%% -----File: 314.png---Folio 300-------
\index{Culmann}%
\index{Non-Euclidean geometry|(}%
\index{Parallels}%
elements of a ``Nullsystem.'' This was done by \textit{Clerk
Maxwell} in 1864, and elaborated further by \textit{Cremona}.\Reference{63} The
\index{Cremona!ref.\ to}%
\index{Maxwell!ref.\ to}%
graphical calculus has been applied by \textit{O.~Mohr} of Dresden
\index{Mohr}%
to the elastic line for continuous spans. \textit{Henry~T. Eddy}, of
\index{Eddy}%
the Rose Polytechnic Institute, gives graphical solutions of
problems on the maximum stresses in bridges under concentrated
loads, with aid of what he calls ``reaction polygons.''
\index{Reaction polygons}%
A standard work, \textit{La Statique graphique}, 1874, was issued by
Maurice Levy of Paris.
\index{Levy}%

Descriptive geometry (reduced to a science by Monge in
\index{Descriptive geometry}%
\index{Geometry!descriptive}%
\index{Monge!ref.\ to}%
France, and elaborated further by his successors, \textit{Hachette},
\index{Hachette}%
\textit{Dupin}, \textit{Olivier}, \textit{J.~de la Gournerie}) was soon studied also in
\index{Dupin!ref.\ to}%
\index{Gournerie}%
\index{Olivier}%
other countries. The French directed their attention mainly
to the theory of surfaces and their curvature; the Germans
and Swiss, through Schreiber, Pohlke, Schlessinger, and particularly
\index{Pohlke}%
\index{Schlessinger}%
\index{Schreiber}%
Fiedler, interwove projective and descriptive geometry.
\index{Fiedler}%
Bellavitis in Italy worked along the same line. The
\index{Bellavitis!ref.\ to}%
theory of shades and shadows was first investigated by the
French writers just quoted, and in Germany treated most
exhaustively by Burmester.\Reference{62}
\index{Burmester}%

During the present century very remarkable generalisations
have been made, which reach to the very root of two of the
oldest branches of mathematics,---elementary algebra and
geometry. In algebra the laws of operation have been extended;
in geometry the axioms have been searched to the
\index{Axioms (of geometry)}%
bottom, and the conclusion has been reached that the space
defined by Euclid's axioms is not the only possible non-contradictory
space. Euclid proved (I.~27) that ``if a straight
line falling on two other straight lines make the alternate
angles equal to one another, the two straight lines shall be
parallel to one another.'' Being unable to prove that in every
other case the two lines are not parallel, he \emph{assumed} this to
be true in what is generally called the 12th ``axiom,'' by some
%% -----File: 315.png---Folio 301-------
the 11th ``axiom.'' But this so-called axiom is far from
axiomatic. After centuries of desperate but fruitless attempts
to prove Euclid's assumption, the bold idea dawned upon
the minds of several mathematicians that a geometry might
be built up without assuming the parallel-axiom. While
Legendre still endeavoured to establish the axiom by rigid
\index{Legendre!ref.\ to}%
proof, Lobatchewsky brought out a publication which assumed
\index{Lobatchewsky}%
the contradictory of that axiom, and which was the first of
a series of articles destined to clear up obscurities in the
fundamental concepts, and to greatly extend the field of
geometry.

\textbf{Nicholaus Ivanovitch Lobatchewsky} (1793--1856) was born at
Makarief, in Nischni-Nowgorod, Russia, studied at Kasan, and
from 1827 to 1846 was professor and rector of the University
of Kasan. His views on the foundation of geometry were
first made public in a discourse before the physical and mathematical
faculty at Kasan, and first printed in the Kasan
\textit{Messenger} for 1829, and then in the \textit{Gelehrte Schriften der
Universität Kasan}, 1836--1838, under the title, ``New Elements
of Geometry, with a complete theory of Parallels.'' Being
\index{Parallels}%
in the Russian language, the work remained unknown to
foreigners, but even at home it attracted no notice. In 1840
he published a brief statement of his researches in Berlin.
Lobatchewsky constructed an ``imaginary geometry,'' as he
\index{Imaginary geometry}%
called it, which has been described by Clifford as ``quite
simple, merely Euclid without the vicious assumption.'' A
remarkable part of this geometry is this, that through a
point an indefinite number of lines can be drawn in a plane,
none of which cut a given line in the same plane. A similar
system of geometry was deduced independently by the Bolyais
in Hungary, who called it ``absolute geometry.''
\index{Absolute geometry}%

\textbf{Wolfgang Bolyai de~Bolya} (1775--1856) was born in Szekler-Land,
\index{Bolyai, Wolfgang}%
Transylvania. After studying at Jena, he went to
%% -----File: 316.png---Folio 302-------
Göttingen, where he became intimate with Gauss, then nineteen
\index{Gauss!ref.\ to}%
years old. Gauss used to say that Bolyai was the only
\index{Bolyai, Johann}%
\index{Bolyai, Wolfgang}%
man who fully understood his views on the metaphysics of
mathematics. Bolyai became professor at the Reformed College
of Maros-Vásárhely, where for forty-seven years he had
for his pupils most of the present professors of Transylvania.
The first publications of this remarkable genius were dramas
and poetry. Clad in old-time planter's garb, he was truly
original in his private life as well as in his mode of thinking.
He was extremely modest. No monument, said he, should
stand over his grave, only an apple-tree, in memory of the
three apples; the two of Eve and Paris, which made hell out
of earth, and that of Newton, which elevated the earth again
\index{Newton!ref.\ to}%
into the circle of heavenly bodies.\Reference{64} His son, \textbf{Johann Bolyai}
(1802--1860), was educated for the army, and distinguished
himself as a profound mathematician, an impassioned violin-player,
and an expert fencer. He once accepted the challenge
of thirteen officers on condition that after each duel he might
play a piece on his violin, and he vanquished them all.

The chief mathematical work of Wolfgang Bolyai appeared
in two volumes, 1832--1833, entitled \textit{Tentamen juventutem
studiosam in elementa matheseos puræ\ldots introducendi}. It
is followed by an appendix composed by his son Johann on
\textit{The Science Absolute of Space}. Its twenty-six pages make the
name of Johann Bolyai immortal. He published nothing else,
but he left behind one thousand pages of manuscript which
have never been read by a competent mathematician! His
father seems to have been the only person in Hungary who
really appreciated the merits of his son's work. For thirty-five
years this appendix, as also Lobatchewsky's researches,
remained in almost entire oblivion. Finally Richard Baltzer
\index{Baltzer, R.!ref.\ to}%
of the University of Giessen, in 1867, called attention to the
wonderful researches. Johann Bolyai's \textit{Science Absolute of}
%% -----File: 317.png---Folio 303-------
\textit{Space} and Lobatchewsky's \textit{Geometrical Researches on the
\index{Lobatchewsky!ref.\ to}%
Theory of Parallels} (1840) were rendered easily accessible to
\index{Parallels}%
American readers by translations into English made in 1891
by George Bruce Halsted of the University of Texas.
\index{Halsted}%

The Russian and Hungarian mathematicians were not the
only ones to whom pangeometry suggested itself. A copy of
the \textit{Tentamen} reached Gauss, the elder Bolyai's former room-mate %[** PP: Only instance]
\index{Gauss!ref.\ to}%
at Göttingen, and this Nestor of German mathematicians
was surprised to discover in it worked out what he himself
had begun long before, only to leave it after him in his
papers. As early as 1792 he had started on researches of that
character. His letters show that in 1799 he was trying to
prove \textit{a~priori} the reality of Euclid's system; but some time
\index{Euclid!ref.\ to}%
within the next thirty years he arrived at the conclusion
reached by Lobatchewsky and Bolyai. In 1829 he wrote to
Bessel, stating that his ``conviction that we cannot found
\index{Bessel!ref.\ to}%
geometry completely a~priori has become, if possible, still
firmer,'' and that ``if number is merely a product of our
mind, space has also a \emph{reality beyond} our mind of which we
cannot fully foreordain the laws \textit{a~priori}.'' The term \emph{non-Euclidean
geometry} is due to Gauss. It has recently been
brought to notice that \textit{Geronimo Saccheri}, a Jesuit father of
\index{Saccheri}%
Milan, in 1733 anticipated Lobatchewsky's doctrine of the
parallel angle. Moreover, G.~B. Halsted has pointed out
that in 1766 Lambert wrote a paper ``Zur Theorie der Parallellinien,''
\index{Lambert!ref.\ to}%
published in the \textit{Leipziger Magazin für reine und
angewandte Mathematik}, 1786, in which: (1)~The failure of
the parallel-axiom in surface-spherics gives a geometry with
angle-sum $> 2$ right angles; (2)~In order to make intuitive
a geometry with angle-sum $< 2$ right angles we need the aid
of an ``imaginary sphere" (pseudo-sphere); (3)~In a space
with the angle-sum differing from 2 right angles, there is
an absolute measure (Bolyai's natural unit for length).
%% -----File: 318.png---Folio 304-------

In 1854, nearly twenty years later, Gauss heard from his
\index{Gauss!ref.\ to}%
pupil, \textit{Riemann}, a marvellous dissertation carrying the discussion
\index{Riemann!ref.\ to}%
one step further by developing the notion of \nnobrkdash-ply
extended magnitude, and the measure-relations of which a
manifoldness of $n$ dimensions is capable, on the assumption
that every line may be measured by every other. Riemann
applied his ideas to space. He taught us to distinguish
between ``unboundedness'' and ``infinite extent.'' According
\index{Infinity}%
to him we have in our mind a more general notion of space,
\ie~a notion of non-Euclidean space; but we learn \emph{by experience}
that our physical space is, if not exactly, at least to high
degree of approximation, Euclidean space. Riemann's profound
dissertation was not published until 1867, when it
appeared in the \textit{Göttingen Abhandlungen}. Before this the
idea of \nnobrkdash-dimensions had suggested itself under various
\index{Hyperspace}%
aspects to Lagrange, Plücker, and H.~Grassmann. About the
\index{Grassmann!ref.\ to}%
\index{Lagrange!ref.\ to}%
\index{Plücker!ref.\ to}%
same time with Riemann's paper, others were published from
the pens of \textit{Helmholtz} and \textit{Beltrami}. These contributed powerfully
\index{Beltrami}%
\index{Helmholtz!ref.\ to}%
to the victory of logic over excessive empiricism. This
period marks the beginning of lively discussions upon this subject.
Some writers---Bellavitis, for example---were able to
\index{Bellavitis!ref.\ to}%
see in non-Euclidean geometry and \nnobrkdash-dimensional space nothing
but huge caricatures, or diseased outgrowths of mathematics.
Helmholtz's article was entitled \textit{Thatsachen, welche
der Geometrie zu Grunde liegen}, 1868, and contained many of
the ideas of Riemann. Helmholtz popularised the subject in
lectures, and in articles for various magazines.

\textbf{Eugenio Beltrami}, born at Cremona, Italy, in 1835, and now
professor at Rome, wrote the classical paper \textit{Saggio di interpretazione
della geometria non-euclidea} (Giorn.\ di Matem.,~6),
which is analytical (and, like several other papers, should be
mentioned elsewhere were we to adhere to a strict separation
between synthesis and analysis). He reached the brilliant
%% -----File: 319.png---Folio 305-------
and surprising conclusion that the theorems of non-Euclidean
geometry find their realisation upon surfaces of constant negative
curvature. He studied, also, surfaces of constant positive
curvature, and ended with the interesting theorem that the
space of constant positive curvature is contained in the space
of constant negative curvature. These researches of Beltrami,
\index{Beltrami}%
Helmholtz, and Riemann culminated in the conclusion that
\index{Helmholtz!ref.\ to}%
\index{Riemann!ref.\ to}%
on surfaces of constant curvature we may have three geometries,---the
non-Euclidean on a surface of constant negative
curvature, the spherical on a surface of constant positive curvature,
and the Euclidean geometry on a surface of zero curvature.
The three geometries do not contradict each other, but
are members of a system,---a geometrical trinity. The ideas
of \DPtypo{hyper-space}{hyperspace} were brilliantly expounded and popularised in
\index{Hyperspace}%
England by Clifford.
\index{Clifford}%

\textbf{William Kingdon Clifford} (1845--1879) was born at Exeter,
educated at Trinity College, Cambridge, and from 1871 until
his death professor of applied mathematics in University College,
London. His premature death left incomplete several
brilliant researches which he had entered upon. Among these
are his paper \textit{On Classification of Loci} and his \textit{Theory of
Graphs}. He wrote articles \textit{On the Canonical Form and
Dissection of a Riemann's Surface}, on \textit{Biquaternions}, and
an incomplete work on the \textit{Elements of Dynamic}. The
theory of polars of curves and surfaces was generalised by
him and by Reye. His classification of loci, 1878, being a
\index{Reye!ref.\ to}%
general study of curves, was an introduction to the study
of \nnobrkdash-dimensional space in a direction mainly projective.
This study has been continued since chiefly by G.~Veronese
\index{Veronese}%
of Padua, C.~Segre of Turin, E.~Bertini, F.~Aschieri, P.~Del~Pezzo
\index{Aschieri}%
\index{Bertini}%
\index{Delpezzo@{Del Pezzo}}%
\index{Segre}%
of Naples.

Beltrami's researches on non-Euclidean geometry were followed,
in 1871, by important investigations of Felix Klein,
\index{Klein!ref.\ to}%
%% -----File: 320.png---Folio 306-------
\index{Clifford}%
\index{Parallels}%
resting upon Cayley's \textit{Sixth Memoir on Quantics}, 1859. The
\index{Cayley!ref.\ to}%
question whether it is not possible to so express the metrical
properties of figures that they will not vary by projection (or
linear transformation) had been solved for special projections
by Chasles, Poncelet, and E.~Laguerre (1834--1886) of Paris,
\index{Chasles!ref.\ to}%
\index{Laguerre}%
\index{Poncelet!ref.\ to}%
but it remained for Cayley to give a general solution by defining
the distance between two points as an arbitrary constant
multiplied by the logarithm of the anharmonic ratio in which
\index{Anharmonic ratio}%
the line joining the two points is divided by the fundamental
quadric. Enlarging upon this notion, Klein showed the independence
\index{Klein!ref.\ to}%
of projective geometry from the parallel-axiom, and
by properly choosing the law of the measurement of distance
deduced from projective geometry the spherical, Euclidean,
and pseudospherical geometries, named by him respectively
the elliptic, parabolic, and hyperbolic geometries. This suggestive
investigation was followed up by numerous writers,
particularly by G.~Battaglini of Naples, E.~d'Ovidio of Turin,
\index{Battaglini}%
\index{Dovidio@{D'Ovidio}}%
R.~de~Paolis of Pisa, F.~Aschieri, A.~Cayley, F.~Lindemann
\index{Aschieri}%
\index{Depaolis@{De Paolis}}%
\index{Lindemann!ref.\ to}%
of Munich, E.~Schering of Göttingen, W.~Story of Clark
\index{Schering}%
\index{Story}%
University, H.~Stahl of Tübingen, A.~Voss of Würzburg,
\index{Stahl}%
\index{Voss}%
Homersham Cox, A.~Buchheim.\Reference{55} The geometry of $n$ dimensions
\index{Buchheim!ref.\ to}%
\index{Cox}%
was studied along a line mainly metrical by a host of
writers, among whom may be mentioned Simon Newcomb of
\index{Newcomb!ref.\ to}%
the Johns Hopkins University, L.~Schläfli of Bern, W.~I.
\index{Schlafli@{Schläfli}}%
Stringham of the University of California, W.~Killing of
\index{Killing}%
\index{Stringham}%
Münster, T.~Craig of the Johns Hopkins, R.~Lipschitz of
\index{Craig, T.}%
\index{Lipschitz}%
Bonn. R.~S. Heath and Killing investigated the kinematics
\index{Heath}%
and mechanics of such a space. Regular solids in \nnobrkdash-dimensional
space were studied by Stringham, Ellery~W. Davis
\index{Davis, E.~W.}%
of the University of Nebraska, R.~Hoppe of Berlin, and
\index{Hoppe}%
others. Stringham gave pictures of projections upon our
space of regular solids in four dimensions, and Schlegel at
\index{Schlegel!ref.\ to, XII}%
Hagen constructed models of such projections. These are
%% -----File: 321.png---Folio 307-------
\index{Non-Euclidean geometry|)}%
among the most curious of a series of models published by
L.~Brill in Darmstadt. It has been pointed out that if a
\index{Brill, L.}%
fourth dimension existed, certain motions could take place
which we hold to be impossible. Thus Newcomb showed the
\index{Newcomb!ref.\ to}%
possibility of turning a closed material shell inside out by simple
flexure without either stretching or tearing; Klein pointed
\index{Klein!ref.\ to}%
out that knots could not be tied; Veronese showed that a
\index{Veronese!ref.\ to}%
body could be removed from a closed room without breaking
the walls; C.~S. Peirce proved that a body in four-fold space
\index{Peirce, C.~S.!ref.\ to}%
either rotates about two axes at once, or cannot rotate without
losing one of its dimensions.

\Section{Analytic Geometry}
\index{Analytic geometry|(}%
\index{Geometry!analytic|(}%

In the preceding chapter we endeavoured to give a flash-light %[** PP: Only instance]
view of the rapid advance of synthetic geometry. In
connection with hyperspace we also mentioned analytical
treatises. Modern synthetic and modern analytical geometry
have much in common, and may be grouped together
under the common name ``projective geometry.'' Each has
\index{Projective geometry}%
advantages over the other. The continual direct viewing of
figures as existing in space adds exceptional charm to the
study of the former, but the latter has the advantage in this,
that a well-established routine in a certain degree may outrun
thought itself, and thereby aid original research. While in
Germany Steiner and von Staudt developed synthetic geometry,
\index{Synthetic geometry|)}%
Plücker laid the foundation of modern analytic geometry.
\index{Geometry!modern synthetic|)}%
\index{Plücker|(}%

\textbf{Julius Plücker} (1801--1868) was born at Elberfeld, in Prussia.
After studying at Bonn, Berlin, and Heidelberg, he spent
a short time in Paris attending lectures of Monge and his
pupils. Between 1826 and 1836 he held positions successively
at Bonn, Berlin, and Halle. He then became professor of
%% -----File: 322.png---Folio 308-------
physics at Bonn. Until 1846 his original researches were on
geometry. In 1828 and in 1831 he published his \textit{Analytisch-Geometrische
Entwicklungen} in two volumes. Therein he
adopted the abbreviated notation (used before him in a more
restricted way by Bobillier), and avoided the tedious process
\index{Bobillier}%
of algebraic elimination by a geometric consideration. In the
\index{Elimination}%
second volume the principle of duality is formulated analytically.
\index{Duality}%
With him duality and homogeneity found expression
\index{Homogeneity}%
already in his system of co-ordinates. The homogenous or
\index{Co-ordinates}%
tri-linear system used by him is much the same as the co-ordinates
of Möbius. In the identity of analytical operation
and geometric construction Plücker looked for the source of
\index{Plücker!ref.\ to}%
his proofs. The \textit{System der Analytischen Geometrie}, 1835, contains
a complete classification of plane curves of the third
order, based on the nature of the points at infinity. The
\index{Infinity}%
\textit{Theorie der Algebraischen Curven}, 1839, contains, besides an
enumeration of curves of the fourth order, the analytic relations
between the ordinary singularities of plane curves
known as ``Plücker's equations,'' by which he was able to
explain ``Poncelet's paradox.'' The discovery of these relations
\index{Poncelet!ref.\ to}%
\index{Poncelet's paradox}%
is, says Cayley, ``the most important one beyond all
\index{Cayley!ref.\ to}%
comparison in the entire subject of modern geometry.'' But
in Germany Plücker's researches met with no favour. His
method was declared to be unproductive as compared with
the synthetic method of Steiner and Poncelet! His relations
\index{Steiner!ref.\ to}%
with Jacobi were not altogether friendly. Steiner once
\index{Jacobi!ref.\ to}%
declared that he would stop writing for \textit{Crelle's Journal} if
Plücker continued to contribute to it.\Reference{66} The result was that
many of Plücker's researches were published in foreign journals,
and that his work came to be better known in France
and England than in his native country. The charge was
also brought against Plücker that, though occupying the chair
of physics, he was no physicist. This induced him to relinquish
%% -----File: 323.png---Folio 309-------
\index{Congruency of lines}%
mathematics, and for nearly twenty years to devote
his energies to physics. Important discoveries on Fresnel's
wave-surface, magnetism, spectrum-analysis were made by
him. But towards the close of his life he returned to his
first love,---mathematics,---and enriched it with new discoveries.
By considering space as made up of lines he created
a ``new geometry of space.'' Regarding a right line as a
curve involving four arbitrary parameters, one has the whole
system of lines in space. By connecting them by a single
relation, he got a ``complex'' of lines; by connecting them
\index{Complex of lines}%
with a twofold relation, he got a ``congruency'' of lines. His
first researches on this subject were laid before the Royal
Society in~1865. His further investigations thereon appeared
in 1868 in a posthumous work entitled \textit{Neue Geometrie des
Raumes gegründet auf die Betrachtung der geraden Linie als
Raumelement}, edited by Felix Klein. Plücker's analysis lacks
\index{Klein!ref.\ to}%
the elegance found in Lagrange, Jacobi, Hesse, and Clebsch.
\index{Clebsch!ref.\ to}%
\index{Hesse|(}%
\index{Hesse!ref.\ to}%
\index{Jacobi!ref.\ to}%
\index{Lagrange!ref.\ to}%
For many years he had not kept up with the progress of
geometry, so that many investigations in his last work had
already received more general treatment on the part of others.
The work contained, nevertheless, much that was fresh and
original. The theory of complexes of the second degree, left
unfinished by Plücker, was continued by Felix Klein, who
\index{Plücker|)}%
greatly extended and supplemented the ideas of his master.

\textbf{Ludwig Otto Hesse} (1811--1874) was born at Königsberg, and
studied at the university of his native place under Bessel,
\index{Bessel!ref.\ to}%
Jacobi, Richelot, and F.~Neumann. Having taken the doctor's
\index{Neumann, C.!ref.\ to}%
\index{Neumann, F.~E.!ref.\ to}%
\index{Richelot!ref.\ to}%
degree in 1840, he became docent at Königsberg, and in 1845
extraordinary professor there. Among his pupils at that time
were Durège, Carl Neumann, Clebsch, Kirchhoff. The Königsberg
\index{Durège!ref.\ to}%
\index{Kirchhoff!ref.\ to}%
period was one of great activity for Hesse. Every new
discovery increased his zeal for still greater achievement.
His earliest researches were on surfaces of the second order,
\index{Surfaces, theory of}%
%% -----File: 324.png---Folio 310-------
\index{Invariant}%
and were partly synthetic. He solved the problem to construct
any tenth point of such a surface when nine points are given.
The analogous problem for a conic had been solved by Pascal
\index{Pascal!ref.\ to}%
by means of the hexagram. A difficult problem confronting
mathematicians of this time was that of elimination. Plücker
\index{Elimination}%
had seen that the main advantage of his special method in
analytic geometry lay in the avoidance of algebraic elimination.
Hesse, however, showed how by determinants to make
algebraic elimination easy. In his earlier results he was
anticipated by Sylvester, who published his dialytic method
\index{Sylvester!ref.\ to}%
of elimination in 1840. These advances in algebra Hesse
applied to the analytic study of curves of the third order. By
linear substitutions, he reduced a form of the third degree in
three variables to one of only four terms, and was led to an
important determinant involving the second differential coefficient
of a form of the third degree, called the ``Hessian.''
\index{Hessian}%
The ``Hessian'' plays a leading part in the theory of invariants,
a subject first studied by Cayley. Hesse showed that
his determinant gives for every curve another curve, such that
the double points of the first are points on the second, or
``Hessian." Similarly for surfaces (Crelle, 1844). Many of
\index{Surfaces, theory of}%
the most important theorems on curves of the third order are
due to Hesse. He determined the curve of the 14th order,
which passes through the 56~points of contact of the 28~bi-tangents
of a curve of the fourth order. His great memoir on
this subject (Crelle, 1855) was published at the same time as
was a paper by Steiner treating of the same subject.

Hesse's income at Königsberg had not kept pace with his
growing reputation. Hardly was he able to support himself
and family. In 1855 he accepted a more lucrative position at
Halle, and in 1856 one at Heidelberg. Here he remained until
1868, when he accepted a position at a technic school in
Munich.\Reference{67} At Heidelberg he revised and enlarged upon his
%% -----File: 325.png---Folio 311-------
\index{Gournerie}%
\index{McCullagh}%
previous researches, and published in 1861 his \textit{Vorlesungen
über die Analytische Geometrie des Raumes, insbesondere über
Flächen 2.~Ordnung}. More elementary works soon followed.
While in Heidelberg he elaborated a principle, his ``Uebertragungsprincip."
According to this, there corresponds to every
point in a plane a pair of points in a line, and the projective
geometry of the plane can be carried back to the geometry of
points in a line.

The researches of Plücker and Hesse were continued in England
\index{Hesse|)}%
by Cayley, Salmon, and Sylvester. It may be premised here
\index{Cayley!ref.\ to}%
\index{Salmon|(}%
\index{Sylvester!ref.\ to}%
that among the early writers on analytical geometry in England
was \textbf{James Booth} (1806--1878), whose chief results are embodied
\index{Booth}%
in his \textit{Treatise on Some New Geometrical Methods}; and \textbf{James
MacCullagh} (1809--1846), who was professor of natural philosophy
\index{MacCullagh}%
at Dublin, and made some valuable discoveries on the
theory of quadrics. The influence of these men on the
progress of geometry was insignificant, for the interchange of
scientific results between different nations was not so complete
at that time as might have been desired. In further illustration
of this, we mention that Chasles in France elaborated
\index{Chasles!ref.\ to}%
subjects which had previously been disposed of by Steiner in
\index{Steiner!ref.\ to}%
Germany, and Steiner published researches which had been
given by Cayley, Sylvester, and Salmon nearly five years
earlier. Cayley and Salmon in 1849 determined the straight
lines in a cubic surface, and studied its principal properties,
while Sylvester in 1851 discovered the pentahedron of such a
surface. Cayley extended Plücker's equations to curves of
higher singularities. Cayley's own investigations, and those
of M.~Nöther of Erlangen, G.~H. Halphen (1844--1889) of the
\index{Halphen}%
\index{Nother@{Nöther}}%
Polytechnic School in Paris, De~La~\DPtypo{Gournérie}{Gournerie} of Paris, A.~Brill
\index{Brill, A.}%
of Tübingen, lead to the conclusion that each higher singularity
of a curve is equivalent to a certain number of simple
singularities,---the node, the ordinary cusp, the double tangent,
%% -----File: 326.png---Folio 312-------
\index{Deficiency of curves}%
and the inflection. Sylvester studied the ``twisted Cartesian,''
\index{Sylvester!ref.\ to}%
\index{Twisted Cartesian}%
a curve of the fourth order. Salmon helped powerfully
towards the spreading of a knowledge of the new algebraic and
geometric methods by the publication of an excellent series of
text-books (\textit{Conic Sections}, \textit{Modern Higher Algebra}, \textit{Higher
Plane Curves}, \textit{Geometry of Three Dimensions}), which have
been placed within easy reach of German readers by a free
translation, with additions, made by Wilhelm Fiedler of the
\index{Fiedler}%
Polytechnicum in Zürich. The next great worker in the field
of analytic geometry was Clebsch.
\index{Clebsch}%

\textbf{Rudolf Friedrich Alfred Clebsch} (1833--1872) was born at
Königsberg in Prussia, studied at the university of that place
under Hesse, Richelot, F.~Neumann. From 1858 to 1863 he
\index{Hesse!ref.\ to}%
\index{Neumann, F.~E.!ref.\ to}%
\index{Richelot!ref.\ to}%
held the chair of theoretical mechanics at the Polytechnicum
in Carlsruhe. The study of Salmon's works led him into
algebra and geometry. In 1863 he accepted a position at the
University of \DPtypo{Giesen}{Giessen}, where he worked in conjunction with
Paul Gordan (now of Erlangen). In 1868 Clebsch went to
\index{Gordan}%
Göttingen, and remained there until his death. He worked
successively at the following subjects: Mathematical physics,
the calculus of variations and partial differential equations of
the first order, the general theory of curves and surfaces,
Abelian functions and their use in geometry, the theory of
\index{Abelian functions}%
invariants, and ``Flächenabbildung.''\Reference{68} He proved theorems
on the pentahedron enunciated by Sylvester and Steiner; he
\index{Steiner!ref.\ to}%
made systematic use of ``deficiency'' (\textit{Geschlecht}) as a fundamental
principle in the classification of algebraic curves. The
notion of deficiency was known before him to Abel and Riemann.
\index{Abel!ref.\ to}%
\index{Riemann!ref.\ to}%
At the beginning of his career, Clebsch had shown
how elliptic functions could be advantageously applied to
Malfatti's problem. The idea involved therein, viz.\ the use
\index{Malfatti's problem}%
of higher transcendentals in the study of geometry, led him
to his greatest discoveries. Not only did he apply Abelian
%% -----File: 327.png---Folio 313-------
\index{Armemante}%
\index{Ptolemy!ref.\ to}%
functions to geometry, but conversely, he drew geometry into
the service of Abelian functions.

Clebsch made liberal use of determinants. His study of
\index{Clebsch}%
\index{Determinants}%
curves and surfaces began with the determination of the points
of contact of lines which meet a surface in four consecutive
points. Salmon had proved that these points lie on the intersection
\index{Salmon|)}%
of the surface with a derived surface of the degree
$11n - 24$, but his solution was given in inconvenient form.
Clebsch's investigation thereon is a most beautiful piece of
analysis.

The representation of one surface upon another (\textit{Flächenabbildung}),
\index{Flächenabbildung}%
so that they have a $(1, 1)$ correspondence, was
thoroughly studied for the first time by Clebsch. The representation
of a sphere on a plane is an old problem which
drew the attention of Ptolemæus, Gerard Mercator, Lambert,
\index{Lambert!ref.\ to}%
\index{Mercator, G.}%
Gauss, Lagrange. Its importance in the construction of maps
\index{Gauss!ref.\ to}%
\index{Lagrange!ref.\ to}%
is obvious. Gauss was the first to represent a surface upon
another with a view of more easily arriving at its properties.
Plücker, Chasles, Cayley, thus represented on a plane the
\index{Cayley!ref.\ to}%
\index{Chasles!ref.\ to}%
\index{Plücker!ref.\ to}%
geometry of quadric surfaces; Clebsch and Cremona, that of
\index{Cremona!ref.\ to}%
cubic surfaces. Other surfaces have been studied in the same
way by recent writers, particularly M.~Nöther of Erlangen,
\index{Nother@{Nöther}}%
Armenante, Felix Klein, Korndörfer, Caporali, H.~G. Zeuthen
\index{Caporali}%
\index{Klein!ref.\ to}%
\index{Korndörfer}%
\index{Zeuthen}%
of Copenhagen. A fundamental question which has as yet
received only a partial answer is this: What surfaces can be
represented by a $(1, 1)$ correspondence upon a given surface?
This and the analogous question for curves was studied by
Clebsch. Higher correspondences between surfaces have been
investigated by Cayley and Nöther. The theory of surfaces
has been studied also by \textbf{Joseph Alfred Serret} (1819--1885), professor
\index{Serret}%
at the Sorbonne in Paris, \textbf{Jean Gaston Darboux} of Paris,
\index{Darboux}%
\textit{John Casey} of Dublin (died 1891), \textit{W.~R.~W. Roberts} of Dublin,
\index{Casey}%
\index{Roberts}%
\textit{H.~Schröter} (1829--1892) of Breslau. Surfaces of the
\index{SchroterH@{Schröter, H.}}%
%% -----File: 328.png---Folio 314-------
\index{Differential equations}%
\index{Fresnel's wave-surface}%
fourth order were investigated by Kummer, and Fresnel's
\index{Kummer!ref.\ to}%
wave-surface, studied by Hamilton, is a particular case of
\index{Hamilton, W.~R.!ref.\ to}%
Kummer's quartic surface, with sixteen canonical points and
sixteen singular tangent planes.\Reference{56}

The infinitesimal calculus was first applied to the determination
of the measure of curvature of surfaces by Lagrange,
\index{Curvature, measure of}%
\index{Lagrange!ref.\ to}%
\index{Surfaces, theory of}%
Euler, and \DPtypo{Meunier}{Meusnier} (1754--1793) of Paris. Then followed the
\index{Euler!ref.\ to}%
\index{Meunier}%
researches of Monge and Dupin, but they were eclipsed by
\index{Dupin!ref.\ to}%
\index{Monge!ref.\ to}%
the work of Gauss, who disposed of this difficult subject in a
\index{Gauss!ref.\ to}%
way that opened new vistas to geometricians. His treatment
is embodied in the \textit{Disquisitiones generales circa superficies
curvas} (1827) and \textit{Untersuchungen über gegenstände\DPnote{** Non-capitalization seems to be a legitimate variant} der
höheren Geodäsie} of 1843 and~1846. He defined the measure
of curvature at a point to be the reciprocal of the product
of the two principal radii of curvature at that point. From
this flows the theorem of \textit{Johann August Grunert} (1797--1872;
\index{Grunert}%
professor in Greifswald), that the arithmetical mean of the
radii of curvature of all normal sections through a point is the
radius of a sphere which has the same measure of curvature
as has the surface at that point. Gauss's deduction of the
formula of curvature was simplified through the use of determinants
by \textit{Heinrich Richard Baltzer} (1818--1887) of Giessen.\Reference{69}
\index{Baltzer, R.}%
Gauss obtained an interesting theorem that if one surface be
developed (\textit{abgewickelt}) upon another, the measure of curvature
remains unaltered at each point. The question whether
two surfaces having the same curvature in corresponding
points can be unwound, one upon the other, was answered
by F.~Minding in the affirmative only when the curvature is
\index{Minding}%
constant. The case of variable curvature is difficult, and was
studied by Minding, J.~Liouville (1806--1882) of the Polytechnic
\index{Liouville!ref.\ to}%
School in Paris, Ossian Bonnet of Paris (died 1892).
\index{Bonnet, O.}%
Gauss's measure of curvature, expressed as a function of curvilinear
co-ordinates, gave an impetus to the study of differential-invariants,
\index{Co-ordinates}%
%% -----File: 329.png---Folio 315-------
\index{Analytic geometry|)}%
\index{Kelvin, Lord!ref.\ to}%
or differential-parameters, which have been
investigated by Jacobi, C.~Neumann, Sir James Cockle,
\index{Cockle}%
\index{Jacobi!ref.\ to}%
\index{Neumann, C.!ref.\ to}%
Halphen, and elaborated into a general theory by Beltrami,
\index{Beltrami!ref.\ to}%
\index{Halphen!ref.\ to}%
S.~Lie, and others. Beltrami showed also the connection
between the measure of curvature and the geometric axioms.
\index{Axioms (of geometry)}%

Various researches have been brought under the head of
``analysis situs.'' The subject was first investigated by
\index{Analysis situs}%
Leibniz, and was later treated by Gauss, whose theory of
\index{Gauss!ref.\ to}%
\index{Leibniz!ref.\ to}%
knots (\textit{Verschlingungen}) has been employed recently by J.~B.
Listing, O.~Simony, F.~Dingeldey, and others in their ``topologic
\index{Dingeldey}%
\index{Listing}%
\index{Simony}%
studies.'' Tait was led to the study of knots by Sir
William Thomson's theory of vortex atoms. In the hands
\index{Thomson, Sir William!ref.\ to}%
of Riemann the analysis situs had for its object the determination
\index{Riemann!ref.\ to}%
of what remains unchanged under transformations
brought about by a combination of infinitesimal distortions.
In continuation of his work, Walter Dyck of Munich wrote on
\index{Dyck}%
the analysis situs of three-dimensional spaces.

Of geometrical text-books not yet mentioned, reference
should be made to \textbf{Alfred Clebsch's} \textit{Vorlesungen über Geometrie},
\index{Clebsch!ref.\ to}%
edited by Ferdinand Lindemann, now of Munich; \textbf{Frost's}
\index{Frost}%
\index{Lindemann}%
\textit{Solid Geometry}; \textbf{Durège's} \textit{Ebene Curven dritter Ordnung}.
\index{Durège!ref.\ to}%
\index{Geometry!analytic|)}%


\Section{Algebra}
\index{Algebra!recent|(}%

The progress of algebra in recent times may be considered
under three principal heads: the study of fundamental laws
and the birth of new algebras, the growth of the theory of
equations, and the development of what is called modern
higher algebra.

We have already spoken of George Peacock and D.~F.
\index{Peacock!ref.\ to, X}%
Gregory in connection with the fundamental laws of algebra.
\index{Gregory, David F}%
Much was done in this line by De~Morgan.
%% -----File: 330.png---Folio 316-------

\textbf{Augustus De~Morgan} (1806--1871) was born at Madura (Madras),
\index{Demorgan@{De Morgan}}%
and educated at Trinity College, Cambridge. His scruples
about the doctrines of the established church prevented
him from proceeding to the M.A.~degree, and from sitting
for a fellowship. In 1828 he became professor at the newly
established University of London, and taught there until
1867, except for five years, from 1831--1835. De~Morgan was
a unique, manly character, and pre-eminent as a teacher. The
value of his original work lies not so much in increasing our
stock of mathematical knowledge as in putting it all upon a
thoroughly logical basis. He felt keenly the lack of close
reasoning in mathematics as he received it. He said once:
``We know that mathematicians care no more for logic than
\index{Logic}%
logicians for mathematics. The two eyes of exact science are
mathematics and logic: the mathematical sect puts out the
logical eye, the logical sect puts out the mathematical eye;
each believing that it can see better with one eye than with
two.'' De~Morgan saw with both eyes. He analysed logic
mathematically, and studied the logical analysis of the laws,
symbols, and operations of mathematics; he wrote a \textit{Formal
Logic} as well as a \textit{Double Algebra}, and corresponded both with
Sir William Hamilton, the metaphysician, and Sir William
\index{Hamilton, W.}%
\index{Hamilton, W.~R.!ref.\ to}%
Rowan Hamilton, the mathematician. Few contemporaries
were as profoundly read in the history of mathematics as
was De~Morgan. No subject was too insignificant to receive
his attention. The authorship of ``Cocker's Arithmetic'' and
the work of circle-squarers was investigated as minutely as was
\index{Circle-squarers}%
the history of the invention of the calculus. Numerous articles
of his lie scattered in the volumes of the \textit{Penny} and \textit{English
Cyclopædias}. His \textit{Differential Calculus}, 1842, is still a
standard work, and contains much that is original with the
author. For the \textit{Encyclopædia Metropolitana} he wrote on the
calculus of functions (giving principles of symbolic reasoning)
%% -----File: 331.png---Folio 317-------
and on the theory of probability. Celebrated is his \textit{Budget of
Paradoxes}, 1872. He published memoirs ``On the Foundation
of Algebra'' (\textit{Trans.\ of Cam.\ Phil.\ Soc.}, 1841, 1842, 1844, and~1847).

In Germany symbolical algebra was studied by Martin Ohm,
\index{Ohm, M}%
who wrote a \textit{System der Mathematik} in~1822. The ideas of
Peacock and De~Morgan recognise the possibility of algebras
which differ from ordinary algebra. Such algebras were
indeed not slow in forthcoming, but, like non-Euclidean
geometry, some of them were slow in finding recognition.
This is true of Grassmann's, Bellavitis's, and Peirce's discoveries,
\index{Bellavitis!ref.\ to}%
\index{Grassmann!ref.\ to}%
\index{Peirce, B.!ref.\ to}%
but Hamilton's quaternions met with immediate
\index{Hamilton, W.~R.!ref.\ to}%
\index{Quaternions!ref.\ to}%
appreciation in England. These algebras offer a geometrical
interpretation of imaginaries. During the times of Descartes,
\index{Descartes!ref.\ to}%
Newton, and Euler, we have seen the negative and the imaginary,
\index{Euler!ref.\ to}%
\index{Newton!ref.\ to}%
$\sqrt{-1}$, accepted as numbers, but the latter was still
regarded as an algebraic fiction. The first to give it a geometric
picture, analogous to the geometric interpretation of the
negative, was \textit{H.~Kühn}, a teacher in Danzig, in a publication of
\index{Kuhn@{Kühn, H.}}%
1750--1751. He represented $a\sqrt{-1}$ by a line perpendicular
to the line~$a$, and equal to~$a$ in length, and construed $\sqrt{-1}$ as
the mean proportional between $+1$~and~$-1$. This same idea
was developed further, so as to give a geometric interpretation
of $a + \sqrt{-b}$, by \textit{Jean-Robert Argand} (1768--?) of Geneva,
\index{Argand}%
in a remarkable \textit{Essai} (1806).\Reference{70} The writings of Kühn and
Argand were little noticed, and it remained for Gauss to break
\index{Gauss!ref.\ to}%
down the last opposition to the imaginary. He introduced~$i$ as
an independent unit co-ordinate to~$1$, and $a + ib$ as a ``complex
\index{Complex quantities}%
number.'' The connection between complex numbers and
points on a plane, though artificial, constituted a powerful
aid in the further study of symbolic algebra. The mind
required a visual representation to aid it. The notion of
what we now call vectors was growing upon mathematicians,
%% -----File: 332.png---Folio 318-------
and the geometric addition of vectors in space was discovered
independently by Hamilton, Grassmann, and others, about the
\index{Grassmann!ref.\ to}%
\index{Hamilton, W.~R.}%
same time.

\textbf{William Rowan Hamilton} (1805--1865) was born of Scotch
parents in Dublin. His early education, carried on at home,
was mainly in languages. At the age of thirteen he is said to
have been familiar with as many languages as he had lived
years. About this time he came across a copy of Newton's
\textit{Universal Arithmetic}. After reading that, he took up successively
analytical geometry, the calculus, Newton's \textit{Principia},
Laplace's \textit{Mécanique Céleste}. At the age of eighteen he
published a paper correcting a mistake in Laplace's work. In
1824 he entered Trinity College, Dublin, and in 1827, while he
was still an undergraduate, he was appointed to the chair of
astronomy. His early papers were on optics. In 1832 he
predicted conical refraction, a discovery by aid of mathematics
which ranks with the discovery of Neptune by
Le~Verrier and Adams. Then followed papers on the \textit{Principle
of Varying Action} (1827) and a general method of
\index{Action!varying}%
\index{Varying action, principle of}%
dynamics (1834--1835). He wrote also on the solution of
\index{Dynamics}%
equations of the fifth degree, the hodograph, fluctuating
functions, the numerical solution of differential equations.
\index{Differential equations}%

The capital discovery of Hamilton is his quaternions, in
\index{Quaternions}%
which his study of algebra culminated. In 1835 he published
in the \textit{Transactions of the Royal Irish Academy} his Theory of
Algebraic Couples. He regarded algebra ``as being no mere
art, nor language, nor primarily a science of quantity, but
rather as the science of order of progression.'' Time appeared
to him as the picture of such a progression. Hence his definition
of algebra as ``the science of pure time.'' It was the
subject of years' meditation for him to determine what he
should regard as the product of each pair of a system of perpendicular
directed lines. At last, on the 16th~of October,
%% -----File: 333.png---Folio 319-------
1843, while walking with his wife one evening, along the
Royal Canal in Dublin, the discovery of quaternions flashed
\index{Quaternions}%
upon him, and he then engraved with his knife on a stone in
Brougham Bridge the fundamental formula $i^2 = j^2 = k^2 = ijk =
-1$. At the general meeting of the Irish Academy, a month
later, he made the first communication on quaternions. An
account of the discovery was given the following year in the
\textit{Philosophical Magazine}. Hamilton displayed wonderful fertility
\index{Hamilton, W.~R.}%
in their development. His \textit{Lectures on Quaternions},
delivered in Dublin, were printed in 1852. His \textit{Elements of
Quaternions} appeared in 1866. Quaternions were greatly
admired in England from the start, but on the Continent they
received less \DPtypo{attenttion}{attention}. P.~G. Tait's \textit{Elementary Treatise}
\index{Tait}%
helped powerfully to spread a knowledge of them in England.
Cayley, Clifford, and Tait advanced the subject somewhat by
\index{Cayley!ref.\ to}%
\index{Clifford!ref.\ to}%
original contributions. But there has been little progress in
