recent years, except that made by Sylvester in the solution of
\index{Sylvester!ref.\ to}%
quaternion equations, nor has the application of quaternions
to physics been as extended as was predicted. The change
in notation made in France by Hoüel and by Laisant has been
\index{Houel@{Hoüel}}%
\index{Laisant}%
considered in England as a wrong step, but the true cause for
the lack of progress is perhaps more deep-seated. There is
indeed great doubt as to whether the quaternionic product can
claim a necessary and fundamental place in a system of vector
analysis. Physicists claim that there is a loss of naturalness
in taking the square of a vector to be negative. In order to
meet more adequately their wants, \textit{J.~W. Gibbs} of Yale University
\index{Gibbs!ref.\ to}%
and \textit{A.~Macfarlane} of the University of Texas, have
\index{Macfarlane}%
each suggested an algebra of vectors with a new notation.
Each gives a definition of his own for the product of two
vectors, but in such a way that the square of a vector is
positive. A third system of vector analysis has been used by
\textit{Oliver Heaviside} in his electrical researches.
\index{Heaviside}%
%% -----File: 334.png---Folio 320-------

\textbf{Hermann Grassmann} (1809--1877) was born at Stettin,
\index{Grassmann|(}%
attended a gymnasium at his native place (where his father
was teacher of mathematics and physics), and studied theology
in Berlin for three years. In 1834 he succeeded Steiner as
\index{Steiner!ref.\ to}%
teacher of mathematics in an industrial school in Berlin, but
returned to Stettin in 1836 to assume the duties of teacher of
mathematics, the sciences, and of religion in a school there.\Reference{71}
Up to this time his knowledge of mathematics was pretty
much confined to what he had learned from his father, who
had written two books on ``Raumlehre'' and ``Grössenlehre.''
But now he made his acquaintance with the works of Lacroix,
\index{Lacroix}%
Lagrange, and Laplace. He noticed that Laplace's results
\index{Laplace!ref.\ to}%
could be reached in a shorter way by some new ideas advanced
in his father's books, and he proceeded to elaborate this
abridged method, and to apply it in the study of tides. He
was thus led to a new geometric analysis. In 1840 he had
made considerable progress in its development, but a new
book of Schleiermacher drew him again to theology. In
1842 he resumed mathematical research, and becoming thoroughly
convinced of the importance of his new analysis,
decided to devote himself to it. It now became his ambition
to secure a mathematical chair at a university, but in this he
never succeeded. In 1844 appeared his great classical work,
the \textit{Lineale Ausdehnungslehre}, which was full of new and
\index{Ausdehnungslehre}%
strange matter, and so general, abstract, and out of fashion in
its mode of exposition, that it could hardly have had less
influence on European mathematics during its first twenty
years, had it been published in China.\DPnote{ouch} Gauss, Grunert, and
\index{Gauss!ref.\ to}%
\index{Grunert!ref.\ to}%
Möbius glanced over it, praised it, but complained of the
\index{Mobius@{Möbius}!ref.\ to}%
strange terminology and its ``philosophische Allgemeinheit.''
Eight years afterwards, Bretschneider of Gotha was said to be
\index{Bretschneider}%
the only man who had read it through. An article in \textit{Crelle's
Journal}, in which Grassmann eclipsed the geometers of that
%% -----File: 335.png---Folio 321-------
\index{Curves!theory of}%
\index{Differential equations}%
\index{Matrices}%
time by constructing, with aid of his method, geometrically
any algebraic curve, remained again unnoticed. Need we marvel
if Grassmann turned his attention to other subjects,---to
Schleiermacher's philosophy, to politics, to philology? Still,
articles by him continued to appear in \textit{Crelle's Journal}, and in
1862 came out the second part of his \textit{Ausdehnungslehre}. It
\index{Ausdehnungslehre}%
was intended to show better than the first part the broad
scope of the Ausdehnungslehre, by considering not only geometric
applications, but by treating also of algebraic functions,
infinite series, and the differential and integral calculus. But
the second part was no more appreciated than the first. At the
age of fifty-three, this wonderful man, with heavy heart, gave
up mathematics, and directed his energies to the study of Sanskrit,
achieving in philology results which were better appreciated,
and which vie in splendour with those in mathematics.

Common to the Ausdehnungslehre and to quaternions are geometric
addition, the function of two vectors represented in quaternions
by $S\alpha\beta$~and~$V\alpha\beta$, and the linear vector functions. The
quaternion is peculiar to Hamilton, while with Grassmann we
\index{Hamilton, W.~R.!ref.\ to}%
find in addition to the algebra of vectors a geometrical algebra
of wide application, and resembling Möbius's \textit{Barycentrische
\index{Mobius@{Möbius}!ref.\ to}%
Calcul}, in which the point is the fundamental element. Grassmann
developed the idea of the ``external product,'' the ``internal
product,'' and the ``open product.'' The last we now call
a matrix. His Ausdehnungslehre has very great extension,
having no limitation to any particular number of dimensions.
Only in recent years has the wonderful richness of
his discoveries begun to be appreciated. A second edition of
the \textit{Ausdehnungslehre} of 1844 was printed in 1877. C.~S.
Peirce gave a representation of Grassmann's system in the
\index{Peirce, C.~S.!ref.\ to}%
logical notation, and E.~W. Hyde of the University of Cincinnati
\index{Hyde}%
wrote the first text-book on Grassmann's calculus in
\index{Grassmann|)}%
the English language.
%% -----File: 336.png---Folio 322-------
\index{Aequipollences@{Æquipollences}}%

Discoveries of less value, which in part covered those of
Grassmann and Hamilton, were made by \textit{Saint-Venant} (1797--1886),
\index{Saint-Venant!ref.\ to}%
who described the multiplication of vectors, and the
addition of vectors and oriented areas; by \textit{Cauchy}, whose
\index{Cauchy!ref.\ to}%
``clefs algébriques'' were units subject to combinatorial multiplication,
and were applied by the author to the theory of
elimination in the same way as had been done earlier by
Grassmann; by \textbf{Justus Bellavitis} (1803--1880), who published
\index{Bellavitis}%
in 1835 and 1837 in the \textit{Annali delle Scienze} his calculus of
æquipollences. Bellavitis, for many years professor at Padua,
was a self-taught mathematician of much power, who in his
thirty-eighth year laid down a city office in his native place,
Bassano, that he might give his time to science.\Reference{65}

The first impression of Grassmann's ideas is marked in the
writings of \textbf{Hermann Hankel} (1839--1873), who published in
\index{Hankel}%
1867 his \textit{Vorlesungen über die Complexen Zahlen}. Hankel,
then docent in Leipzig, had been in correspondence with
Grassmann. The ``alternate numbers'' of Hankel are subject
\index{Alternate numbers}%
to his law of combinatorial multiplication. In considering
the foundations of algebra Hankel affirms the principle of
the permanence of formal laws previously enunciated incompletely
by Peacock. Hankel was a close student of mathematical
history, and left behind an unfinished work thereon.
Before his death he was professor at Tübingen. His \textit{\DPtypo{Complexe}{Complexen}
Zahlen} was at first little read, and we must turn to
\textbf{Victor Schlegel} of Hagen as the successful interpreter of Grassmann.
\index{Schlegel}%
Schlegel was at one time a young colleague of Grassmann
at the Marienstifts-Gymnasium in Stettin. Encouraged
by Clebsch, Schlegel wrote a \textit{System der Raumlehre} which
\index{Clebsch!ref.\ to}%
explained the essential conceptions and operations of the
Ausdehnungslehre.

Multiple algebra was powerfully advanced by Peirce, whose
theory is not geometrical, as are those of Hamilton and Grassmann.
%% -----File: 337.png---Folio 323-------
\textbf{Benjamin Peirce} (1809--1880) was born at Salem, Mass.,
\index{Peirce, B.}%
\index{Peirce, C.~S.}%
and graduated at Harvard College, having as undergraduate
carried the study of mathematics far beyond the limits of the
college course.\Reference{2} When Bowditch was preparing his translation
\index{Bowditch}%
and commentary of the \textit{Mécanique Céleste}, young Peirce
helped in reading the proof-sheets. He was made professor at
Harvard in 1833, a position which he retained until his death.
For some years he was in charge of the \textit{Nautical Almanac}
and superintendent of the United States Coast Survey. He
published a series of college text-books on mathematics, an
\textit{Analytical Mechanics}, 1855, and calculated, together with Sears~C.
Walker of Washington, the orbit of Neptune. Profound
\index{Walker}%
are his researches on \textit{Linear Associative Algebra}. The first of
\index{Linear associative algebra}%
several papers thereon was read at the first meeting of the
American Association for the Advancement of Science in 1864.
Lithographed copies of a memoir were distributed among friends
in 1870, but so small seemed to be the interest taken in this
subject that the memoir was not printed until 1881 (\textit{Am.\ Jour.\
Math.}, Vol.~IV., No.~2). Peirce works out the multiplication
tables, first of \emph{single} algebras, then of \emph{double} algebras, and so
on up to sextuple, making in all 162~algebras, which he shows
to be possible on the consideration of symbols $A$,~$B$,~etc.,
which are linear functions of a determinate number of letters
or units $i$,~$j$, $k$,~$l$,~etc., with coefficients which are ordinary analytical
magnitudes, real or imaginary,---the letters $i$,~$j$,~etc.,
being such that every binary combination $i^2$,~$ij$, $ji$,~etc., is equal
to a linear function of the letters, but under the restriction of
satisfying the associative law.\Reference{56} \textit{Charles~S. Peirce}, a son of
Benjamin Peirce, and one of the foremost writers on mathematical
logic, showed that these algebras were all defective
\index{Logic}%
forms of quadrate algebras which he had previously discovered
by logical analysis, and for which he had devised a simple
notation. Of these quadrate algebras quaternions is a simple
%% -----File: 338.png---Folio 324-------
example; nonions is another. C.~S. Peirce showed that of all
linear associative algebras there are only three in which division
is unambiguous. These are ordinary single algebra,
ordinary double algebra, and quaternions, from which the
imaginary scalar is excluded. He showed that his father's
algebras are operational and matricular. Lectures on multiple
algebra were delivered by J.~J. Sylvester at the Johns Hopkins
\index{Sylvester!ref.\ to}%
University, and published in various journals. They treat
largely of the algebra of matrices. The theory of matrices
\index{Matrices}%
was developed as early as 1858 by Cayley in an important
\index{Cayley!ref.\ to}%
memoir which, in the opinion of Sylvester, ushered in the
reign of Algebra the Second. Clifford, Sylvester, H.~Taber,
\index{Clifford!ref.\ to}%
\index{Taber}%
C.~H. Chapman, carried the investigations much further. The
\index{Chapman}%
originator of matrices is really Hamilton, but his theory, published
\index{Hamilton, W.~R.!ref.\ to}%
in his \textit{Lectures on Quaternions}, is less general than that
of Cayley. The latter makes no reference to Hamilton.

The theory of determinants\Reference[]{73} was studied by Hoëné Wronski
\index{Determinants}%
\index{Wronski}%
in Italy and J.~Binet in France; but they were forestalled by
\index{Binet}%
the great master of this subject, Cauchy. In a paper (\textit{Jour.\
\index{Cauchy!ref.\ to}%
de l'ecole Polyt.}, IX.,~16) Cauchy developed several general
theorems. He introduced the name \emph{determinant}, a term
previously used by Gauss in the functions considered by him.
\index{Gauss!ref.\ to}%
In 1826 Jacobi began using this calculus, and he gave brilliant
\index{Jacobi!ref.\ to}%
proof of its power. In 1841 he wrote extended memoirs on
determinants in \textit{Crelle's Journal}, which rendered the theory
easily accessible. In England the study of linear transformations
of quantics gave a powerful impulse. Cayley developed
skew-determinants and Pfaffians, and introduced the use of
determinant brackets, or the familiar pair of upright lines.
More recent researches on determinants appertain to special
forms. ``Continuants'' are due to Sylvester; ``alternants,''
originated by Cauchy, have been developed by Jacobi, N.~Trudi,
\index{Trudi}%
H.~Nägelbach, and G.~Garbieri; ``axisymmetric determinants,''
\index{Garbieri}%
\index{Nagelbach@{Nägelbach}}%
%% -----File: 339.png---Folio 325-------
\index{Invariant}%
first used by Jacobi, have been studied by V.~A. Lebesgue,
\index{Lebesgue}%
Sylvester, and Hesse; ``circulants'' are due to E.~Catalan of
\index{Catalan, E.}%
\index{Hesse!ref.\ to}%
\index{Sylvester!ref.\ to}%
Liège, W.~Spottiswoode (1825--1883), J.~W.~L. Glaisher, and
\index{Glaisher!ref.\ to}%
\index{Spottiswoode}%
R.~F. Scott; for ``centro-symmetric determinants'' we are
\index{Determinants}%
\index{Scott}%
indebted to G.~Zehfuss. E.~B. Christoffel of Strassburg and
\index{Christoffel}%
\index{Zehfuss}%
G.~Frobenius discovered the properties of ``Wronskians,'' first
\index{Frobenius}%
used by Wronski. V.~Nachreiner and S.~Günther, both of
\index{Nachreiner}%
Munich, pointed out relations between determinants and continued
fractions; Scott uses Hankel's alternate numbers in his
\index{Hankel!ref.\ to}%
treatise. Text-books on determinants were written by Spottiswoode
(1851), Brioschi (1854), Baltzer (1857), Günther
\index{Baltzer, R.!ref.\ to}%
\index{Brioschi!ref.\ to}%
\index{Gunther@{Günther, S.}}%
(1875), Dostor (1877), Scott (1880), Muir (1882), Hanus
\index{Dostor}%
\index{Hanus}%
\index{Muir}%
(1886).

Modern higher algebra is especially occupied with the
theory of linear transformations. Its development is mainly
the work of Cayley and Sylvester.
\index{Cayley}%

\textbf{Arthur Cayley}, born at Richmond, in Surrey, in 1821, was
educated at Trinity College, Cambridge.\Reference{74} He came out Senior
Wrangler in 1842. He then devoted some years to the study
and practice of law. On the foundation of the Sadlerian professorship
at Cambridge, he accepted the offer of that chair,
thus giving up a profession promising wealth for a very
modest provision, but which would enable him to give all his
time to mathematics. Cayley began his mathematical publications
in the \textit{Cambridge Mathematical Journal} while he was
still an undergraduate. Some of his most brilliant discoveries
were made during the time of his legal practice. There is
hardly any subject in pure mathematics which the genius of
Cayley has not enriched, but most important is his creation
of a new branch of analysis by his theory of invariants.
Germs of the principle of invariants are found in the writings
of Lagrange, Gauss, and particularly of Boole, who
\index{Boole!ref.\ to}%
\index{Gauss!ref.\ to}%
\index{Lagrange!ref.\ to}%
showed, in 1841, that invariance is a property of discriminants
%% -----File: 340.png---Folio 326-------
generally, and who applied it to the theory of orthogonal
substitution. Cayley set himself the problem to determine
\index{Cayley}%
\textit{a~priori} what functions of the coefficients of a given equation
possess this property of invariance, and found, to begin with,
in 1845, that the so-called ``hyper-determinants'' possessed it.
Boole made a number of additional discoveries. Then Sylvester
\index{Sylvester}%
began his papers in the \textit{Cambridge and Dublin Mathematical
Journal} on the Calculus of Forms. After this,
discoveries followed in rapid succession. At that time Cayley
and Sylvester were both residents of London, and they
stimulated each other by frequent oral communications. It
has often been difficult to determine how much really belongs
to each.

\textbf{James Joseph Sylvester} was born in London in 1814, and
educated at St.~Johns College, Cambridge. He came out
Second Wrangler in 1837. His Jewish origin incapacitated
him from taking a degree. In 1846 he became a student at
the Inner Temple, and was called to the bar in 1850. He
became professor of natural philosophy at University College,
London; then, successively, professor of mathematics at the
University of Virginia, at the Royal Military Academy in
Woolwich, at the Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore,
and is, since 1883, professor of geometry at Oxford. His
first printed paper was on Fresnel's optic theory, 1837. Then
followed his researches on invariants, the theory of equations,
theory of partitions, multiple algebra, the theory of numbers,
and other subjects mentioned elsewhere. About 1874 he took
part in the development of the geometrical theory of link-work %[** PP: Only instance]
movements, originated by the beautiful discovery of
A.~Peaucellier, Capitaine du Génie à Nice (published in
\index{Peaucellier}%
\textit{Nouvelles Annales}, 1864 and 1873), and made the subject
of close study by A.~B. Kempe. To Sylvester is ascribed the
\index{Kempe}%
general statement of the theory of contravariants, the discovery
\index{Contravariants}%
%% -----File: 341.png---Folio 327-------
\index{Macmahon}%
of the partial differential equations satisfied by the
invariants and covariants of binary quantics, and the subject
\index{Covariants}%
of mixed concomitants. In the \textit{American Journal of Mathematics}
are memoirs on binary and ternary quantics, elaborated
partly with aid of \textit{F.~Franklin}, now professor at the Johns
\index{Franklin}%
Hopkins University. At Oxford, Sylvester has opened up a
new subject, the theory of reciprocants, treating of the functions
\index{Reciprocants}%
of a dependent variable~$y$ and the functions of its differential
coefficients in regard to~$x$, which remain unaltered by
the interchange of $x$~and~$y$. This theory is more general than
one on differential invariants by Halphen (1878), and has
\index{Differential invariants}%
\index{Halphen!ref.\ to}%
been developed further by J.~Hammond of Oxford, McMahon
\index{Hammond, J}%
of Woolwich, A.~R. Forsyth of Cambridge, and others. Sylvester
\index{Forsyth}%
playfully lays claim to the appellation of the Mathematical
Adam, for the many names he has introduced into
mathematics. Thus the terms \emph{invariant}, \emph{discriminant}, \emph{Hessian},
\index{Hessian}%
\emph{Jacobian}, are his.

The great theory of invariants, developed in England mainly
by Cayley and Sylvester, came to be studied earnestly in Germany,
France, and Italy. One of the earliest in the field was
\textbf{Siegfried Heinrich Aronhold} (1819--1884), who demonstrated
\index{Aronhold}%
the existence of invariants, $S$~and~$T$, of the ternary cubic.
Hermite discovered evectants and the theorem of reciprocity
named after him. Paul Gordan showed, with the aid of
\index{Gordan}%
symbolic methods, that the number of distinct forms for a
binary quantic is finite. Clebsch proved this to be true for
\index{Clebsch!ref.\ to}%
quantics with any number of variables. A very much simpler
proof of this was given in 1891, by David Hilbert of Königsberg.
\index{Hilbert}%
In Italy, F.~Brioschi of Milan and \textit{Faà de Bruno}
\index{Brioschi}%
\index{Bruno, Faà de}%
(1825--1888) contributed to the theory of invariants, the
latter writing a text-book on binary forms, which ranks by
the side of Salmon's treatise and those of Clebsch and
Gordan. Among other writers on invariants are E.~B. Christoffel,
\index{Christoffel}%
%% -----File: 342.png---Folio 328-------
\index{Burkhardt, H.}%
\index{Invariant}%
\index{Sylvester!ref.\ to}%
\index{Tchirnhausen!ref.\ to}%
Wilhelm Fiedler, P.~A. McMahon, J.~W.~L. Glaisher of
\index{Fiedler}%
\index{Glaisher!ref.\ to}%
\index{McMahon}%
Cambridge, Emory McClintock of New York. McMahon discovered
\index{McClintock}%
that the theory of semi-invariants is a part of that of
\index{Semi-invariants}%
symmetric functions. The modern higher algebra has reached
\index{Symmetric functions}%
out and indissolubly connected itself with several other
branches of mathematics---geometry, calculus of variations,
\index{Calculus!of variations}%
mechanics. Clebsch extended the theory of binary forms to
\index{Clebsch!ref.\ to}%
\index{Mechanics!more recent work}%
ternary, and applied the results to geometry. Clebsch, Klein,
\index{Klein!ref.\ to}%
Weierstrass, Burckhardt, and Bianchi have used the theory of
\index{Bianchi}%
\index{Weierstrass!ref.\ to}%
invariants in hyperelliptic and Abelian functions.
\index{Abelian functions}%
\index{Hyperelliptic functions}%

In the theory of equations Lagrange, Argand, and Gauss
\index{Equations!theory of|(}%
furnished proof to the important theorem that every algebraic
equation has a real or a complex root. Abel proved rigorously
\index{Abel!ref.\ to}%
that the general algebraic equation of the fifth or of higher
degrees cannot be solved by radicals (\textit{Crelle},~I., 1826). A modification
of Abel's proof was given by Wantzel. Before Abel,
\index{Wantzel}%
an Italian physician, \textit{Paolo Ruffini} (1765--1822), had printed
\index{Ruffini}%
proofs of the insolvability, which were criticised by his
countryman Malfatti. Though inconclusive, Ruffini's papers
\index{Malfatti}%
are remarkable as containing anticipations of Cauchy's theory
\index{Cauchy!ref.\ to}%
of groups.\Reference{76} A transcendental solution of the quintic involving
\index{Groups, theory of|(}%
elliptic integrals was given by Hermite (\textit{Compt.\ Rend.}, 1858,
\index{Elliptic integrals}%
\index{Hermite!ref.\ to}%
1865, 1866). After Hermite's first publication, Kronecker, in
\index{Kronecker!ref.\ to}%
1858, in a letter to Hermite, gave a second solution in which
was obtained a simple resolvent of the sixth degree. \textit{Jerrard}, in
\index{Jerrard}%
his \textit{Mathematical Researches} (1832--1835), reduced the quintic
to the trinomial form by an extension of the method of
Tschirnhausen. This important reduction had been effected
as early as 1786 by \textit{E.~S. Bring}, a Swede, and brought out
\index{Bring}%
in a publication of the University of Lund. Jerrard, like
Tschirnhausen, believed that his method furnished a general
algebraic solution of equations of any degree. In 1836 William~R.
Hamilton made a report on the validity of Jerrard's
\index{Hamilton, W.~R.!ref.\ to}%
%% -----File: 343.png---Folio 329-------
\index{Elliptic functions}%
\index{Hamilton's numbers}%
method, and showed that by his process the quintic could be
transformed to any one of the four trinomial forms. Hamilton
defined the limits of its applicability to higher equations.
Sylvester investigated this question, What is the lowest degree
an equation can have in order that it may admit of being
deprived of $i$~consecutive terms by aid of equations not higher
than $i$th~degree. He carried the investigation as far as $i = 8$,
and was led to a series of numbers which he named ``Hamilton's
numbers.'' A transformation of equal importance to Jerrard's
is that of Sylvester, who expressed the quintic as the sum of
three fifth-powers. The covariants and invariants of higher
equations have been studied much in recent years.

Abel's proof that higher equations cannot always be solved
algebraically led to the inquiry as to what equations of a given
degree can be solved by radicals. Such equations are the
ones discussed by Gauss in considering the division of the
\index{Division of the circle}%
\index{Gauss!ref.\ to}%
circle. Abel advanced one step further by proving that an
\index{Circle!division of}%
irreducible equation can always be solved in radicals, if, of
two of its roots, the one can be expressed rationally in terms
of the other, provided that the degree of the equation is
prime; if it is not prime, then the solution depends upon
that of equations of lower degree. Through geometrical considerations,
Hesse came upon algebraically solvable equations
\index{Hesse!ref.\ to}%
of the ninth degree, not included in the previous groups.
The subject was powerfully advanced in Paris by the youthful
\textit{Evariste Galois} (born, 1811; killed in a duel, 1832), who
\index{Galois}%
introduced the notion of a group of substitutions. To him are
\index{Substitutions, theory of}%
due also some valuable results in relation to another set of
equations, presenting themselves in the theory of elliptic
functions, viz.\ the modular equations. Galois's labours gave
\index{Modular equations}%
birth to the important theory of substitutions, which has been
\index{Theory of substitutions}%
greatly advanced by \textit{C.~Jordan} of Paris, \textit{J.~A. Serret} (1819--1885)
\index{Jordan}%
of the Sorbonne in Paris, L.~Kronecker (1823--1891) of
\index{Kronecker}%
%% -----File: 344.png---Folio 330-------
\index{Sturm's theorem}%
\index{Warring}%
Berlin, Klein of Göttingen, M.~Nöther of Erlangen, C.~Hermite
\index{Hermite!ref.\ to}%
\index{Klein!ref.\ to}%
\index{Nother@{Nöther}}%
of Paris, A.~Capelli of Naples, L.~Sylow of Friedrichshald,
\index{Capelli}%
\index{Sylow}%
E.~Netto of Giessen. Netto's book, the \textit{Substitutionstheorie},
\index{Netto}%
has been translated into English by F.~N. Cole of
\index{Cole}%
the University of Michigan, who contributed to the theory.
A simple group of 504~substitutions of nine letters, discovered
by Cole, has been shown by E.~H. Moore of the University of
\index{Moore}%
Chicago to belong to a doubly-infinite system of simple groups.
\index{Groups, theory of|)}%
The theory of substitutions has important applications in the
theory of differential equations. Kronecker published, in 1882,
\index{Kronecker!ref.\ to}%
his \textit{Grundzüge einer Arithmetischen Theorie der Algebraischen
Grössen}.

Since Fourier and Budan, the solution of numerical equations
has been advanced by \textit{W.~G. Horner} of Bath, who gave
\index{Horner}%
an improved method of approximation (\textit{Philosophical Transactions},
1819). \textbf{Jacques Charles François Sturm} (1803--1855), a
\index{Sturm, J.~C.~F.}%
native of Geneva, Switzerland, and the successor of Poisson
\index{Poisson!ref.\ to}%
in the chair of mechanics at the Sorbonne, published in 1829
his celebrated theorem determining the number and situation
of roots of an equation comprised between given limits. Sturm
tells us that his theorem stared him in the face in the midst
of some mechanical investigations connected with the motion
of a compound pendulum.\Reference{77} This theorem, and Horner's
method, offer together sure and ready means of finding the
real roots of a numerical equation.

The symmetric functions of the sums of powers of the roots
\index{Symmetric functions}%
of an equation, studied by Newton and Waring, was considered
\index{Newton!ref.\ to}%
more recently by Gauss, Cayley, Sylvester, Brioschi. Cayley
\index{Brioschi!ref.\ to}%
\index{Cayley!ref.\ to}%
\index{Gauss!ref.\ to}%
\index{Sylvester!ref.\ to}%
gives rules for the ``weight'' and ``order'' of symmetric functions.

The theory of elimination was greatly advanced by Sylvester,
\index{Elimination}%
Cayley, Salmon, Jacobi, Hesse, Cauchy, Brioschi, and
\index{Cauchy!ref.\ to}%
\index{Hesse!ref.\ to}%
\index{Jacobi!ref.\ to}%
\index{Salmon}%
Gordan. Sylvester gave the dialytic method (\textit{Philosophical
\index{Dialytic method of elimination}%
\index{Gordan}%
%% -----File: 345.png---Folio 331-------
\index{Algebra!recent|)}%
Magazine}, 1840), and in 1852 established a theorem relating
to the expression of an eliminant as a determinant. Cayley
made a new statement of Bézout's method of elimination and
\index{Bezout's@{Bézout's method of elimination}}%
\index{Elimination}%
established a general theory of elimination (1852).

\Section{Analysis}
\index{Analysis!modern|(}%

Under this head we find it convenient to consider the subjects
of the differential and integral calculus, the calculus of
variations, infinite series, probability, and differential equations.
\index{Equations!theory of|)}%
Prominent in the development of these subjects was
Cauchy.
\index{Cauchy|(}%

\textbf{Augustin-Louis Cauchy}\Reference[]{78} (1789--1857) was born in Paris,
and received his early education from his father. Lagrange
and Laplace, with whom the father came in frequent contact,
foretold the future greatness of the young boy. At the
École Centrale du Panthéon he excelled in ancient classical
studies. In 1805 he entered the Polytechnic School, and two
years later the École des Ponts et Chaussées. Cauchy left for
Cherbourg in 1810, in the capacity of engineer. Laplace's
\textit{Mécanique Céleste and} Lagrange's \textit{Fonctions Analytiques} were
among his book companions there. Considerations of health
induced him to return to Paris after three years. Yielding to
the persuasions of Lagrange and Laplace, he renounced engineering
in favour of pure science. We find him next holding
a professorship at the Polytechnic School. On the expulsion
of Charles~X., and the accession to the throne of Louis Philippe
in 1830, Cauchy, being exceedingly conscientious, found himself
unable to take the oath demanded of him. Being, in
consequence, deprived of his positions, he went into voluntary
exile. At Fribourg in Switzerland, Cauchy resumed his
studies, and in 1831 was induced by the king of Piedmont to
%% -----File: 346.png---Folio 332-------
accept the chair of mathematical physics, especially created
for him at the university of Turin. In 1833 he obeyed the
call of his exiled king, Charles~X., to undertake the education
of a grandson, the Duke of Bordeaux. This gave Cauchy an
opportunity to visit various parts of Europe, and to learn how
extensively his works were being read. Charles~X. bestowed
upon him the title of Baron. On his return to Paris in 1838,
a chair in the College de France was offered to him, but the
oath demanded of him prevented his acceptance. He was
nominated member of the Bureau of Longitude, but declared
ineligible by the ruling power. During the political events of
1848 the oath was suspended, and Cauchy at last became
professor at the Polytechnic School. On the establishment of
the second empire, the oath was re-instated, but Cauchy and
Arago were exempt from it. Cauchy was a man of great
\index{Arago}%
piety, and in two of his publications staunchly defended the
Jesuits.

Cauchy was a prolific and profound mathematician. By a
prompt publication of his results, and the preparation of
standard text-books, he exercised a more immediate and
beneficial influence upon the great mass of mathematicians
than any contemporary writer. He was one of the leaders
in infusing rigour into analysis. His researches extended
over the field of series, of imaginaries, theory of numbers,
differential equations, theory of substitutions, theory of functions,
determinants, mathematical astronomy, light, elasticity,
etc.,---covering pretty much the whole realm of mathematics,
pure and applied.

Encouraged by Laplace and Poisson, Cauchy published in
1821 his \textit{Cours d'Analyse de l'École Royale Polytechnique}, a
work of great merit. Had it been studied more diligently by
writers of text-books in England and the United States, many
a lax and loose method of analysis hardly as yet eradicated
%% -----File: 347.png---Folio 333-------
\index{Differential equations}%
from elementary text-books would have been discarded over
half a century ago. Cauchy was the first to publish a
rigorous proof of Taylor's theorem. He greatly improved
\index{Taylor's theorem}%
the exposition of fundamental principles of the differential
\index{Differential calculus!philosophy of}%
calculus by his mode of considering limits and his new theory
\index{Calculus!of variations|(}%
on the continuity of functions. The method of Cauchy and
\index{Continuity}%
Duhamel was accepted with favour by Hoüel and others. In
\index{Duhamel}%
England special attention to the clear exposition of fundamental
principles was given by De~Morgan. Recent American
\index{Demorgan@{De Morgan}!ref.\ to}%
treatises on the calculus introduce time as an independent variable,
and the allied notions of velocity and acceleration---thus
virtually returning to the method of fluxions.
\index{Fluxions}%

Cauchy made some researches on the calculus of variations.
\index{Cauchy|)}%
This subject is now in its essential principles the same as
when it came from the hands of Lagrange. Recent studies
pertain to the variation of a double integral when the limits
are also variable, and to variations of multiple integrals in
general. Memoirs were published by Gauss in 1829, Poisson
\index{Gauss!ref.\ to}%
\index{Poisson!ref.\ to}%
in 1831, and Ostrogradsky of St.~Petersburg in 1834, without,
\index{Ostrogradsky}%
however, determining in a general manner the number and
form of the equations which must subsist at the limits in case
of a double or triple integral. In 1837 Jacobi published a
\index{Jacobi!ref.\ to}%
memoir, showing that the difficult integrations demanded by
the discussion of the second variation, by which the existence
of a maximum or minimum can be ascertained, are included
in the integrations of the first variation, and thus are superfluous.
This important theorem, presented with great brevity
by Jacobi, was elucidated and extended by V.~A. Lebesgue,
\index{Lebesgue}%
C.~E. Delaunay, Eisenlohr, S.~Spitzer, Hesse, and Clebsch. An
\index{Clebsch!ref.\ to}%
\index{Delaunay!ref.\ to}%
\index{Eisenlohr}%
\index{Hesse!ref.\ to}%
\index{Spitzer}%
important memoir by Sarrus on the question of determining
\index{Sarrus}%
the limiting equations which must be combined with the
indefinite equations in order to determine completely the
maxima and minima of multiple integrals, was awarded a
\index{Maxima and minima}%
%% -----File: 348.png---Folio 334-------
\index{Criteria of convergence|(}%
\index{Jellet}%
prize by the French Academy in 1845, honourable mention
being made of a paper by Delaunay. Sarrus's method was
\index{Delaunay!ref.\ to}%
simplified by Cauchy. In 1852 G.~Mainardi attempted to
\index{Mainardi}%
exhibit a new method of discriminating maxima and minima,
\index{Maxima and minima}%
and extended Jacobi's theorem to double integrals. Mainardi
and F.~Brioschi showed the value of determinants in exhibiting
\index{Brioschi!ref.\ to}%
\index{Determinants}%
the terms of the second variation. In 1861 \textit{Isaac Todhunter}
\index{Todhunter}%
(1820--1884) of St.~John's College, Cambridge, published
his valuable work on the \textit{History of the Progress of the Calculus
of Variations}, which contains researches of his own. In 1866
he published a most important research, developing the theory
of discontinuous solutions (discussed in particular cases by
Legendre), and doing for this subject what Sarrus had done
for multiple integrals.

The following are the more important authors of systematic
treatises on the calculus of variations, and the dates of publication:
\index{Calculus!of variations|)}%
Robert Woodhouse, Fellow of Caius College, Cambridge,
\index{Woodhouse}%
1810; Richard Abbatt in London, 1837; John Hewitt
\index{Abbatt}%
Jellett (1817--1888), once Provost of Trinity College, Dublin,
1850; G.~W. Strauch in \DPtypo{Zurich}{Zürich}, 1849; Moigno and Lindelöf,
\index{Lindelöf}%
\index{Moigno}%
\index{Strauch}%
1861; Lewis Buffett Carll of Flushing in New York, 1881.
\index{Carll}%

The lectures on definite integrals, delivered by Dirichlet in
\index{Definite integrals}%
\index{Dirichlet!ref.\ to}%
1858, have been elaborated into a standard work by G.~F.
Meyer. The subject has been treated most exhaustively by
\index{Meyer, G.~F.}%
D.~Bierens de Haan of Leiden in his \textit{Exposé de la théorie des
\index{Haan}%
intégrals définies}, Amsterdam, 1862.

The history of infinite series illustrates vividly the salient
\index{Infinite series|(}%
feature of the new era which analysis entered upon during the
\index{Analysis!modern|)}%
first quarter of this century. Newton and Leibniz felt the
\index{Leibniz!ref.\ to}%
\index{Newton!ref.\ to}%
necessity of inquiring into the convergence of infinite series,
\index{Convergence of series|(}%
but they had no proper criteria, excepting the test advanced
by Leibniz for alternating series. By Euler and his contemporaries
\index{Euler!ref.\ to}%
the \emph{formal} treatment of series was greatly extended,
%% -----File: 349.png---Folio 335-------
\index{Multiplication of series}%
while the necessity for determining the convergence was generally
lost sight of. Euler reached some very pretty results
on infinite series, now well known, and also some very
\index{Absolutely convergent series}%
absurd results, now quite forgotten. The faults of his time
found their culmination in the Combinatorial School in Germany,
\index{Combinatorial School}%
which has now passed into deserved oblivion. At the
beginning of the period now under consideration, the doubtful,
or plainly absurd, results obtained from infinite series stimulated
profounder inquiries into the validity of operations with
them. Their \emph{actual contents} came to be the primary, \emph{form} a
secondary, consideration. The first important and strictly
rigorous investigation of series was made by Gauss in connection
\index{Gauss!ref.\ to}%
with the hypergeometric series. The criterion developed
\index{Hypergeometric series}%
by him settles the question of convergence in every case
which it is intended to cover, and thus bears the stamp of
generality so characteristic of Gauss's writings. Owing to the
strangeness of treatment and unusual rigour, Gauss's paper
excited little interest among the mathematicians of that time.

More fortunate in reaching the public was Cauchy, whose
\index{Cauchy!ref.\ to}%
\textit{Analyse Algébrique} of 1821 contains a rigorous treatment of
series. All series whose sum does not approach a fixed limit
as the number of terms increases indefinitely are called divergent.
Like Gauss, he institutes comparisons with geometric
series, and finds that series with positive terms are convergent
or not, according as the $n$th root of the $n$th term, or the ratio
of the $(n + 1)$th term and the $n$th term, is ultimately less
or greater than unity. To reach some of the cases where
these expressions become ultimately unity and fail, Cauchy
established two other tests. He showed that series with negative
\Addendlabel{335}%
terms converge when the absolute values of the terms
converge, and then deduces Leibniz's test for alternating
series. The product of two convergent series was not found
to be necessarily convergent. Cauchy's theorem that the
%% -----File: 350.png---Folio 336-------
product of two absolutely convergent series converges to the
product of the sums of the two series was shown half a century
later by F.~Mertens of Graz to be still true if, of the two
\index{Mertens}%
convergent series to be multiplied together, only one is absolutely
convergent.

The most outspoken critic of the old methods in series
was Abel. His letter to his friend Holmboe (1826) contains
\index{Abel!ref.\ to}%
\index{Holmboe}%
severe criticisms. It is very interesting reading, even to
modern students. In his demonstration of the binomial theorem
he established the theorem that if two series and their
product series are all convergent, then the product series will
converge towards the product of the sums of the two given
series. This remarkable result would dispose of the whole
problem of multiplication of series if we had a universal
\index{Multiplication of series}%
practical criterion of convergency for semi-convergent series.
\index{Semi-convergent series}%
Since we do not possess such a criterion, theorems have been
recently established by A.~Pringsheim of Munich and A.~Voss
\index{Pringsheim|(}%
\index{Voss!ref.\ to}%
of Würzburg which remove in certain cases the necessity of
applying tests of convergency to the product series by the
application of tests to easier related expressions. Pringsheim
reaches the following interesting conclusions: The product
of two semi-convergent series can never converge absolutely,
but a semi-convergent series, or even a divergent series, multiplied
by an absolutely convergent series, \emph{may} yield an absolutely
convergent product.

The researches of Abel and Cauchy caused a considerable
stir. We are told that after a scientific meeting in which
Cauchy had presented his first researches on series, Laplace
\index{Laplace!ref.\ to}%
hastened home and remained there in seclusion until he had
examined the series in his \textit{Mécanique Céleste}. Luckily, every
one was found to be convergent! We must not conclude,
however, that the new ideas at once displaced the old. On the
contrary, the new views were generally accepted only after a
%% -----File: 351.png---Folio 337-------
severe and long struggle. As late as 1844 De~Morgan began a
\index{Demorgan@{De Morgan}!ref.\ to}%
paper on ``divergent series'' in this style: ``I believe it will
\index{Absolutely convergent series}%
\index{Divergent series}%
be generally admitted that the heading of this paper describes
the only subject yet remaining, of an elementary character, on
which a serious schism exists among mathematicians as to the
absolute correctness or incorrectness of results.''

First in time in the evolution of more delicate criteria of
convergence and divergence come the researches of Josef Ludwig
Raabe (\textit{Crelle}, Vol.~IX.); then follow those of De~Morgan
\index{Raabe}%
as given in his calculus. De~Morgan established the logarithmic
criteria which were discovered in part independently
by J.~Bertrand. The forms of these criteria, as given by
\index{Bertrand}%
Bertrand and by Ossian Bonnet, are more convenient than
\index{Bonnet, O.!ref.\ to}%
De~Morgan's. It appears from Abel's posthumous papers
\index{Abel!ref.\ to}%
that he had anticipated the above-named writers in establishing
logarithmic criteria. It was the opinion of Bonnet
\index{Logarithmic criteria of convergence}%
that the logarithmic criteria never fail; but Du~Bois-Reymond
\index{Bois-Reymond, P.~du|(}%
and Pringsheim have each discovered series demonstrably
convergent in which these criteria fail to determine
the convergence. The criteria thus far alluded to have
been called by Pringsheim \emph{special} criteria, because they all
depend upon a comparison of the $n$th term of the series
with special functions $a^n$, $n^x$, $n(\log n)^x$, etc. Among the
first to suggest \emph{general} criteria, and to consider the subject
from a still wider point of view, culminating in a regular
mathematical theory, was Kummer. He established a theorem
\index{Kummer!ref.\ to}%
yielding a test consisting of two parts, the first part of
which was afterwards found to be superfluous. The study
of general criteria was continued by U.~Dini of Pisa, Paul
\index{Dini}%
Du~Bois-Reymond, G.~Kohn of Minden, and Pringsheim.
\index{Kohn}%
Du~Bois-Reymond divides criteria into two classes: criteria
of the \emph{first kind} and criteria of the \emph{second kind}, according as
the general $n$th term, or the ratio of the $(n + 1)$th term and
%% -----File: 352.png---Folio 338-------
the $n$th~term, is made the basis of research. Kummer's is a
\index{Kummer!ref.\ to}%
criterion of the second kind. A criterion of the first kind,
analogous to this, was invented by Pringsheim. From the
general criteria established by Du~Bois-Reymond and Pringsheim
respectively, all the special criteria can be derived. The
theory of Pringsheim is very complete, and offers, in addition
\index{Pringsheim|)}%
to the criteria of the first kind and second kind, entirely new
criteria of a \emph{third kind}, and also generalised criteria of the
second kind, which apply, however, only to series with never
\index{Absolutely convergent series}%
increasing terms. Those of the third kind rest mainly on the
consideration of the limit of the difference either of consecutive
terms or of their reciprocals. In the generalised criteria
of the second kind he does not consider the ratio of two consecutive
terms, but the ratio of any two terms however far
apart, and deduces, among others, two criteria previously given
by Kohn and Ermakoff respectively.

Difficult questions arose in the study of Fourier's series.\Reference{79}
\index{Fourier's series}%
Cauchy was the first who felt the necessity of inquiring into
\index{Cauchy!ref.\ to}%
its convergence. But his mode of proceeding was found
by Dirichlet to be unsatisfactory. Dirichlet made the first
\index{Dirichlet!ref.\ to}%
thorough researches on this subject (\textit{Crelle}, Vol.~IV.). They
culminate in the result that whenever the function does not
become infinite, does not have an infinite number of discontinuities,
and does not possess an infinite number of
maxima and minima, then Fourier's series converges toward
the value of that function at all places, except points of
discontinuity, and there it converges toward the mean of
the two boundary values. Schläfli of Bern and Du~Bois-Reymond
\index{Schlafli@{Schläfli}!ref.\ to}%
expressed doubts as to the correctness of the mean
value, which were, however, not well founded. Dirichlet's
conditions are sufficient, but not necessary. Lipschitz, of
\index{Lipschitz!ref.\ to}%
Bonn, proved that Fourier's series still represents the function
when the number of discontinuities is infinite, and
%% -----File: 353.png---Folio 339-------
\index{Criteria of convergence|)}%
\index{Definite integrals}%
\index{Undulatory theory of light}%
established a condition on which it represents a function
having an infinite number of maxima and minima. Dirichlet's
\index{Dirichlet!ref.\ to}%
\index{Maxima and minima}%
belief that all continuous functions can be represented
by Fourier's series at all points was shared by Riemann and
\index{Fourier's series}%
\index{Riemann!ref.\ to}%
H.~Hankel, but was proved to be false by Du~Bois-Reymond
\index{Hankel!ref.\ to}%
and H.~A. Schwarz.
\index{Schwarz!ref.\ to}%

Riemann inquired what properties a function must have,
so that there may be a trigonometric series which, whenever
\index{Trigonometric series}%
it is convergent, converges toward the value of the function.
He found necessary and sufficient conditions for this. They
do not decide, however, whether such a series actually represents
the function or not. Riemann rejected Cauchy's definition
\index{Cauchy!ref.\ to}%
of a definite integral on account of its arbitrariness, gave
a new definition, and then inquired when a function has an
integral. His researches brought to light the fact that continuous
functions need not always have a differential coefficient.
But this property, which was shown by Weierstrass to
\index{Weierstrass!ref.\ to}%
belong to large classes of functions, was not found necessarily
to exclude them from being represented by Fourier's series.
Doubts on some of the conclusions about Fourier's series were
thrown by the observation, made by Weierstrass, that the
integral of an infinite series can be shown to be equal to the
\index{Infinite series|)}%
sum of the integrals of the separate terms only when the series
converges \emph{uniformly} within the region in question. The subject
of uniform convergence was investigated by Philipp Ludwig
\index{Convergence of series|)}%
Seidel (1848) and G.~G. Stokes (1847), and has assumed
\index{Seidel}%
\index{Stokes!ref.\ to}%
great importance in Weierstrass' theory of functions. It
became necessary to prove that a trigonometric series representing
a continuous function converges uniformly. This was
done by Heinrich Eduard Heine (1821--1881), of Halle. Later
\index{Heine}%
researches on Fourier's series were made by G.~Cantor and
\index{Cantor, G.}%
Du~Bois-Reymond.
\index{Bois-Reymond, P.~du|)}%

As compared with the vast development of other mathematical
%% -----File: 354.png---Folio 340-------
branches, the theory of probability has made very
\index{Probability}%
insignificant progress since the time of Laplace. Improvements
\index{Laplace!ref.\ to}%
and \DPtypo{simplications}{simplifications} in the mode of exposition have been
made by A.~De~Morgan, G.~Boole, A.~Meyer (edited by E.~Czuber),
\index{Boole!ref.\ to}%
\index{Czuber}%
\index{Demorgan@{De Morgan}!ref.\ to}%
\index{Meyer, A.}%
J.~Bertrand. Cournot's and Westergaard's treatment
\index{Bertrand}%
\index{Cournot}%
\index{Westergaard}%
of insurance and the theory of life-tables are classical. Applications
\index{Insurance}%
of the calculus to statistics have been made by L.~A.~J.
\index{Statistics}%
Quetelet (1796--1874), director of the observatory at Brussels;
\index{Quetelet}%
by Lexis; Harald Westergaard, of Copenhagen; and Düsing.
\index{Dusing@{Düsing}}%
\index{Lexis}%

Worthy of note is the rejection of inverse probability by the
\index{Inverse probability}%
best authorities of our time. This branch of probability had
been worked out by Thomas Bayes (died 1761) and by Laplace
\index{Bayes}%
(Bk.~II., Ch.~VI. of his \textit{Théorie Analytique}). By it some
logicians have explained induction. For example, if a man,
\index{Induction}%
who has never heard of the tides, were to go to the shore of the
Atlantic Ocean and witness on $m$~successive days the rise of the
sea, then, says Quetelet, he would be entitled to conclude that
there was a probability equal to $\dfrac{m+1}{m+2}$ that the sea would rise
next day. Putting $m = 0$, it is seen that this view rests upon
the unwarrantable assumption that the probability of a totally
unknown event is~$\frac{1}{2}$, or that of all theories proposed for investigation
one-half are true. W.~S. Jevons in his \textit{Principles of
\index{Jevons}%
Science} founds induction upon the theory of inverse probability,
and F.~Y. Edgeworth also accepts it in his \textit{Mathematical
\index{Edgeworth}%
Psychics}.

The only noteworthy recent addition to probability is the
subject of ``local probability,'' developed by several English
\index{Local probability}%
and a few American and French mathematicians. The earliest
problem on this subject dates back to the time of Buffon, the
\index{Buffon}%
naturalist, who proposed the problem, solved by himself and
Laplace, to determine the probability that a short needle,
thrown at random upon a floor ruled with equidistant parallel
%% -----File: 355.png---Folio 341-------
lines, will fall on one of the lines. Then came Sylvester's
\index{Sylvester!ref.\ to}%
four-point problem: to find the probability that four points,
\index{Four-point problem}%
\index{Probability}%
taken at random within a given boundary, shall form a re-entrant %[** PP: Only instance]
quadrilateral. Local probability has been studied in
England by A.~R. Clarke, H.~McColl, S.~Watson, J.~Wolstenholme,
\index{Clarke}%
\index{McColl}%
\index{Watson, S.}%
\index{Wolstenholme}%
but with greatest success by \textit{M.~W. Crofton} of the
\index{Crofton}%
military school at Woolwich. It was pursued in America by
E.~B. Seitz; in France by C.~Jordan, E.~Lemoine, E.~Barbier,
\index{Barbier}%
\index{Jordan!ref.\ to}%
\index{Lemoine}%
\index{Seitz}%
and others. Through considerations of local probability,
Crofton was led to the evaluation of certain definite integrals.
\index{Definite integrals}%

The first full scientific treatment of differential equations
\index{Differential equations|(}%
was given by Lagrange and Laplace. This remark is especially
true of partial differential equations. The latter were investigated
\index{Partial differential equations|etseq}%
in more recent time by Monge, Pfaff, Jacobi, Émile Bour
\index{Bour}%
\index{Jacobi!ref.\ to}%
\index{Monge!ref.\ to}%
\index{Pfaff}%
(1831--1866) of Paris, A.~Weiler, Clebsch, A.~N. Korkine of St.~Petersburg,
\index{Clebsch!ref.\ to}%
\index{Korkine!ref.\ to}%
\index{Weiler}%
G.~Boole, A.~Meyer, Cauchy, Serret, Sophus Lie,
\index{Boole!ref.\ to}%
\index{Cauchy!ref.\ to}%
\index{Lie!ref.\ to}%
\index{Meyer, A.}%
\index{Serret!ref.\ to}%
and others. In 1873 their \DPtypo{reseaches}{researches}, on partial differential
equations of the first order, were presented in text-book form
by Paul Mansion, of the University of Gand. The keen
\index{Mansion}%
researches of \textbf{Johann Friedrich Pfaff} (1795--1825) marked a
decided advance. He was an intimate friend of young Gauss
at Göttingen. Afterwards he was with the astronomer Bode.
\index{Bode}%
Later he became professor at Helmstädt, then at Halle. By a
peculiar method, Pfaff found the general integration of partial
differential equations of the first order for any number
of variables. Starting from the theory of ordinary differential
equations of the first order in $n$~variables, he gives first their
general integration, and then considers the integration of the
partial differential equations as a particular case of the former,
assuming, however, as known, the general integration of differential
equations of any order between two variables. His
researches led Jacobi to introduce the name ``Pfaffian problem.''
\index{Pfaffian problem}%
From the connection, observed by Hamilton, between
\index{Hamilton, W.~R.!ref.\ to}%
%% -----File: 356.png---Folio 342-------
\index{Maxima and minima}%
\index{Pfaffian problem}%
a system of ordinary differential equations (in analytical
mechanics) and a partial differential equation, Jacobi drew
the conclusion that, of the series of systems whose successive
integration Pfaff's method demanded, all but the first system
\index{Pfaff}%
were entirely superfluous. Clebsch considered Pfaff's problem
\index{Clebsch!ref.\ to}%
from a new point of view, and reduced it to systems of simultaneous
linear partial differential equations, which can be
established independently of each other without any integration.
Jacobi materially advanced the theory of differential
equations of the first order. The problem to determine unknown
functions in such a way that an integral containing
these functions and their differential coefficients, in a prescribed
manner, shall reach a maximum or minimum value,
demands, in the first place, the vanishing of the first variation
of the integral. This condition leads to differential equations,
the integration of which determines the functions. To ascertain
whether the value is a maximum or a minimum, the
second variation must be examined. This leads to new and
difficult differential equations, the integration of which, for
the simpler cases, was ingeniously deduced by Jacobi from
the integration of the differential equations of the first variation.
Jacobi's solution was perfected by Hesse, while Clebsch
\index{Hesse!ref.\ to}%
extended to the general case Jacobi's results on the second
variation. Cauchy gave a method of solving partial differential
\index{Cauchy!ref.\ to}%
equations of the first order having any number of
variables, which was corrected and extended by Serret, J.~Bertrand,
\index{Bertrand}%
\index{Serret!ref.\ to}%
O.~Bonnet in France, and Imschenetzky in Russia.
\index{Bonnet, O.!ref.\ to}%
\index{Imschenetzky}%
Fundamental is the proposition of Cauchy that every ordinary
differential equation admits in the vicinity of any non-singular
point of an integral, which is synectic within a certain circle
of convergence, and is developable by Taylor's theorem.
\index{Taylor's theorem}%
Allied to the point of view indicated by this theorem is that
of Riemann, who regards a function of a single variable as
\index{Riemann!ref.\ to}%
%% -----File: 357.png---Folio 343-------
\index{Logic}%
defined by the position and nature of its singularities, and
who has applied this conception to that linear differential
equation of the second order, which is satisfied by the hypergeometric
series. This equation was studied also by Gauss
\index{Gauss!ref.\ to}%
and Kummer. Its general theory, when no restriction is
\index{Kummer!ref.\ to}%
imposed upon the value of the variable, has been considered
by J.~Tannery, of Paris, who employed Fuchs' method of
\index{Fuchs}%
\index{Tannery}%
linear differential equations and found all of Kummer's
twenty-four integrals of this equation. This study has been
continued by Édouard Goursat of Paris.
\index{Goursat}%

A standard text-book on \textit{Differential Equations}, including
original matter on integrating factors, singular solutions, and
especially on symbolical methods, was prepared in 1859 by
\textbf{George Boole} (1815--1864), at one time professor in Queen's
\index{Boole}%
University, Cork, Ireland. He was a native of Lincoln, and a
self-educated mathematician of great power. His treatise on
\textit{Finite Differences} (1860) and his \textit{Laws of Thought} (1854) are
\index{Finite differences}%
works of high merit.

The fertility of the conceptions of Cauchy and Riemann
with regard to differential equations is attested by the
researches to which they have given rise on the part of
\textbf{Lazarus Fuchs} of Berlin (born 1835), \textbf{Felix Klein} of Göttingen
\index{Klein}%
(born 1849), \textbf{Henri Poincaré} of Paris (born 1854), and others.
\index{Poincaré}%
The study of linear differential equations entered a new
period with the publication of Fuchs' memoirs of 1866
and~1868. Before this, linear equations with \emph{constant} coefficients
were almost the only ones for which general methods
of integration were known. While the general theory of
these equations has recently been presented in a new light
by Hermite, Darboux, and Jordan, Fuchs began the study
\index{Darboux}%
\index{Hermite!ref.\ to}%
\index{Jordan!ref.\ to}%
from the more general standpoint of the linear differential
equations whose coefficients are not constant. He directed
his attention mainly to those whose integrals are all regular.
%% -----File: 358.png---Folio 344-------
\index{Invariant}%
If the variable be made to describe all possible paths enclosing
one or more of the critical points of the equation, we
have a certain substitution corresponding to each of the
paths; the aggregate of all these substitutions being called
a \emph{group}. The forms of integrals of such equations were
examined by Fuchs and by G.~Frobenius by independent
\index{Frobenius}%
\index{Fuchs!ref.\ to}%
methods. Logarithms generally appear in the integrals of
a group, and Fuchs and Frobenius investigated the conditions
under which no logarithms shall appear. Through the study
of groups the reducibility or irreducibility of linear differential
\index{Groups, theory of|(}%
equations has been examined by Frobenius and Leo
Königsberger. The subject of linear differential equations,
\index{Konigsberger@{Königsberger}!ref.\ to}%
not all of whose integrals are regular, has been attacked by
G.~Frobenius of Berlin, W.~Thomé of Greifswald (born 1841),
\index{Thome@{Thomé}}%
and Poincaré, but the resulting theory of irregular integrals
\index{Irregular integrals}%
is as yet in very incomplete form.

The theory of invariants associated with linear differential
equations has been developed by Halphen and by A.~R. Forsyth.
\index{Forsyth}%
\index{Halphen!ref.\ to}%

The researches above referred to are closely connected with
the theory of functions and of groups. Endeavours have thus
\index{Theory of functions}%
been made to determine the nature of the function defined by
a differential equation from the differential equation itself,
and not from any analytical expression of the function, obtained
first by solving the differential equation. Instead of studying
the properties of the integrals of a differential equation for all
the values of the variable, investigators at first contented themselves
with the study of the properties in the vicinity of a
given point. The nature of the integrals at singular points
and at ordinary points is entirely different. \textit{Albert Briot}
\index{Briot}%
(1817--1882) and \textit{Jean Claude Bouquet} (1819--1885), both of
\index{Bouquet}%
Paris, studied the case when, near a singular point, the differential
equations take the form $(x-x_0) \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \displaystyle\int (xy)$. Fuchs
%% -----File: 359.png---Folio 345-------
\index{Kleinian groups}%
\index{Theory of functions}%
gave the development in series of the integrals for the particular
case of linear equations. Poincaré did the same for the
\index{Poincaré!ref.\ to}%
case when the equations are not linear, as also for partial
differential equations of the first order. The developments for
ordinary points were given by Cauchy and Madame Kowalevsky.
\index{Cauchy!ref.\ to}%
\index{Kowalevsky!ref.\ to}%

The attempt to express the integrals by developments that
are always convergent and not limited to particular points in
a plane necessitates the introduction of new transcendents, for
the old functions permit the integration of only a small number
\index{Functions!theory of}%
of differential equations. Poincaré tried this plan with
linear equations, which were then the best known, having
been studied in the vicinity of given points by Fuchs, Thomé,
\index{Fuchs!ref.\ to}%
\index{Thome@{Thomé}!ref.\ to}%
Frobenius, Schwarz, Klein, and Halphen. Confining himself to
\index{Frobenius}%
\index{Halphen!ref.\ to}%
\index{Klein!ref.\ to}%
\index{Schwarz!ref.\ to}%
those with rational algebraical coefficients, Poincaré was able
to integrate them by the use of functions named by him \emph{Fuchsians}.\Reference{81}
He divided these equations into ``families.'' If the
integral of such an equation be subjected to a certain transformation,
the result will be the integral of an equation
belonging to the same family. The new transcendents have a
great analogy to elliptic functions; while the region of the
\index{Elliptic functions}%
latter may be divided into parallelograms, each representing a
group, the former may be divided into curvilinear polygons,
so that the knowledge of the function inside of one polygon
carries with it the knowledge of it inside the others. Thus
Poincaré arrives at what he calls \emph{Fuchsian groups}. He found,
\index{Fuchsian groups}%
moreover, that Fuchsian functions can be expressed as the
\index{Fuchsian functions}%
ratio of two transcendents (theta-fuchsians) in the same way
\index{Theta-fuchsians}%
that elliptic functions can be. If, instead of linear substitutions
with real coefficients, as employed in the above groups,
imaginary coefficients be used, then discontinuous groups are
obtained, which he called \emph{Kleinians}. The extension to non-linear %[** PP: Only instance]
equations of the method thus applied to linear equations
has been begun by Fuchs and Poincaré.
%% -----File: 360.png---Folio 346-------
\index{Abelian functions}%
\index{Algebraic functions}%
\index{Elliptic functions}%

We have seen that among the earliest of the several kinds
of ``groups'' are the finite discontinuous groups (groups in
the theory of substitution), which since the time of Galois
have become the leading concept in the theory of algebraic
equations; that since 1876 Felix Klein, H.~Poincaré, and
\index{Klein!ref.\ to}%
\index{Poincaré!ref.\ to}%
others have applied the theory of finite and infinite discontinuous
groups to the theory of functions and of differential
\index{Theory of functions}%
equations. The finite continuous groups were first made
\index{Groups, theory of|)}%
the subject of general research in 1873 by Sophus Lie, now
\index{Lie}%
of Leipzig, and applied by him to the integration of ordinary
linear partial differential equations.

Much interest attaches to the determination of those linear
differential equations which can be integrated by simpler
functions, such as algebraic, elliptic, or Abelian. This has
been studied by C.~Jordan, P.~Appel of Paris (born 1858), and
\index{Appel}%
\index{Jordan!ref.\ to}%
Poincaré.

The mode of integration above referred to, which makes
known the properties of equations from the standpoint of the
theory of functions, does not suffice in the application of
differential equations to questions of mechanics. If we consider
\index{Mechanics!more recent work}%
the function as defining a plane curve, then the general
form of the curve does not appear from the above mode of
investigation. It is, however, often desirable to construct
the curves defined by differential equations. Studies having
this end in view have been carried on by Briot and Bouquet,
\index{Bouquet!ref.\ to}%
\index{Briot!ref.\ to}%
and by Poincaré.\Reference{81}

The subject of singular solutions of differential equations
has been materially advanced since the time of Boole by G.~Darboux
\index{Boole!ref.\ to}%
\index{Darboux}%
and Cayley. The papers prepared by these mathematicians
\index{Cayley!ref.\ to}%
point out a difficulty as yet unsurmounted: whereas
a singular solution, from the point of view of the integrated
equation, ought to be a phenomenon of universal, or at least of
general occurrence, it is, on the other hand, a very special and
%% -----File: 361.png---Folio 347-------
exceptional phenomenon from the point of view of the differential
equation.\Reference{89} A geometrical theory of singular solutions
resembling the one used by Cayley was previously employed
by W.~W. Johnson of Annapolis.
\index{Johnson}%

An advanced \textit{Treatise on Linear Differential Equations}
(1889) was brought out by Thomas Craig of the Johns Hopkins
\index{Craig, T.}%
University. He chose the algebraic method of presentation
followed by Hermite and Poincaré, instead of the geometric
\index{Hermite!ref.\ to}%
\index{Poincaré!ref.\ to}%
method preferred by Klein and Schwarz. A notable work, the
\index{Klein!ref.\ to}%
\index{Schwarz!ref.\ to}%
\textit{Traité d'Analyse}, is now being published by Émile Picard of
\index{Picard, E.}%
Paris, the interest of which is made to centre in the subject of
differential equations.
\index{Differential equations|)}%


\Section{Theory of Functions}
\index{Theory of functions|(}%

We begin our sketch of the vast progress in the theory of
functions by considering the special class called elliptic functions.
\index{Elliptic functions|(}%
These were richly developed by Abel and Jacobi.
\index{Abel}%
\index{Jacobi!ref.\ to}%

\textbf{Niels Henrick Abel} (1802--1829) was born at Findoë in Norway,
and was prepared for the university at the cathedral
school in Christiania. He exhibited no interest in mathematics
until 1818, when B.~Holmboe became lecturer there,
\index{Holmboe}%
and aroused Abel's interest by assigning original problems
to the class. Like Jacobi and many other young men who
became eminent mathematicians, Abel found the first exercise
of his talent in the attempt to solve by algebra the general
equation of the fifth degree. In 1821 he entered the University
in Christiania. The works of Euler, Lagrange, and
Legendre were closely studied by him. The idea of the inversion
of elliptic functions dates back to this time. His extraordinary
success in mathematical study led to the offer of a
stipend by the government, that he might continue his studies
%% -----File: 362.png---Folio 348-------
\index{Abelian functions}%
\index{Binomial formula}%
\index{Integral calculus}%
in Germany and France. Leaving Norway in 1825, Abel visited
\index{Abel}%
the astronomer, Schumacher, in Hamburg, and spent six
\index{Schumacher!ref.\ to}%
months in Berlin, where he became intimate with \textbf{August
Leopold Crelle} (1780--1855), and met Steiner. Encouraged by
\index{Crelle}%
\index{Steiner!ref.\ to}%
Abel and Steiner, Crelle started his journal in 1826. Abel
began to put some of his work in shape for print. His proof
of the impossibility of solving the general equation of the fifth
degree by radicals,---first printed in 1824 in a very concise
form, and difficult of apprehension,---was elaborated in greater
detail, and published in the first volume. He entered also
upon the subject of infinite series (particularly the binomial
\index{Infinite series}%
theorem, of which he gave in \textit{Crelle's Journal} a rigid general
investigation), the study of functions, and of the integral
calculus. The obscurities everywhere encountered by him
owing to the prevailing loose methods of analysis he endeavoured
to clear up. For a short time he left Berlin for Freiberg,
where he had fewer interruptions to work, and it was
there that he made researches on hyperelliptic and Abelian
\index{Hyperelliptic functions}%
functions. In July, 1826, Abel left Germany for Paris without
having met Gauss! Abel had sent to Gauss his proof of
\index{Gauss!ref.\ to}%
1824 of the impossibility of solving equations of the fifth
\index{Equations!solution of}%
degree, to which Gauss never paid any attention. This slight,
and a haughtiness of spirit which he associated with Gauss,
prevented the genial Abel from going to Göttingen. A similar
feeling was entertained by him later against Cauchy. Abel
\index{Cauchy!ref.\ to}%
remained ten months in Paris. He met there Dirichlet,
\index{Dirichlet!ref.\ to}%
Legendre, Cauchy, and others; but was little appreciated.
He had already published several important memoirs in
\textit{Crelle's Journal}, but by the French this new periodical was
as yet hardly known to exist, and Abel was too modest to
speak of his own work. Pecuniary embarrassments induced
him to return home after a second short stay in Berlin. At
Christiania he for some time gave private lessons, and served
%% -----File: 363.png---Folio 349-------
\index{Elliptic integrals}%
\index{Periodicity of functions}%
as docent. Crelle secured at last an appointment for him at
\index{Crelle!ref.\ to}%
Berlin; but the news of it did not reach Norway until after
the death of Abel at Froland.\Reference{82}

At nearly the same time with Abel, Jacobi published articles
\index{Jacobi!ref.\ to}%
on elliptic functions. Legendre's favourite subject, so long
\index{Legendre!ref.\ to}%
neglected, was at last to be enriched by some extraordinary
discoveries. The advantage to be derived by inverting the
elliptic integral of the first kind and treating it as a function
of its amplitude (now called elliptic function) was recognised
by Abel, and a few months later also by Jacobi. A second
fruitful idea, also arrived at independently by both, is the
introduction of imaginaries leading to the observation that
the new functions simulated at once trigonometric and exponential
functions. For it was shown that while trigonometric
functions had only a real period, and exponential only an imaginary,
\index{Imaginary quantities}%
elliptic functions had both sorts of periods. These two
discoveries were the foundations upon which Abel and Jacobi,
each in his own way, erected beautiful new structures. Abel
developed the curious expressions representing elliptic functions
by infinite series or quotients of infinite products.
\index{Infinite products}%
\index{Infinite series}%
Great as were the achievements of Abel in elliptic functions,
they were eclipsed by his researches on what are now called
Abelian functions. Abel's theorem on these functions was
\index{Abelian functions}%
given by him in several forms, the most general of these
being that in his \textit{Mémoire sur une propriété générale d'une
classe très-étendue de fonctions transcendentes} (1826). The history
of this memoir is interesting. A few months after his
arrival in Paris, Abel submitted it to the French Academy.
Cauchy and Legendre were appointed to examine it; but said
\index{Cauchy!ref.\ to}%
nothing about it until after Abel's death. In a brief statement
of the discoveries in question, published by Abel in \textit{Crelle's
Journal}, 1829, reference is made to that memoir. This led
Jacobi to inquire of Legendre what had become of it. Legendre
%% -----File: 364.png---Folio 350-------
says that the manuscript was so badly written as to be
illegible, and that Abel was asked to hand in a better copy,
\index{Abel!ref.\ to}%
which he neglected to do. The memoir remained in Cauchy's
\index{Cauchy!ref.\ to}%
hands. It was not published until 1841. By a singular mishap,
the manuscript was lost before the proof-sheets were
read.

In its form, the contents of the memoir belongs to the integral
calculus. Abelian integrals depend upon an irrational
\index{Abelian integrals}%
function $y$ which is connected with $x$ by an algebraic equation
$F(x, y) = 0$. Abel's theorem asserts that a sum of such
\index{Addition theorem of elliptic integrals}%
integrals can be expressed by a definite number $p$ of similar
integrals, where $p$ depends merely on the properties of the
equation $F(x, y) = 0$. It was shown later that $p$ is the deficiency
of the curve $F(x, y) = 0$. The addition theorems of
elliptic integrals are deducible from Abel's theorem. The
\index{Elliptic integrals}%
hyperelliptic integrals introduced by Abel, and proved by him
to possess multiple periodicity, are special cases of Abelian
\index{Periodicity of functions}%
integrals whenever $p= \text{or} > 3$. The reduction of Abelian to
elliptic integrals has been studied mainly by Jacobi, Hermite,
\index{Hermite!ref.\ to}%
\index{Jacobi!ref.\ to}%
Königsberger, Brioschi, Goursat, E.~Picard, and O.~Bolza of
\index{Bolza}%
\index{Brioschi!ref.\ to}%
\index{Goursat!ref.\ to}%
\index{Konigsberger@{Königsberger}!ref.\ to}%
\index{Picard, E.}%
the University of Chicago.

Two editions of Abel's works have been published: the first
by Holmboe in 1839, and the second by Sylow and Lie in
\index{Holmboe}%
\index{Lie!ref.\ to}%
\index{Sylow!ref.\ to}%
1881.

Abel's theorem was pronounced by Jacobi the greatest discovery
of our century on the integral calculus. The aged
\index{Integral calculus}%
Legendre, who greatly admired Abel's genius, called it ``\textit{monumentum
\index{Legendre!ref.\ to}%
aere perennius}.'' During the few years of work
allotted to the young Norwegian, he penetrated new fields of
research, the development of which has kept mathematicians
busy for over half a century.

Some of the discoveries of Abel and Jacobi were anticipated
by Gauss. In the \textit{Disquisitiones Arithmeticæ} he observed
\index{Gauss!ref.\ to}%
%% -----File: 365.png---Folio 351-------
that the principles which he used in the division of the circle
were applicable to many other functions, besides the circular,
and particularly to the transcendents dependent on the integral
$\displaystyle\int \frac{dx}{\sqrt{1-x^4}}$. From this Jacobi\Reference[]{83} concluded that Gauss had
\index{Gauss!ref.\ to}%
\index{Jacobi|(}%
thirty years earlier considered the nature and properties of
elliptic functions and had discovered their double periodicity.
The papers in the collected works of Gauss confirm this conclusion.

\textbf{Carl Gustav Jacob Jacobi}\Reference[]{84} (1804--1851) was born of Jewish
parents at Potsdam. Like many other mathematicians he was
initiated into mathematics by reading Euler. At the University
of Berlin, where he pursued his mathematical studies
independently of the lecture courses, he took the degree of
Ph.D. in 1825. After giving lectures in Berlin for two years,
he was elected extraordinary professor at Königsberg, and two
years later to the ordinary professorship there. After the
publication of his \textit{Fundamenta Nova} he spent some time in
travel, meeting Gauss in Göttingen, and Legendre, Fourier,
\index{Fourier!ref.\ to}%
\index{Legendre!ref.\ to}%
Poisson, in Paris. In 1842 he and his colleague, Bessel, attended
\index{Bessel!ref.\ to}%
\index{Poisson!ref.\ to}%
the meetings of the British Association, where they
made the acquaintance of English mathematicians.

His early researches were on Gauss' approximation to the
value of definite integrals, partial differential equations, Legendre's
\index{Definite integrals}%
coefficients, and cubic residues. He read Legendre's
\textit{Exercises}, which give an account of elliptic integrals. When
he returned the book to the library, he was depressed in spirits
and said that important books generally excited in him new
ideas, but that this time he had not been led to a single original
thought. Though slow at first, his ideas flowed all the
richer afterwards. Many of his discoveries in elliptic functions
were made independently by Abel. Jacobi communicated
his first researches to \textit{Crelle's Journal}. In 1829, at the age
%% -----File: 366.png---Folio 352-------
\index{Kowalevsky!ref.\ to}%
of twenty-five, he published his \textit{Fundamenta Nova Theoriæ
Functionum Ellipticarum}, which contains in condensed form
the main results in elliptic functions. This work at once
secured for him a wide reputation. He then made a closer
study of theta-functions and lectured to his pupils on a new
\index{Theta-functions}%
theory of elliptic functions based on the theta-functions. He
developed a theory of transformation which led him to a multitude
of formulæ containing~$q$, a transcendental function of
the modulus, defined by the equation $q = e^{-\pi k'/k}$. He was also
led by it to consider the two new functions $\Eta$~and~$\Theta$, which
taken each separately with two different arguments are the
four (single) theta-functions designated by the $\Theta_1$, $\Theta_2$, $\Theta_3$, $\Theta_4$.\Reference{56}
In a short but very important memoir of 1832, he shows that
for the hyperelliptic integral of any class the direct functions
\index{Hyperelliptic integrals}%
to which Abel's theorem has reference are not functions of a
\index{Abel's theorem}%
single variable, such as the elliptic $\sn$,~$\cn$,~$\dn$, but functions of
$p$~variables.\Reference{56} Thus in the case $p = 2$, which Jacobi especially
considers, it is shown that Abel's theorem has reference to
two functions $\lambda(u, v)$, $\lambda_1(u, v)$, each of two variables, and
gives in effect an addition-theorem for the expression of the
functions $\lambda(u + u', v + v')$, $\lambda_1(u + u', v + v')$ algebraically in
terms of the functions $\lambda(u, v)$, $\lambda_1(u, v)$, $\lambda(u', v')$, $\lambda_1(u', v')$. By
the memoirs of Abel and Jacobi it may be considered that the
notion of the Abelian function of $p$~variables was established
and the addition-theorem for these functions given. Recent
studies touching Abelian functions have been made by Weierstrass,
\index{Abelian functions}%
\index{Weierstrass!ref.\ to}%
E.~Picard, Madame Kowalevski, and Poincaré. Jacobi's
\index{Poincaré!ref.\ to}%
work on differential equations, determinants, dynamics, and
the theory of numbers is mentioned elsewhere.

In 1842 Jacobi visited Italy for a few months to recuperate
\index{Jacobi|)}%
