his health. At this time the Prussian government gave him
a pension, and he moved to Berlin, where the last years of his
life were spent.
%% -----File: 367.png---Folio 353-------

The researches on functions mentioned thus far have been
greatly extended. In 1858 \textbf{Charles Hermite} of Paris (born 1822),
\index{Hermite}%
introduced in place of the variable $q$ of Jacobi a new variable $\omega$
\index{Jacobi!ref.\ to}%
connected with it by the equation $q = e^{i\pi\omega}$, so that $\omega = ik'/k$, and
was led to consider the functions $\phi(\omega)$, $\psi(\omega)$, $\chi(\omega)$.\Reference{56} Henry
Smith regarded a theta-function with the argument equal to
\index{Smith, H.!ref.\ to}%
zero, as a function of $\omega$. This he called an omega-function,
\index{Omega-function}%
while the three functions $\phi(\omega)$, $\psi(\omega)$, $\chi(\omega)$, are his modular
functions. Researches on theta-functions with respect to real
\index{Theta-functions}%
and imaginary arguments have been made by Meissel of Kiel,
\index{Meissel}%
J.~Thomae of Jena, Alfred Enneper of Göttingen (1830--1885).
\index{Enneper}%
\index{Thomae}%
A general formula for the product of two theta-functions was
given in 1854 by H.~Schröter of Breslau (1829--1892). These
\index{SchroterH@{Schröter, H.}!ref.\ to}%
functions have been studied also by Cauchy, Königsberger of
\index{Cauchy!ref.\ to}%
\index{Konigsberger@{Königsberger}}%
Heidelberg (born 1837), F.~S. Richelot of Königsberg (1808--1875),
\index{Richelot}%
Johann Georg Rosenhain of Königsberg (1816--1887),
\index{Rosenhain!ref.\ to}%
L.~Schläfli of Bern (born 1818).\Reference{85}
\index{Schlafli@{Schläfli}!ref.\ to}%

Legendre's method of reducing an elliptic differential to its
\index{Legendre!ref.\ to}%
normal form has called forth many investigations, most important
of which are those of Richelot and of Weierstrass of
\index{Weierstrass!ref.\ to}%
Berlin.

The algebraic transformations of elliptic functions involve
a relation between the old modulus and the new one which
Jacobi expressed by a differential equation of the third order,
and also by an algebraic equation, called by him ``modular
equation.'' The notion of modular equations was familiar to
\index{Modular equations}%
Abel, but the development of this subject devolved upon later
\index{Abel!ref.\ to}%
investigators. These equations have become of importance in
the theory of algebraic equations, and have been studied by
Sohnke, E.~Mathieu, L.~Königsberger, E.~Betti of Pisa (died
\index{Betti}%
\index{Mathieu!ref.\ to}%
\index{Sohnke}%
1892), C.~Hermite of Paris, Joubert of Angers, Francesco
\index{Joubert}%
Brioschi of Milan, Schläfli, H.~Schröter, M.~Gudermann of
\index{Brioschi!ref.\ to}%
\index{Gudermann}%
Cleve, Gützlaff.
\index{Gutzlaff@{Gützlaff}}%
%% -----File: 368.png---Folio 354-------
\index{Invariant}%
\index{Primary factors, Weierstrass' theory of}%

Felix Klein of Göttingen has made an extensive study of
\index{Klein!ref.\ to}%
modular functions, dealing with a type of operations lying
\index{Modular functions}%
between the two extreme types, known as the theory of substitutions
\index{Theory of substitutions}%
and the theory of invariants and covariants. Klein's
\index{Covariants}%
theory has been presented in book-form by his pupil, Robert
Fricke. The bolder features of it were first published in his
\index{Fricke}%
\textit{Ikosaeder}, 1884. His researches embrace the theory of modular
functions as a specific class of elliptic functions, the
statement of a more general problem as based on the doctrine
of groups of operations, and the further development of the
subject in connection with a class of Riemann's surfaces.
\index{Riemann!ref.\ to}%

The elliptic functions were expressed by Abel as quotients
of doubly infinite products. He did not, however, inquire
\index{Infinite products}%
rigorously into the convergency of the products. In 1845
Cayley studied these products, and found for them a complete
\index{Cayley!ref.\ to}%
theory, based in part upon geometrical interpretation, which
he made the basis of the whole theory of elliptic functions.
Eisenstein discussed by purely analytical methods the general
\index{Eisenstein!ref.\ to}%
doubly infinite product, and arrived at results which have
been greatly simplified in form by the theory of primary
factors, due to Weierstrass. A certain function involving a
\index{Weierstrass!ref.\ to}%
doubly infinite product has been called by Weierstrass the
sigma-function, and is the basis of his beautiful theory of
\index{Sigma-function}%
elliptic functions. The first systematic presentation of Weierstrass'
theory of elliptic functions was published in 1886 by
G.~H. Halphen in his \textit{Théorie des fonctions elliptiques et des
\index{Halphen!ref.\ to}%
leurs applications}. Applications of these functions have been
given also by A.~G. Greenhill. Generalisations analogous to
\index{Greenhill}%
those of Weierstrass on elliptic functions have been made
by Felix Klein on hyperelliptic functions.
\index{Hyperelliptic functions}%

Standard works on elliptic functions have been published by
\index{Elliptic functions|)}%
\textit{Briot and Bouquet} (1859), by \textit{Königsberger}, \textit{Cayley}, \textit{Heinrich
\index{Bouquet!ref.\ to}%
\index{Briot!ref.\ to}%
\index{Konigsberger@{Königsberger}!ref.\ to}%
Durège} of Prague (1821--1893), and others.
\index{Durège}%
%% -----File: 369.png---Folio 355-------

Jacobi's work on Abelian and theta-functions was greatly
\index{Theta-functions}%
extended by \textbf{Adolph Göpel} (1812--1847), professor in a gymnasium
\index{Gopel@{Göpel}}%
near Potsdam, and \textbf{Johann Georg Rosenhain} of Königsberg
\index{Rosenhain}%
(1816--1887). Göpel in his \Lat{\textit{Theoriæ transcendentium primi
ordinis adumbratio levis}} (\textit{Crelle},~35, 1847) and Rosenhain in
several memoirs established each independently, on the analogy
of the single theta-functions, the functions of two variables,
called double theta-functions, and worked out in connection
with them the theory of the Abelian functions of two variables.
\index{Abelian functions|(}%
The theta-relations established by Göpel and Rosenhain received
for thirty years no further development, notwithstanding
the fact that the double theta series came to be of increasing
importance in analytical, geometrical, and mechanical problems,
and that Hermite and Königsberger had considered the
\index{Hermite!ref.\ to}%
\index{Konigsberger@{Königsberger}!ref.\ to}%
subject of transformation. Finally, the investigations of C.~W.
Borchardt of Berlin (1817--1880), treating of the representation
\index{Borchardt}%
of Kummer's surface by Göpel's biquadratic relation between
\index{Kummer!ref.\ to}%
four theta-functions of two variables, and researches of H.~H.
Weber of Marburg, F.~Prym of Würzburg, Adolf Krazer, and
\index{Krazer}%
\index{Prym}%
\index{Weber, H.~H.}%
Martin Krause of Dresden led to broader views. Researches
\index{Krause}%
on double theta-functions, made by Cayley, were extended to
\index{Cayley!ref.\ to}%
quadruple theta-functions by Thomas Craig of the Johns
\index{Craig, T.}%
Hopkins University.

Starting with the integrals of the most general form and
considering the inverse functions corresponding to these integrals
(the Abelian functions of $p$~variables), \textit{Riemann}
\index{Riemann!ref.\ to}%
defined the theta-functions of $p$~variables as the sum of a
$p$\nobreakdash-tuply infinite series of exponentials, the general term depending
on $p$~variables. Riemann shows that the Abelian
functions are algebraically connected with theta-functions of
the proper arguments, and presents the theory in the broadest
form.\Reference{56} He rests the theory of the multiple theta-functions
upon the general principles of the theory of functions of a
complex variable.
%% -----File: 370.png---Folio 356-------
\index{Bernoulli, James (born 1758)}%
\index{Bernoulli, John (born 1667)!ref.\ to}%
\index{Riemann's surfaces!ref.\ to}%

Through the researches of A.~Brill of Tübingen, M.~Nöther
\index{Brill, A.}%
\index{Nother@{Nöther}}%
of Erlangen, and Ferdinand Lindemann of Munich, made
\index{Lindemann!ref.\ to}%
in connection with Riemann-Roch's theorem and the theory
\index{Riemann!ref.\ to}%
of residuation, there has grown out of the theory of Abelian
functions a theory of algebraic functions and point-groups on
\index{Functions!definition of}%
\index{Functions!theory of|(}%
algebraic curves.

Before proceeding to the general theory of functions, we
make mention of the ``calculus of functions,'' studied chiefly
\index{Calculus!of variations}%
by C.~Babbage, J.~F.~W. Herschel, and De~Morgan, which was
\index{Babbage}%
\index{Demorgan@{De Morgan}!ref.\ to}%
\index{Herschel, J.~F.~W.!ref.\ to}%
not so much a theory of functions as a theory of the solution
of functional equations by means of known functions or
symbols.

The history of the general theory of functions begins with
the adoption of new definitions of a function. With the
Bernoullis and Leibniz, $y$ was called a function of~$x$, if there
\index{Leibniz!ref.\ to}%
existed an equation between these variables which made it
possible to calculate~$y$ for any given value of~$x$ lying anywhere
between $-\infty$~and~$+\infty$. The study of Fourier's theory
\index{Fourier!ref.\ to}%
of heat led Dirichlet to a new definition: $y$ is called a function
\index{Dirichlet!ref.\ to}%
of~$x$, if $y$ possess one or more definite values for each of certain
values that $x$ is assumed to take in an interval $x_0$~to~$x_1$. In
functions thus defined, there need be no analytical connection
between $y$~and~$x$, and it becomes necessary to look for possible
discontinuities. A great revolution in the ideas of a function
was brought about by Cauchy when, in a function as defined
\index{Cauchy!ref.\ to}%
by Dirichlet, he gave the variables imaginary values, and when
he extended the notion of a definite integral by letting the
variable pass from one limit to the other by a succession of
imaginary values along arbitrary paths. Cauchy established
several fundamental theorems, and gave the first great impulse
to the study of the general theory of functions. His researches
were continued in France by Puiseux and Liouville. But more
\index{Liouville!ref.\ to}%
\index{Puiseux}%
profound investigations were made in Germany by Riemann.
%% -----File: 371.png---Folio 357-------

\textbf{Georg Friedrich Bernhard Riemann} (1826--1866) was born at
\index{Riemann|(}%
Breselenz in Hanover. His father wished him to study
theology, and he accordingly entered upon philological and
theological studies at Göttingen. He attended also some lectures
on mathematics. Such was his predilection for this
science that he abandoned theology. After studying for a
time under Gauss and Stern, he was drawn, in 1847, to Berlin
\index{Gauss!ref.\ to}%
\index{Stern}%
by a galaxy of mathematicians, in which shone Dirichlet,
\index{Dirichlet!ref.\ to}%
Jacobi, Steiner, and Eisenstein. Returning to Göttingen in
\index{Eisenstein!ref.\ to}%
\index{Jacobi!ref.\ to}%
\index{Steiner!ref.\ to}%
1850, he studied physics under Weber, and obtained the
\index{Weber, W.~E.!ref.\ to}%
doctorate the following year. The thesis presented on that
occasion, \textit{Grundlagen für eine allgemeine Theorie der Funktionen
einer veränderlichen complexen Grösse}, excited the admiration of
Gauss to a very unusual degree, as did also Riemann's trial
lecture, \textit{Ueber die Hypothesen welche der Geometrie zu Grunde
liegen}. Riemann's Habilitationsschrift was on the Representation
of a Function by means of a Trigonometric Series, in
\index{Trigonometric series}%
which he advanced materially beyond the position of Dirichlet.
Our hearts are drawn to this extraordinarily gifted but
shy genius when we read of the timidity and nervousness
displayed when he began to lecture at Göttingen, and of his
jubilation over the unexpectedly large audience of eight students
at his first lecture on differential equations.

Later he lectured on Abelian functions to a class of three
\index{Abelian functions|)}%
only,---Schering, Bjerknes, and Dedekind. Gauss died in 1855,
\index{Bjerknes, C. A.}%
\index{Dedekind!ref.\ to}%
\index{Schering!ref.\ to}%
and was succeeded by Dirichlet. On the death of the latter,
in 1859, Riemann was made ordinary professor. In 1860 he
visited Paris, where he made the acquaintance of French
mathematicians. The delicate state of his health induced
him to go to Italy three times. He died on his last trip at
Selasca, and was buried at Biganzolo.

Like all of Riemann's researches, those on functions were
profound and far-reaching. He laid the foundation for a
%% -----File: 372.png---Folio 358-------
\index{Kelvin, Lord!ref.\ to}%
general theory of functions of a complex variable. The theory
of potential, which up to that time had been used only in
\index{Potential}%
mathematical physics, was applied by him in pure mathematics.
He accordingly based his theory of functions on the
partial differential equation, $\dfrac{\partial^2u}{\partial x^2} + \dfrac{\partial^2 u}{\partial y^2} = \Delta u = 0$, which must
hold for the analytical function $w = u + iv$ of $z = x + iy$. It
had been proved by Dirichlet that (for a plane) there is always
one, and only one, function of $x$~and~$y$, which satisfies $\Delta u = 0$,
and which, together with its differential quotients of the first
two orders, is for all values of $x$~and~$y$ within a given area
one-valued and continuous, and which has for points on the
boundary of the area arbitrarily given values.\Reference{86} Riemann
called this ``Dirichlet's principle,'' but the same theorem was
stated by Green and proved analytically by Sir William
\index{Green!ref.\ to}%
Thomson. It follows then that $w$ is uniquely determined for
\index{Thomson, Sir William!ref.\ to}%
all points within a closed surface, if $u$ is arbitrarily given
for all points on the curve, whilst $v$ is given for one point
within the curve. In order to treat the more complicated
case where $w$ has $n$~values for one value of~$z$, and to observe
the conditions about continuity, Riemann invented the celebrated
surfaces, known as ``Riemann's surfaces,'' consisting
\index{Riemann's surfaces}%
of $n$~coincident planes or sheets, such that the passage from
one sheet to another is made at the branch-points, and that the
$n$~sheets form together a multiply-connected surface, which
can be dissected by cross-cuts into a singly-connected surface.
The $n$-valued function~$w$ becomes thus a one-valued function.
Aided by researches of J.~Lüroth of Freiburg and of Clebsch,
\index{Clebsch!ref.\ to}%
\index{Luroth@{Lüroth}}%
W.~K. Clifford brought Riemann's surface for algebraic functions
\index{Clifford!ref.\ to}%
\Addendlabel{358}%
to a canonical form, in which only the two last of the $n$~leaves
are multiply-connected, and then transformed the surface into
the surface of a solid with $p$~holes. A.~Hurwitz of Zürich
\index{Hurwitz}%
discussed the question, how far a Riemann's surface is determinate
%% -----File: 373.png---Folio 359-------
\index{Thomson's theorem}%
by the assignment of its number of sheets, its branch-points
and branch-lines.\Reference{62}

Riemann's theory ascertains the criteria which will determine
an analytical function by aid of its discontinuities and
boundary conditions, and thus defines a function independently
of a mathematical expression. In order to show that
two different expressions are identical, it is not necessary to
transform one into the other, but it is sufficient to prove the
agreement to a far less extent, merely in certain critical points.

Riemann's theory, as based on Dirichlet's principle (Thomson's
\index{Dirichlet!ref.\ to}%
theorem), is not free from objections. It has become
evident that the existence of a derived function is not a consequence
of continuity, and that a function may be integrable
\index{Continuity}%
without being differentiable. It is not known how far the
methods of the infinitesimal calculus and the calculus of
variations (by which Dirichlet's principle is established) can
be applied to an unknown analytical function in its generality.
Hence the use of these methods will endow the functions with
properties which themselves require proof. Objections of this
kind to Riemann's theory have been raised by Kronecker,
\index{Kronecker!ref.\ to}%
Weierstrass, and others, and it has become doubtful whether
\index{Weierstrass}%
\index{Weierstrass!ref.\ to}%
his most important theorems are actually proved. In consequence
of this, attempts have been made to graft Riemann's
speculations on the more strongly rooted methods of Weierstrass.
The latter developed a theory of functions by starting,
not with the theory of potential, but with analytical
expressions and operations. Both applied their theories to
Abelian functions, but there Riemann's work is more general.\Reference{86}
\index{Abelian functions}%

The theory of functions of one complex variable has been
studied since Riemann's time mainly by \textbf{Karl Weierstrass} of
\index{Riemann|)}%
Berlin (born 1815), \textbf{Gustaf Mittag-Leffler} of Stockholm (born
\index{Mittag-Leffler}%
1846), and Poincaré of Paris. Of the three classes of such
\index{Poincaré!ref.\ to}%
%% -----File: 374.png---Folio 360-------
\index{Fuchsian functions}%
\index{Hyperelliptic functions}%
functions (viz.\ functions uniform throughout, functions uniform
only in lacunary spaces, and non-uniform functions)
Weierstrass showed that those functions of the first class
which can be developed according to ascending powers of~$x$
into converging series, can be decomposed into a product of an
infinite number of primary factors. A primary factor of the
\index{Primary factors, Weierstrass' theory of}%
species~$n$ is the product $\left(1- \dfrac{x}{a}\right)e^{\Change{P_{(x)}}{P(x)}}$, $\Change{P_{(x)}}{P(x)}$ being an entire polynomial
of the $n$th~degree. A function of the species~$n$ is one,
all the primary factors of which are of species~$n$. This classification
gave rise to many interesting problems studied also
by Poincaré.

The first of the three classes of functions of a complex
variable embraces, among others, functions having an infinite
number of singular points, but no singular lines, and at the
same time no isolated singular points. These are Fuchsian
functions, existing throughout the whole extent. Poincaré
first gave an example of such a function.

Uniform functions of two variables, unaltered by certain
linear substitutions, called hyperfuchsian functions, have been
studied by E.~Picard of Paris, and by Poincaré.\Reference{81}
\index{Picard, E.}%

Functions of the second class, uniform only in lacunary
spaces, were first pointed out by Weierstrass. The Fuchsian
and the Kleinian functions do not generally exist, except in
\index{Kleinian functions}%
the interior of a circle or of a domain otherwise bounded, and
are therefore examples of functions of the second class.
Poincaré has shown how to generate functions of this class,
and has studied them along the lines marked out by Weierstrass.
Important is his proof that there is no way of
generalising them so as to get rid of the lacunæ.

Non-uniform functions are much less developed than the
preceding classes, even though their properties in the vicinity
of a given point have been diligently studied, and though
%% -----File: 375.png---Folio 361-------
\index{Conform representation of surfaces}%
\index{Infinite series}%
much light has been thrown on them by the use of Riemann's
surfaces. With the view of reducing their study to that of
uniform transcendents, Poincaré proved that if $y$ is any
analytical non-uniform function of~$x$, one can always find a
variable~$z$, such that $x$~and~$y$ are uniform functions of~$z$.

Weierstrass and Darboux have each given examples of continuous
\index{Darboux}%
\index{Weierstrass!ref.\ to}%
functions having no derivatives. Formerly it had
been generally assumed that every function had a derivative.
\Addendlabel{361}%
Ampère was the first who attempted to prove analytically
\index{Ampère!ref.\ to}%
(1806) the existence of a derivative, but the demonstration
is not valid. In treating of discontinuous functions, Darboux
established rigorously the necessary and sufficient condition
that a continuous or discontinuous function be susceptible of
integration. He gave fresh evidence of the care that must
be exercised in the use of series by giving an example of a
series always convergent and continuous, such that the series
formed by the integrals of the terms is always convergent, and
yet does not represent the integral of the first series.\Reference{87}

The general theory of functions of two variables has been
investigated to some extent by Weierstrass and Poincaré.

\textbf{H.~A. Schwarz} of Berlin (born 1845), a pupil of Weierstrass,
\index{Schwarz}%
has given the conform\DPnote{** PP: [sic]} representation (\emph{Abbildung}) of various
surfaces on a circle. In transforming by aid of certain
substitutions a polygon bounded by circular arcs into another
also bounded by circular arcs, he was led to a remarkable
differential equation $\psi(u', t) = \psi(u, t)$, where $\psi(u, t)$ is the
expression which Cayley calls the ``Schwarzian derivative,''
\index{Schwarzian derivative}%
and which led Sylvester to the theory of reciprocants.
\index{Reciprocants}%
\index{Sylvester!ref.\ to}%
Schwarz's developments on minimum surfaces, his work on
hypergeometric series, his inquiries on the existence of solutions
\index{Hypergeometric series}%
to important partial differential equations under prescribed
conditions, have secured a prominent place in mathematical
literature.
%% -----File: 376.png---Folio 362-------
\index{Irrationals}%

The modern theory of functions of one real variable was
first worked out by H.~Hankel, Dedekind, G.~Cantor, Dini, and
\index{Cantor, G.}%
\index{Dedekind!ref.\ to}%
\index{Dini!ref.\ to}%
\index{Hankel!ref.\ to}%
Heine, and then carried further, principally, by Weierstrass,
\index{Heine!ref.\ to}%
\index{Weierstrass!ref.\ to}%
Schwarz, Du~Bois-Reymond, Thomae, and Darboux. Hankel
\index{Bois-Reymond, P.~du}%
\index{Darboux}%
\index{Schwarz!ref.\ to}%
\index{Thomae}%
established the principle of the condensation of singularities;
\index{Condensation of singularities}%
Dedekind and Cantor gave definitions for irrational numbers;
\index{Numbers!theory of numbers|(}%
definite integrals were studied by Thomae, Du~Bois-Reymond,
\index{Definite integrals}%
and Darboux along the lines indicated by the definitions of
such integrals given by Cauchy, Dirichlet, and Riemann. Dini
\index{Cauchy!ref.\ to}%
\index{Dirichlet!ref.\ to}%
\index{Riemann!ref.\ to}%
wrote a text-book on functions of a real variable (1878), which
was translated into German, with additions, by J.~Lüroth and
\index{Luroth@{Lüroth}!ref.\ to}%
A.~Schepp. Important works on the theory of functions are
\index{Schepp}%
the \textit{Cours de M.~Hermite}, \textit{Tannery's Théorie des Fonctions
\index{Hermite!ref.\ to}%
\index{Tannery!ref.\ to}%
d'une variable seule}, \textit{A Treatise on the Theory of Functions} by
\textit{James Harkness} and \textit{Frank Morley}, and \textit{Theory of Functions of
\index{Functions!theory of|)}%
\index{Harkness}%
\index{Morley}%
\index{Theory of functions|)}%
a Complex Variable} by \textit{A.~R. Forsyth}.
\index{Forsyth}%

\Section{Theory of Numbers}
\index{Theory of numbers|(}%

``Mathematics, the queen of the sciences, and arithmetic,
the queen of mathematics.'' Such was the dictum of Gauss,
\index{Gauss!ref.\ to}%
who was destined to revolutionise the theory of numbers.
When asked who was the greatest mathematician in Germany,
Laplace answered, Pfaff. When the questioner said
\index{Laplace!ref.\ to}%
\index{Pfaff!ref.\ to}%
he should have thought Gauss was, Laplace replied, ``Pfaff
is by far the greatest mathematician in Germany; but Gauss
is the greatest in all Europe.''\Reference{83} Gauss is one of the three
greatest masters of modern analysis,---Lagrange, Laplace,
\index{Lagrange!ref.\ to}%
Gauss. Of these three contemporaries he was the youngest.
While the first two belong to the period in mathematical history
preceding the one now under consideration, Gauss is the
one whose writings may truly be said to mark the beginning
%% -----File: 377.png---Folio 363-------
\index{Imaginary quantities}%
\index{Infinite series}%
\index{Kaestner}%
of our own epoch. In him that abundant fertility of invention,
displayed by mathematicians of the preceding period,
is combined with an absolute rigorousness in demonstration
which is too often wanting in their writings, and which the
ancient Greeks might have envied. Unlike Laplace, Gauss
\index{Gauss|(}%
\index{Laplace!ref.\ to}%
strove in his writings after perfection of form. He rivals
Lagrange in elegance, and surpasses this great Frenchman in
\index{Lagrange!ref.\ to}%
rigour. Wonderful was his richness of ideas; one thought followed
another so quickly that he had hardly time to write
down even the most meagre outline. At the age of twenty
Gauss had overturned old theories and old methods in all
branches of higher mathematics; but little pains did he take
to publish his results, and thereby to establish his priority.
He was the first to observe rigour in the treatment of infinite
series, the first to fully recognise and emphasise the importance,
and to make systematic use of determinants and of
\index{Determinants}%
imaginaries, the first to arrive at the method of least squares,
\index{Least squares}%
the first to observe the double periodicity of elliptic functions.
\index{Elliptic functions}%
He invented the heliotrope and, together with Weber, the
\index{Heliotrope}%
\index{Weber, W.~E.!ref.\ to}%
bifilar magnetometer and the declination instrument. He
reconstructed the whole of magnetic science.

\textbf{Carl Friedrich Gauss}\Reference[]{47} (1777--1855), the son of a bricklayer,
was born at Brunswick. He used to say, jokingly, that he
could reckon before he could talk. The marvellous aptitude
for calculation of the young boy attracted the attention of
Bartels, afterwards professor of mathematics at Dorpat, who
brought him under the notice of Charles William, Duke of
Brunswick. The duke undertook to educate the boy, and sent
him to the Collegium Carolinum. His progress in languages
there was quite equal to that in mathematics. In 1795 he
went to Göttingen, as yet undecided whether to pursue philology
or mathematics. Abraham Gotthelf Kästner, then professor
of mathematics there, and now chiefly remembered for
%% -----File: 378.png---Folio 364-------
his \textit{Geschichte der Mathematik} (1796), was not an inspiring
teacher. At the age of nineteen Gauss discovered a method of
inscribing in a circle a regular polygon of seventeen sides, and
this success encouraged him to pursue mathematics. He worked
quite independently of his teachers, and while a student at
Göttingen made several of his greatest discoveries. Higher
arithmetic was his favourite study. Among his small circle
of intimate friends was Wolfgang Bolyai. After completing
\index{Bolyai, Wolfgang!ref.\ to}%
his course he returned to Brunswick. In 1798 and 1799 he
repaired to the university at \Change{Helmstadt}{Helmstädt} to consult the library,
and there made the acquaintance of Pfaff, a mathematician of
much power. In 1807 the Emperor of Russia offered Gauss a
chair in the Academy at St.~Petersburg, but by the advice of
the astronomer Olbers, who desired to secure him as director
\index{Olbers}%
of a proposed new observatory at Göttingen, he declined the
offer, and accepted the place at Göttingen. Gauss had a
marked objection to a mathematical chair, and preferred the
post of astronomer, that he might give all his time to science.
He spent his life in Göttingen in the midst of continuous
work. In 1828 he went to Berlin to attend a meeting of
scientists, but after this he never again left Göttingen, except
in 1854, when a railroad was opened between Göttingen and
Hanover. He had a strong will, and his character showed
a curious mixture of self-conscious dignity and child-like
simplicity. He was little communicative, and at times
morose.

A new epoch in the theory of numbers dates from the publication
of his \textit{Disquisitiones Arithmeticæ}, Leipzig, 1801. The
beginning of this work dates back as far as 1795. Some of its
results had been previously given by Lagrange and Euler, but
\index{Euler!ref.\ to}%
\index{Lagrange!ref.\ to}%
were reached independently by Gauss, who had gone deeply
into the subject before he became acquainted with the writings
of his great predecessors. The \textit{Disquisitiones Arithmeticæ}
%% -----File: 379.png---Folio 365-------
\index{Congruencies, theory of}%
was already in print when Legendre's \textit{Théorie des Nombres}
\index{Legendre!ref.\ to}%
appeared. The great law of quadratic reciprocity, given in
\index{Quadratic reciprocity}%
the fourth section of Gauss' work, a law which involves the
whole theory of quadratic residues, was discovered by him by
induction before he was eighteen, and was proved by him one
year later. Afterwards he learned that Euler had imperfectly
\index{Euler!ref.\ to}%
enunciated that theorem, and that Legendre had attempted
to prove it, but met with apparently insuperable difficulties.
In the fifth section Gauss gave a second proof of this ``gem''
of higher arithmetic. In 1808 followed a third and fourth
demonstration; in 1817, a fifth and sixth. No wonder that
he felt a personal attachment to this theorem. Proofs were
given also by Jacobi, Eisenstein, Liouville, Lebesgue, A.~Genocchi,
\index{Eisenstein!ref.\ to}%
\index{Genocchi}%
\index{Jacobi!ref.\ to}%
\index{Lebesgue}%
\index{Liouville!ref.\ to}%
Kummer, M.~A. Stern, Chr.\ Zeller, Kronecker,
\index{Kronecker!ref.\ to}%
\index{Kummer!ref.\ to}%
\index{Stern}%
\index{Zeller}%
Bouniakowsky, E.~Schering, J.~Petersen, Voigt, E.~Busche,
\index{Bouniakowsky}%
\index{Busche}%
\index{Petersen}%
\index{Schering!ref.\ to}%
\index{Voigt}%
and Th.\ Pepin.\Reference{48} The solution of the problem of the representation
\index{Pepin}%
of numbers by binary quadratic forms is one of the
great achievements of Gauss. He created a new algorithm by
introducing the theory of congruences. The fourth section
of the \textit{Disquisitiones Arithmeticæ}, treating of congruences of
the second degree, and the fifth section, treating of quadratic
forms, were, until the time of Jacobi, passed over with universal
neglect, but they have since been the starting-point of a long
series of important researches. The seventh or last section,
developing the theory of the division of the circle, was received
\index{Circle!division of}%
\index{Division of the circle}%
from the start with deserved enthusiasm, and has since been
repeatedly elaborated for students. A standard work on
\textit{Kreistheilung} was published in 1872 by Paul Bachmann, then
\index{Bachmann!ref.\ to}%
of Breslau. Gauss had planned an eighth section, which was
omitted to lessen the expense of publication. His papers on
the theory of numbers were not all included in his great treatise.
Some of them were published for the first time after his death
in his collected works (1863--1871). He wrote two memoirs on
%% -----File: 380.png---Folio 366-------
\index{Action, least}%
\index{Capillarity}%
\index{Ellipsoid!(attraction of)}%
\index{Geodesy}%
the theory of biquadratic residues (1825 and 1831), the second
\index{Biquadratic residues}%
of which contains a theorem of biquadratic reciprocity.

Gauss was led to astronomy by the discovery of the planet
\index{Astronomy!more recent researches}%
Ceres at Palermo in 1801. His determination of the elements
of its orbit with sufficient accuracy to enable Olbers to \Change{rediscover}{re-discover}
it, made the name of Gauss generally known. In 1809
he published the \textit{Theoria motus corporum coelestium}, which
contains a discussion of the problems arising in the determination
of the movements of planets and comets from
observations made on them under any circumstances. In it
are found four formulæ in spherical trigonometry, now usually
called ``Gauss' Analogies,'' but which were published somewhat
\index{Gauss' Analogies}%
earlier by Karl Brandon Mollweide of Leipzig (1774--1825),
\index{Mollweide}%
and earlier still by Jean Baptiste Joseph Delambre
\index{Delambre}%
(1749--1822).\Reference{44} Many years of hard work were spent in the
astronomical and magnetic observatory. He founded the
German Magnetic Union, with the object of securing continuous
\index{German Magnetic Union}%
observations at fixed times. He took part in geodetic
observations, and in 1843 and 1846 wrote two memoirs, \textit{Ueber
Gegenstände der höheren Geodesie}. He wrote on the attraction
of homogeneous ellipsoids, 1813. In a memoir on capillary
attraction, 1833, he solves a problem in the calculus of
\index{Calculus!of variations}%
variations involving the variation of a certain double integral,
the limits of integration being also variable; it is the earliest
example of the solution of such a problem. He discussed the
problem of rays of light passing through a system of lenses.

Among Gauss' pupils were Christian Heinrich Schumacher,
\index{Schumacher}%
Christian Gerling, Friedrich Nicolai, August Ferdinand
\index{Gerling}%
\index{Nicolai}%
Möbius, Georg Wilhelm Struve,\DPnote{** PP: [sic] no `and'} Johann Frantz Encke.
\index{Encke}%
\index{Mobius@{Möbius}!ref.\ to}%
\index{Struve}%

Gauss' researches on the theory of numbers were the starting-point
for a school of writers, among the earliest of whom
was Jacobi. The latter contributed to \textit{Crelle's Journal} an article
on cubic residues, giving theorems without proofs. After the
\index{Cubic residues}%
%% -----File: 381.png---Folio 367-------
\index{Elliptic functions}%
publication of Gauss' paper on biquadratic residues, giving
the law of biquadratic reciprocity, and his treatment of complex
numbers, Jacobi found a similar law for cubic residues.
\index{Jacobi!ref.\ to}%
By the theory of elliptical functions, he was led to beautiful
theorems on the representation of numbers by $2$,~$4$,~$6$, and~$8$
squares. Next come the researches of Dirichlet, the expounder
\index{Dirichlet|(}%
of Gauss, and a contributor of rich results of his own.

\textbf{Peter Gustav Lejeune Dirichlet}\Reference[]{88} (1805--1859) was born in
Düren, attended the gymnasium in Bonn, and then the
Jesuit gymnasium in Cologne. In 1822 he was attracted to
Paris by the names of Laplace, Legendre, Fourier, Poisson,
\index{Fourier!ref.\ to}%
\index{Legendre!ref.\ to}%
Cauchy. The facilities for a mathematical education there
were far better than in Germany, where Gauss was the only
great figure. He read in Paris Gauss' \textit{Disquisitiones Arithmeticæ},
a work which he never ceased to admire and study.
Much in it was simplified by Dirichlet, and thereby placed
within easier reach of mathematicians. His first memoir on
the impossibility of certain indeterminate equations of the
fifth degree was presented to the French Academy in 1825.
He showed that Fermat's equation, $x^n + y^n = z^n$, cannot exist
\index{Fermat!ref.\ to}%
when $n = 5$. Some parts of the analysis are, however,
Legendre's. Euler and Lagrange had proved this when $n$~is~$3$
\index{Euler!ref.\ to}%
\index{Lagrange!ref.\ to}%
and~$4$, and Lamé proved it when $n = 7$. Dirichlet's acquaintance
\index{Lame@{Lamé}!ref.\ to}%
with Fourier led him to investigate Fourier's series. He
\index{Fourier's series}%
became docent in Breslau in 1827. In 1828 he accepted a
position in Berlin, and finally succeeded Gauss at Göttingen
in 1855. The general principles on which depends the average
number of classes of binary quadratic forms of positive
and negative determinant (a subject first investigated by
Gauss) were given by Dirichlet in a memoir, \textit{Ueber die Bestimmung
\index{Gauss|)}%
der mittleren Werthe in der Zahlentheorie}, 1849. More
recently F.~Mertens of Graz has determined the asymptotic
\index{Mertens}%
values of several numerical functions. Dirichlet gave some
%% -----File: 382.png---Folio 368-------
attention to prime numbers. Gauss and Legendre had given
\index{Prime numbers}%
expressions denoting approximately the asymptotic value of
the number of primes inferior to a given limit, but it remained
for Riemann in his memoir, \textit{Ueber die Anzahl der Primzahlen
\index{Riemann!ref.\ to}%
unter einer gegebenen Grösse}, 1859, to give an investigation of
the asymptotic frequency of primes which is rigorous. Approaching
the problem from a different direction, \textit{Patnutij
Tchebycheff}, formerly professor in the University of St.~Petersburg
\index{Tchebycheff}%
(born 1821), established, in a celebrated memoir, \textit{Sur les
Nombres Premiers}, 1850, the existence of limits within which
the sum of the logarithms of the primes~$P$, inferior to a given
number~$x$, must be comprised.\Reference{89} This paper depends on very
elementary considerations, and, in that respect, contrasts
strongly with Riemann's, which involves abstruse theorems
of the integral calculus. Poincaré's papers, Sylvester's contraction
\index{Integral calculus}%
\index{Poincaré!ref.\ to}%
\index{Sylvester!ref.\ to}%
of Tchebycheff's limits, with reference to the distribution
of primes, and researches of J.~Hadamard (awarded the
\index{Hadamard}%
\textit{Grand prix} of 1892), are among the latest researches in this
line. The enumeration of prime numbers has been undertaken
at different times by various mathematicians. In 1877 the
British Association began the preparation of factor-tables,
\index{Factor-tables}%
under the direction of J.~W.~L. Glaisher. The printing, by
\index{Glaisher!ref.\ to}%
the Association, of tables for the sixth million marked the
completion of tables, to the preparation of which Germany,
France, and England contributed, and which enable us to
resolve into prime factors every composite number less than
$9,000,000$.

Miscellaneous contributions to the theory of numbers were
made by \textit{Cauchy}. He showed, for instance, how to find all
\index{Cauchy!ref.\ to}%
the infinite solutions of a homogeneous indeterminate equation
of the second degree in three variables when one solution is
given. He established the theorem that if two congruences,
which have the same modulus, admit of a common solution,
%% -----File: 383.png---Folio 369-------
\index{Covariants}%
\index{Dirichlet|)}%
the modulus is a divisor of their resultant. \textbf{Joseph Liouville}
\index{Liouville}%
(1809--1882), professor at the \DPtypo{Collége}{Collège} de France, investigated
mainly questions on the theory of quadratic forms of two, and
of a greater number of variables. Profound researches were
instituted by \textbf{Ferdinand Gotthold Eisenstein} (1823--1852), of
\index{Eisenstein}%
Berlin. Ternary quadratic forms had been studied somewhat
by Gauss, but the extension from two to three indeterminates
was the work of Eisenstein who, in his memoir, \textit{Neue Theoreme
der höheren Arithmetik}, defined the ordinal and generic
characters of ternary quadratic forms of uneven determinant;
and, in case of definite forms, assigned the weight of any order
or genus. But he did not publish demonstrations of his results.
In inspecting the theory of binary cubic forms, he was
led to the discovery of the first covariant ever considered in
analysis. He showed that the series of theorems, relating to
the presentation of numbers by sums of squares, ceases when
the number of squares surpasses eight. Many of the proofs
omitted by Eisenstein were supplied by Henry Smith, who
\index{Smith, H.}%
was one of the few Englishmen who devoted themselves to the
study of higher arithmetic.

\textbf{Henry John Stephen Smith}\Reference[]{90} (1826--1883) was born in London,
and educated at Rugby and at Balliol College, Oxford.
Before 1847 he travelled much in Europe for his health,
and at one time attended lectures of Arago in Paris, but
after that year he was never absent from Oxford for a
single term. In 1861 he was elected Savilian professor of
geometry. His first paper on the theory of numbers appeared
in 1855. The results of ten years' study of everything published
on the theory of numbers are contained in his Reports
which appeared in the British Association volumes from 1859
to 1865. These reports are a model of clear and precise
exposition and perfection of form. They contain much original
matter, but the chief results of his own discoveries were
%% -----File: 384.png---Folio 370-------
printed in the \textit{Philosophical Transactions} for 1861 and 1867.
They treat of linear indeterminate equations and congruences,
and of the orders and genera of ternary quadratic forms. He
established the principles on which the extension to the general
case of $n$ indeterminates of quadratic forms depends.
He contributed also two memoirs to the \textit{Proceedings of the
Royal Society} of 1864 and 1868, in the second of which he
remarks that the theorems of Jacobi, Eisenstein, and Liouville,
\index{Eisenstein!ref.\ to}%
\index{Jacobi!ref.\ to}%
\index{Liouville!ref.\ to}%
relating to the representation of numbers by $4$,~$6$,~$8$
squares, and other simple quadratic forms are deducible by a
uniform method from the principles indicated in his paper.
Theorems relating to the case of $5$~squares were given by
Eisenstein, but Smith completed the enunciation of them, and
\index{Smith, H.}%
added the corresponding theorems for $7$~squares. The solution
of the cases of $2$,~$4$,~$6$ squares may be obtained by elliptic
functions, but when the number of squares is odd, it involves
processes peculiar to the theory of numbers. This class of
theorems is limited to $8$~squares, and Smith completed the
group. In ignorance of Smith's investigations, the French
Academy offered a prize for the demonstration and completion
of Eisenstein's theorems for $5$~squares. This Smith had
accomplished fifteen years earlier. He sent in a dissertation
in 1882, and next year, a month after his death, the prize was
awarded to him, another prize being also awarded to H.~Minkowsky
\index{Minkowsky}%
of Bonn. The theory of numbers led Smith to the
study of elliptic functions. He wrote also on modern geometry.
\index{Elliptic functions}%
His successor at Oxford was J.~J. Sylvester.
\index{Sylvester!ref.\ to}%

\textbf{Ernst Eduard Kummer} (1810--1893), professor in the University
\index{Kummer}%
of Berlin, is closely identified with the theory of numbers.
Dirichlet's work on complex numbers of the form $a + ib$,
introduced by Gauss, was extended by him, by Eisenstein,
and Dedekind. Instead of the equation $x^4 - 1 = 0$, the roots
of which yield Gauss' units, Eisenstein used the equation
%% -----File: 385.png---Folio 371-------
$x^3 - 1 = 0$ and complex numbers $a + b\rho$ ($\rho$~being a cube root
of unity), the theory of which resembles that of Gauss' numbers.
Kummer passed to the general case $x^n - 1 = 0$ and got
\index{Kummer}%
complex numbers of the form $\alpha = a_1A_1 + a_2A_2 + a_3A_3 + \dotsb$,
where $a_i$~are whole real numbers, and $A_i$~roots of the above
equation.\Reference{59} Euclid's theory of the greatest common divisor
is not applicable to such complex numbers, and their prime
factors cannot be defined in the same way as prime factors of
common integers are defined. In the effort to overcome this
difficulty, Kummer was led to introduce the conception of
``ideal numbers.'' These ideal numbers have been applied by
\index{Ideal numbers}%
G.~Zolotareff of St.~Petersburg to the solution of a problem
\index{Zolotareff}%
of the integral calculus, left unfinished by Abel (\textit{Liouville's
\index{Abel!ref.\ to}%
\index{Integral calculus}%
Journal}, Second Series, 1864, Vol.~IX.). \textbf{Julius Wilhelm Richard
Dedekind} of Braunschweig (born 1831) has given in the second
\index{Dedekind}%
edition of Dirichlet's \textit{Vorlesungen über Zahlentheorie} a new
\index{Dirichlet!ref.\ to}%
theory of complex numbers, in which he to some extent
deviates from the course of Kummer, and avoids the use of
ideal numbers. Dedekind has taken the roots of any irreducible
equation with integral coefficients as the units for his complex
numbers. Attracted by Kummer's investigations, his
pupil, \textbf{Leopold Kronecker} (1823--1891) made researches which
he applied to algebraic equations.

On the other hand, efforts have been made to utilise in the
theory of numbers the results of the modern higher algebra.
Following up researches of Hermite, \textbf{Paul Bachmann} of Münster
\index{Bachmann}%
investigated the arithmetical formula which gives the automorphics
of a ternary quadratic form.\Reference{89} The problem of the
equivalence of two positive or definite ternary quadratic forms
was solved by L.~Seeber; and that of the arithmetical automorphics
\index{Seeber}%
of such forms, by Eisenstein. The more difficult problem
\index{Eisenstein!ref.\ to}%
of the equivalence for indefinite ternary forms has been
investigated by Edward Selling of Würzburg. On quadratic
\index{Selling}%
%% -----File: 386.png---Folio 372-------
\index{Negative quantities}%
\index{Partition of numbers}%
\index{Theory of numbers|)}%
forms of four or more indeterminates little has yet been done.
Hermite showed that the number of non-equivalent classes of
\index{Hermite!ref.\ to}%
quadratic forms having integral coefficients and a given discriminant
is finite, while Zolotareff and A.~N. Korkine, both
\index{Korkine}%
\index{Zolotareff!ref.\ to}%
of St.~Petersburg, investigated the minima of positive quadratic
forms. In connection with binary quadratic forms, Smith
\index{Smith, H.!ref.\ to}%
established the theorem that if the joint invariant of two
properly primitive forms vanishes, the determinant of either
of them is represented primitively by the duplicate of the
other.

The interchange of theorems between arithmetic and algebra
is displayed in the recent researches of J.~W.~L. Glaisher
\index{Glaisher}%
of Trinity College (born 1848) and Sylvester. Sylvester gave
a Constructive Theory of Partitions, which received additions
from his pupils, F.~Franklin and G.~S. Ely.
\index{Ely}%
\index{Franklin}%

The conception of ``number'' has been much extended in
our time. With the Greeks it included only the ordinary
positive whole numbers; Diophantus added rational fractions
\index{Diophantus!ref.\ to}%
\index{Numbers!definitions of numbers}%
to the domain of numbers. Later negative numbers and
imaginaries came gradually to be recognised. Descartes fully
grasped the notion of the negative; Gauss, that of the imaginary.
\index{Imaginary quantities}%
With Euclid, a ratio, whether rational or irrational, was
not a number. The recognition of ratios and irrationals as
\index{Irrationals}%
\index{Ratios}%
numbers took place in the sixteenth century, and found expression
with Newton. By the ratio method, the continuity of the
\index{Continuity}%
\index{Newton!ref.\ to}%
real number system has been based on the continuity of space,
but in recent time three theories of irrationals have been
advanced by Weierstrass, J.~W.~R. Dedekind, G.~Cantor, and
\index{Cantor, G.}%
\index{Dedekind!ref.\ to}%
\index{Weierstrass!ref.\ to}%
Heine, which prove the continuity of numbers without borrowing
\index{Heine!ref.\ to}%
it from space. They are based on the definition of numbers
\index{Numbers!theory of numbers|)}%
by regular sequences, the use of series and limits, and some
new mathematical conceptions.
%% -----File: 387.png---Folio 373-------
\index{Astronomy!more recent researches|(}%


\Section{Applied Mathematics}
\index{Applied mathematics|(}%

Notwithstanding the beautiful developments of celestial
mechanics reached by Laplace at the close of the eighteenth
\index{Laplace!ref.\ to}%
century, there was made a discovery on the first day of the
present century which presented a problem seemingly beyond
the power of that analysis. We refer to the discovery of Ceres
by Piazzi in Italy, which became known in Germany just after
\index{Piazzi}%
the philosopher Hegel had published a dissertation proving \textit{a~priori}
\index{Hegel}%
that such a discovery could not be made. From the
positions of the planet observed by Piazzi its orbit could not
be satisfactorily calculated by the old methods, and it remained
for the genius of Gauss to devise a method of calculating
\index{Gauss!ref.\ to}%
elliptic orbits which was free from the assumption of a small
eccentricity and inclination. Gauss' method was developed
further in his \textit{Theoria Motus}. The new planet was re-discovered
with aid of Gauss' data by Olbers, an astronomer
\index{Olbers}%
who promoted science not only by his own astronomical
studies, but also by discerning and directing towards astronomical
pursuits the genius of Bessel.
\index{Bessel|(}%

\textbf{Friedrich Wilhelm Bessel}\Reference[]{91} (1784--1846) was a native of
Minden in Westphalia. Fondness for figures, and a distaste
for Latin grammar led him to the choice of a mercantile
career. In his fifteenth year he became an apprenticed clerk
in Bremen, and for nearly seven years he devoted his days to
mastering the details of his business, and part of his nights to
study. Hoping some day to become a supercargo on trading
expeditions, he became interested in observations at sea. With
a sextant constructed by him and an ordinary clock he determined
the latitude of Bremen. His success in this inspired
him for astronomical study. One work after another was
mastered by him, unaided, during the hours snatched from
%% -----File: 388.png---Folio 374-------
sleep. From old observations he calculated the orbit of
Halley's comet. Bessel introduced himself to Olbers, and
\index{Halley's Comet}%
submitted to him the calculation, which Olbers immediately
sent for publication. Encouraged by Olbers, Bessel turned
his back to the prospect of affluence, chose poverty and the
stars, and became assistant in J.~H. Schröter's observatory at
\index{SchroterJH@{Schröter, J.~H.}}%
Lilienthal. Four years later he was chosen to superintend
the construction of the new observatory at Königsberg.\Reference{92} In
the absence of an adequate mathematical teaching force, Bessel
was obliged to lecture on mathematics to prepare students for
astronomy. He was relieved of this work in 1825 by the
arrival of Jacobi. We shall not recount the labours by which
\index{Jacobi!ref.\ to}%
Bessel earned the title of founder of modern practical astronomy
and geodesy. As an observer he towered far above
Gauss, but as a mathematician he reverently bowed before the
genius of his great contemporary. Of Bessel's papers, the one
of greatest mathematical interest is an ``\textit{Untersuchung des
Theils der planetarischen Störungen, welcher aus der Bewegung
der Sonne ensteht}'' (1824), in which he introduces a class of
transcendental functions, $J_n(x)$, much used in applied mathematics,
and known as ``Bessel's functions.'' He gave their
\index{Bessel's functions}%
principal properties, and constructed tables for their evaluation.
Recently it has been observed that Bessel's functions
appear much earlier in mathematical literature.\Reference{98}
Such functions of the zero order occur in papers of Daniel
Bernoulli (1732) and Euler on vibration of heavy strings suspended
\index{Euler!ref.\ to}%
from one end. All of Bessel's functions of the first
kind and of integral orders occur in a paper by Euler (1764) on
the vibration of a stretched elastic membrane. In 1878 Lord
Rayleigh proved that Bessel's functions are merely particular
\index{Rayleigh, Lord!ref.\ to}%
cases of Laplace's functions. J.~W.~L. Glaisher illustrates
\index{Glaisher!ref.\ to}%
by Bessel's functions his assertion that mathematical branches
growing out of physical inquiries as a rule ``lack the easy flow
%% -----File: 389.png---Folio 375-------
\index{Bessel|)}%
or homogeneity of form which is characteristic of a mathematical
theory properly so called.'' These functions have been
studied by C.~Th.\ Anger of Danzig, O.~Schlömilch of Dresden,
\index{Anger}%
\index{Schlomilch@{Schlömilch}}%
R.~Lipschitz of Bonn (born 1832), Carl Neumann of Leipzig
\index{Lipschitz!ref.\ to}%
\index{Neumann, C.}%
(born 1832), Eugen Lommel of Leipzig, I.~Todhunter of St.~John's
\index{Lommel}%
\index{Todhunter!ref.\ to}%
College, Cambridge.

Prominent among the successors of Laplace are the following:
\index{Laplace!ref.\ to}%
\textit{Siméon Denis Poisson} (1781--1840), who wrote in 1808
\index{Poisson!ref.\ to}%
a classic \textit{Mémoire sur les inégalités séculaires des moyens mouvements
des planètes}. \textit{Giovanni Antonio Amadeo Plana} (1781--1864)
\index{Plana}%
of Turin, a nephew of Lagrange, who published in 1811
a \Ita{\textit{Memoria sulla teoria dell'\DPnote{** PP: [sic] space} attrazione degli sferoidi ellitici}}, and
contributed to the theory of the moon. \textbf{Peter Andreas Hansen}
\index{Hansen}%
(1795--1874) of Gotha, at one time a clockmaker in Tondern,
then Schumacher's assistant at Altona, and finally director of
the observatory at Gotha, wrote on various astronomical subjects,
but mainly on the lunar theory, which he elaborated in
his work \textit{Fundamenta nova investigationes orbitæ veræ quam
Luna perlustrat} (1838), and in subsequent investigations
embracing extensive lunar tables. \textbf{George Biddel Airy} (1801--1892),
\index{Airy}%
royal astronomer at Greenwich, published in 1826 his
\textit{Mathematical Tracts on the Lunar and Planetary Theories}.
These researches have since been greatly extended by him.
\textbf{August Ferdinand Möbius} (1790--1868) of Leipzig wrote, in 1842,
\index{Mobius@{Möbius}!ref.\ to}%
\textit{Elemente der Mechanik des Himmels}. \textbf{Urbain Jean Joseph Le
Verrier} (1811--1877) of Paris wrote\DPtypo{,}{} the \textit{Recherches Astronomiques},
\index{Leverrier@{Le Verrier}}%
constituting in part a new elaboration of celestial
mechanics, and is famous for his theoretical discovery of
Neptune. \textbf{John Couch Adams} (1819--1892) of Cambridge
\index{Adams}%
\index{Neptune, discovery of}%
divided with Le~Verrier the honour of the mathematical discovery
of Neptune, and pointed out in 1853 that Laplace's
explanation of the secular acceleration of the moon's mean
motion accounted for only half the observed acceleration.
%% -----File: 390.png---Folio 376-------
\textbf{Charles Eugène Delaunay} (born 1816, and drowned off Cherbourg
\index{Delaunay}%
in 1872), professor of mechanics at the Sorbonne in
Paris, explained most of the remaining acceleration of the
moon, unaccounted for by Laplace's theory as corrected by
\index{Laplace!ref.\ to}%
Adams, by tracing the effect of tidal friction, a theory
previously suggested independently by Kant, Robert Mayer,
\index{Kant}%
\index{Mayer!ref.\ to}%
and William Ferrel of Kentucky. \textbf{George Howard Darwin} of
\index{Darwin}%
\index{Ferrel!ref.\ to}%
Cambridge (born 1845) made some very remarkable investigations
in 1879 on tidal friction, which trace with great
certainty the history of the moon from its origin. He has
since studied also the effects of tidal friction upon other
bodies in the solar system. Criticisms on some parts of his
researches have been made by James Nolan of Victoria. \textbf{Simon
\index{Nolan}%
Newcomb} (born 1835), superintendent of the \textit{Nautical Almanac}
\index{Nautical almanac, United States}%
\index{Newcomb}%
at Washington, and professor of mathematics at the Johns
Hopkins University, investigated the errors in Hansen's tables
of the moon. For the last twelve years the main work of the
\textit{U.~S. Nautical Almanac} office has been to collect and discuss
data for new tables of the planets which will supplant the
tables of Le~Verrier. \textit{G.~W. Hill} of that office has contributed
\index{Hill}%
\index{Leverrier@{Le Verrier}!ref.\ to}%
an elegant paper on certain possible abbreviations in the computation
of the long-period of the moon's motion due to the
direct action of the planets, and has made the most elaborate
determination yet undertaken of the inequalities of the moon's
motion due to the figure of the earth. He has also computed
certain lunar inequalities due to the action of Jupiter.

The mathematical discussion of Saturn's rings was taken up
\index{Saturn's rings}%
first by Laplace, who demonstrated that a homogeneous solid
ring could not be in equilibrium, and in 1851 by B.~Peirce,
\index{Peirce, B.!ref.\ to}%
who proved their non-solidity by showing that even an irregular
solid ring could not be in equilibrium about Saturn. The
mechanism of these rings was investigated by James Clerk
Maxwell in an essay to which the Adams prize was awarded.
\index{Maxwell!ref.\ to}%
%% -----File: 391.png---Folio 377-------
\index{Algebraic functions!integrals}%
\index{Mechanics!more recent work|(}%
He concluded that they consisted of an aggregate of unconnected
particles.

The problem of three bodies has been treated in various
\index{Problem of three bodies}%
\index{Three bodies, problem of}%
ways since the time of Lagrange, but no decided advance
towards a more complete algebraic solution has been made,
and the problem stands substantially where it was left by him.
He had made a reduction in the differential equations to the
seventh order. This was elegantly accomplished in a different
way by Jacobi in 1843. \textit{R.~Radau} (\textit{Comptes Rendus}, LXVII.,
\index{Jacobi!ref.\ to}%
\index{Radau}%
1868, p.~841) and \textit{Allégret} (\textit{Journal de Mathématiques}, 1875,
\index{Allégret}%
p.~277) showed that the reduction can be performed on the
equations in their original form. Noteworthy transformations
and discussions of the problem have been given by J.~L.~F.
Bertrand, by Émile Bour (1831--1866) of the Polytechnic School
\index{Bertrand}%
\index{Bour}%
in Paris, by Mathieu, Hesse, J.~A. Serret. H.~Bruns of Leipzig
\index{Bruns}%
\index{Hesse!ref.\ to}%
\index{Mathieu!ref.\ to}%
\index{Serret!ref.\ to}%
has shown that no advance in the problem of three or of $n$
bodies may be expected by algebraic integrals, and that we
must look to the modern theory of functions for a complete
solution (\textit{Acta Math.}, XI., p.~43).\Reference{93}

Among valuable text-books on mathematical astronomy rank
the following works: \textit{Manual of Spherical and Practical Astronomy}
by \textit{Chauvenet} (1863), \textit{Practical and Spherical Astronomy}
\index{Chauvenet}%
by \textit{Robert Main} of Cambridge, \textit{Theoretical Astronomy} by \textit{James~C.
\index{Astronomy!more recent researches|)}%
\index{Main}%
Watson} of Ann Arbor (1868), \textit{Traité élémentaire de Mécanique
\index{Watson, J.~C.}%
Céleste} of \textit{H.~Resal} of the Polytechnic School in Paris,
\index{Resal}%
\textit{Cours d'Astronomie de l'École Polytechnique} by \textit{Faye}, \textit{Traité
\index{Faye}%
de Mécanique Céleste} by \textit{Tisserand}, \textit{Lehrbuch der Bahnbestimmung}
\index{Tisserand}%
by \textit{T.~Oppolzer}, \textit{Mathematische Theorien der Planetenbewegung}
\index{Oppolzer}%
by \textit{O.~Dziobek}, translated into English by M.~W.
\index{Dziobek}%
Harrington and W.~J. Hussey.
\index{Harrington}%
\index{Hussey}%

During the present century we have come to recognise the
advantages frequently arising from a geometrical treatment of
mechanical problems. To Poinsot, Chasles, and Möbius we
\index{Chasles!ref.\ to}%
\index{Mobius@{Möbius}!ref.\ to}%
\index{Poinsot!ref.\ to}%
%% -----File: 392.png---Folio 378-------
\index{Dynamics|(}%
\index{Kowalevsky!ref.\ to}%
\index{Variation of arbitrary consonants}%
owe the most important developments made in geometrical
mechanics. \textbf{Louis Poinsot} (1777--1859), a graduate of the
\index{Poinsot}%
Polytechnic School in Paris, and for many years member of
the superior council of public instruction, published in 1804
his \textit{Éléments de Statique}. This work is remarkable not only
as being the earliest introduction to synthetic mechanics, but
also as containing for the first time the idea of couples, which
was applied by Poinsot in a publication of 1834 to the theory
of rotation. A clear conception of the nature of rotary
motion was conveyed by Poinsot's elegant geometrical representation
by means of an ellipsoid rolling on a certain fixed
\index{Ellipsoid!(attraction of)}%
plane. This construction was extended by Sylvester so as
\index{Sylvester!ref.\ to}%
to measure the rate of rotation of the ellipsoid on the plane.

A particular class of dynamical problems has recently been
treated geometrically by \textbf{Sir Robert Stawell Ball}, formerly
\index{Ball, Sir~R.~S.}%
astronomer royal of Ireland, now Lowndean Professor of
Astronomy and Geometry at Cambridge. His method is given
in a work entitled \textit{Theory of Screws}, Dublin, 1876, and in
\index{Screws, theory of}%
subsequent articles. Modern geometry is here drawn upon,
as was done also by Clifford in the related subject of Biquaternions.
\index{Biquaternions}%
\index{Clifford!ref.\ to}%
Arthur Buchheim of Manchester (1859--1888),
\index{Buchheim}%
showed that Grassmann's Ausdehnungslehre supplies all the
\index{Ausdehnungslehre}%
\index{Grassmann!ref.\ to}%
necessary materials for a simple calculus of screws in elliptic
space. Horace Lamb applied the theory of screws to the question
\index{Lamb}%
of the steady motion of any solid in a fluid.

Advances in theoretical mechanics, bearing on the integration
and the alteration in form of dynamical equations,
were made since Lagrange by Poisson, William Rowan Hamilton,
\index{Hamilton, W.~R.!ref.\ to}%
\index{Lagrange!ref.\ to}%
\index{Poisson!ref.\ to}%
Jacobi, Madame Kowalevski, and others. Lagrange had
\index{Jacobi!ref.\ to}%
established the ``Lagrangian form'' of the equations of
motion. He had given a theory of the variation of the
arbitrary constants which, however, turned out to be less
fruitful in results than a theory advanced by Poisson.\Reference{99} Poisson's
%% -----File: 393.png---Folio 379-------
\index{Geodesics}%
\index{Ultimate multiplier, theory of}%
theory of the variation of the arbitrary constants and
the method of integration thereby afforded marked the first
onward step since Lagrange. Then came the researches of
Sir William Rowan Hamilton. His discovery that the integration
\index{Hamilton, W.~R.!ref.\ to}%
of the dynamic differential equations is connected with
the integration of a certain partial differential equation of the
\index{Partial differential equations}%
first order and second degree, grew out of an attempt to deduce,
by the undulatory theory, results in geometrical optics previously
\index{Undulatory theory of light}%
based on the conceptions of the emission theory. The
\textit{Philosophical Transactions} of 1833 and 1834 contain Hamilton's
papers, in which appear the first applications to mechanics
of the principle of varying action and the characteristic
\index{Action!varying}%
\index{Varying action, principle of}%
function, established by him some years previously. The
object which Hamilton proposed to himself is indicated by
the title of his first paper, viz.\ the discovery of a function
by means of which all integral equations can be actually
represented. The new form obtained by him for the equation
of motion is a result of no less importance than that which
was the professed object of the memoir. Hamilton's method
of integration was freed by Jacobi of an unnecessary complication,
\index{Jacobi!ref.\ to}%
and was then applied by him to the determination of a
geodetic line on the general ellipsoid. With aid of elliptic \DPtypo{coordinates}{co-ordinates}
\index{Co-ordinates}%
\index{Elliptic co-ordinates}%
\index{Ellipsoid!(attraction of)}%
Jacobi integrated the partial differential equation
and expressed the equation of the geodetic in form of a
relation between two Abelian integrals. Jacobi applied to
\index{Abelian integrals}%
differential equations of dynamics the theory of the ultimate
multiplier. The differential equations of dynamics are only
one of the classes of differential equations considered by
Jacobi. Dynamic investigations along the lines of Lagrange,
Hamilton, and Jacobi were made by Liouville, A.~Desboves,
\index{Desboves}%
\index{Liouville!ref.\ to}%
Serret, J.~C.~F. Sturm, Ostrogradsky, J.~Bertrand, Donkin,
\index{Bertrand}%
\index{Donkin}%
\index{Ostrogradsky}%
\index{Serret!ref.\ to}%
\index{Sturm, J.~C.~F.!ref.\ to}%
Brioschi, leading up to the development of the theory of a
\index{Brioschi!ref.\ to}%
system of canonical integrals.
%% -----File: 394.png---Folio 380-------
\index{Hydrodynamics}%
\index{Ignoration of co-ordinates}%
\index{Kowalevsky}%

An important addition to the theory of the motion of a solid
body about a fixed point was made by Madame \textbf{Sophie de
Kowalevski}\Reference[]{96} (1853--1891), who discovered a new case in which
the differential equations of motion can be integrated. By
the use of theta-functions of two independent variables she
\index{Theta-functions}%
furnished a remarkable example of how the modern theory of
functions may become useful in mechanical problems. She
was a native of Moscow, studied under Weierstrass, obtained
the doctor's degree at Göttingen, and from 1884 until her
death was professor of higher mathematics at the University
of Stockholm. The research above mentioned received the
Bordin prize of the French Academy in 1888, which was
doubled on account of the exceptional merit of the paper.

There are in vogue three forms for the expression of the
kinetic energy of a dynamical system: the Lagrangian, the
Hamiltonian, and a modified form of Lagrange's equations in
which certain velocities are omitted. The kinetic energy
is expressed in the first form as a homogeneous quadratic
function of the velocities, which are the time-variations of the
co-ordinates of the system; in the second form, as a homogeneous
quadratic function of the momenta of the system;
the third form, elaborated recently by Edward John Routh
\index{Routh}%
of Cambridge, in connection with his theory of ``ignoration of
co-ordinates,'' and by A.~B. Basset, is of importance in hydrodynamical
\index{Basset}%
problems relating to the motion of perforated solids
in a liquid, and in other branches of physics.

In recent time great practical importance has come to be
attached to the principle of mechanical similitude. By it one
\index{Similitude (mechanical)}%
can determine from the performance of a model the action of
the machine constructed on a larger scale. The principle was
first enunciated by Newton (\textit{Principia}, Bk.~II., Sec.~VIII.,
\index{Newton!ref.\ to}%
Prop.~32), and was derived by Bertrand from the principle
\index{Bertrand}%
of virtual velocities. A corollary to it, applied in ship-building,
%% -----File: 395.png---Folio 381-------
\index{Hydrodynamics|(}%
goes by the name of William Froude's law, but was enunciated
\index{Froude}%
also by Reech.
\index{Reech}%

The present problems of dynamics differ materially from
those of the last century. The explanation of the orbital and
axial motions of the heavenly bodies by the law of universal
gravitation was the great problem solved by Clairaut, Euler,
D'Alembert, Lagrange, and Laplace. It did not involve the
consideration of frictional resistances. In the present time
the aid of dynamics has been invoked by the physical
sciences. The problems there arising are often complicated
by the presence of friction. Unlike astronomical problems of
a century ago, they refer to phenomena of matter and motion
that are usually concealed from direct observation. The great
pioneer in such problems is Lord Kelvin. While yet an
\index{Kelvin, Lord!ref.\ to}%
undergraduate at Cambridge, during holidays spent at the
seaside, he entered upon researches of this kind by working
out the theory of spinning tops, which previously had been
only partially explained by Jellet in his \textit{Treatise on the Theory
\index{Jellet!ref.\ to}%
of Friction} (1872), and by Archibald Smith.
\index{Smith, A.}%

Among standard works on mechanics are \textbf{Jacobi's} \textit{Vorlesungen
\index{Jacobi!ref.\ to}%
über Dynamik}, edited by Clebsch, 1866; \textbf{Kirchhoff's} \textit{Vorlesungen
\index{Clebsch!ref.\ to}%
\index{Kirchhoff!ref.\ to}%
über mathematische Physik}, 1876; \textbf{Benjamin Peirce's}
\index{Peirce, B.!ref.\ to}%
\textit{Analytic Mechanics}, 1855; \textbf{Somoff's} \textit{Theoretische Mechanik},
\index{Mechanics!more recent work|)}%
\index{Somoff}%
1879; \textbf{Tait and Steele's} \textit{Dynamics of a Particle}, 1856; \textbf{Minchin's}
\index{Minchin}%
\index{Steele}%
\index{Tait}%
\textit{Treatise on Statics}; \textbf{Routh's} \textit{Dynamics of a System of Rigid
\index{Dynamics|)}%
\index{Routh!ref.\ to}%
Bodies}; \textbf{Sturm's} \textit{Cours de Mécanique de l'École Polytechnique}.
\index{Sturm, J.~C.~F.!ref.\ to}%

The equations which constitute the foundation of the theory
of fluid motion were fully laid down at the time of Lagrange,
but the solutions actually worked out were few and mainly
of the irrotational type. A powerful method of attacking
problems in fluid motion is that of images, introduced in 1843
\index{Images, theory of}%
by George Gabriel Stokes of Pembroke College, Cambridge.
\index{Stokes}%
It received little attention until Sir William Thomson's discovery
\index{Thomson, Sir William!ref.\ to}%
%% -----File: 396.png---Folio 382-------
\index{Kelvin, Lord!ref.\ to}%
\index{Vortex rings}%
of electrical images, whereupon the theory was extended
by Stokes, Hicks, and Lewis. In 1849, Thomson gave the
\index{Hicks}%
\index{Lewis}%
\index{Stokes!ref.\ to}%
\index{Thomson, J.~J.}%
\index{Thomson, Sir William!ref.\ to}%
maximum and minimum theorem peculiar to hydrodynamics,
which was afterwards extended to dynamical problems in
general.

A new epoch in the progress of hydrodynamics was created,
in 1856, by Helmholtz, who worked out remarkable properties
\index{Helmholtz!ref.\ to}%
of rotational motion in a homogeneous, incompressible fluid,
devoid of viscosity. He showed that the vortex filaments in
such a medium may possess any number of knottings and twistings,
but are either endless or the ends are in the free surface
of the medium; they are indivisible. These results suggested
to Sir William Thomson the possibility of founding on them a
new form of the atomic theory, according to which every atom
\index{Atomic theory}%
is a vortex ring in a non-frictional ether, and as such must be
absolutely permanent in substance and duration. The vortex-atom
theory is discussed by J.~J. Thomson of Cambridge
(born 1856) in his classical treatise on the \textit{Motion of Vortex
Rings}, to which the Adams Prize was awarded in 1882.
Papers on vortex motion have been published also by Horace
\index{Vortex motion}%
Lamb, Thomas Craig, Henry~A. Rowland, and Charles Chree.
\index{Chree}%
\index{Craig, T.}%
\index{Lamb}%
\index{Rowland}%

The subject of jets was investigated by Helmholtz, Kirchhoff,
\index{Jets}%
\index{Kirchhoff!ref.\ to}%
Plateau, and Rayleigh; the motion of fluids in a fluid by
\index{Plateau}%
Stokes, Sir W.~Thomson, Köpcke, Greenhill, and Lamb; the
\index{Greenhill}%
\index{Kopcke@{Köpcke}}%
theory of viscous fluids by Navier, Poisson, Saint-Venant,
\index{Navier!ref.\ to}%
\index{Poisson!ref.\ to}%
\index{Saint-Venant!ref.\ to}%
Stokes, O.~E. Meyer, Stefano, Maxwell, Lipschitz, Craig,
\index{Lipschitz!ref.\ to}%
\index{Maxwell!ref.\ to}%
\index{Meyer, O.~E.}%
\index{Stefano}%
Helmholtz, and A.~B. Basset. Viscous fluids present great
\index{Basset}%
difficulties, because the equations of motion have not the same
degree of certainty as in perfect fluids, on account of a deficient
theory of friction, and of the difficulty of connecting
\index{Friction, theory of}%
oblique pressures on a small area with the differentials of the
velocities.

Waves in liquids have been a favourite subject with English
\index{Waves|(}%
%% -----File: 397.png---Folio 383-------
\index{Kelvin, Lord!ref.\ to}%
\index{Solitary wave}%
mathematicians. The early inquiries of Poisson and
\index{Poisson!ref.\ to}%
Cauchy were directed to the investigation of waves produced
\index{Cauchy!ref.\ to}%
by disturbing causes acting arbitrarily on a small portion
of the fluid. The velocity of the long wave was given
\index{Long wave}%
approximately by Lagrange in 1786 in case of a channel of
\index{Lagrange!ref.\ to}%
rectangular cross-section, by Green in 1839 for a channel of
\index{Green!ref.\ to}%
triangular section, and by P.~Kelland for a channel of any
\index{Kelland}%
uniform section. Sir George B. Airy, in his treatise on \textit{Tides
\index{Airy!ref.\ to}%
\index{Tides}%
and Waves}, discarded mere approximations, and gave the exact
equation on which the theory of the long wave in a channel of
uniform rectangular section depends. But he gave no general
solutions. J.~McCowan of University College at Dundee
\index{McCowan}%
discusses this topic more fully, and arrives at exact and
complete solutions for certain cases. The most important
application of the theory of the long wave is to the explanation
of tidal phenomena in rivers and estuaries.

The mathematical treatment of solitary waves was first
taken up by S.~Earnshaw in 1845, then by Stokes; but the first
\index{Earnshaw}%
\index{Stokes!ref.\ to}%
sound approximate theory was given by J.~Boussinesq in 1871,
\index{Boussinesq}%
who obtained an equation for their form, and a value for the
velocity in agreement with experiment. Other methods of
approximation were given by Rayleigh and J.~McCowan. In
\index{Rayleigh, Lord!ref.\ to}%
connection with deep-water waves, Osborne Reynolds gave in
\index{Reynolds}%
1877 the dynamical explanation for the fact that a group
of such waves advances with only half the rapidity of the
individual waves.

The solution of the problem of the general motion of an
ellipsoid in a fluid is due to the successive labours of Green
\index{Ellipsoid!motion of}%
(1833), Clebsch (1856), and Bjerknes (1873). The free
\index{Bjerknes, C. A.}%
\index{Clebsch!ref.\ to}%
motion of a solid in a liquid has been investigated by W.~Thomson,
\index{Thomson, Sir William!ref.\ to}%
Kirchhoff, and Horace Lamb. By these labours, the
\index{Kirchhoff!ref.\ to}%
\index{Lamb}%
motion of a single solid in a fluid has come to be pretty well
understood, but the case of two solids in a fluid is not developed
%% -----File: 398.png---Folio 384-------
\index{Hydrodynamics|)}%
\index{Spheroid (liquid)}%
so fully. The problem has been attacked by W.~M.
Hicks.
\index{Hicks}%

The determination of the period of oscillation of a rotating
liquid spheroid has important bearings on the question of the
origin of the moon. G.~H. Darwin's investigations thereon,
\index{Darwin!ref.\ to}%
viewed in the light of Riemann's and Poincaré's researches,
\index{Poincaré!ref.\ to}%
\index{Riemann!ref.\ to}%
seem to disprove Laplace's hypothesis that the moon separated
\index{Laplace!ref.\ to}%
from the earth as a ring, because the angular velocity was too
great for stability; Darwin finds no instability.

The explanation of the contracted vein has been a point of
\index{Contracted vein}%
much controversy, but has been put in a much better light by
the application of the principle of momentum, originated by
Froude and Rayleigh. Rayleigh considered also the reflection
\index{Froude}%
\index{Rayleigh, Lord!ref.\ to}%
of waves, not at the surface of separation of two uniform
media, where the transition is abrupt, but at the confines of
two media between which the transition is gradual.

The first serious study of the circulation of winds on the
\index{Winds|(}%
earth's surface was instituted at the beginning of the second
quarter of this century by \textit{H.~W. Dové}, \textit{William~C. Redfield}, and
\index{Dové}%
\index{Redfield}%
\textit{James~P. Espy}, followed by researches of \textit{W.~Reid}, \textit{Piddington},
\index{Espy}%
\index{Piddington}%
\index{Reid}%
and \textit{Elias Loomis}. But the deepest insight into the wonderful
\index{Loomis}%
correlations that exist among the varied motions of the
atmosphere was obtained by \textbf{William Ferrel} (1817--1891). He
\index{Ferrel}%
was born in Fulton County, Pa., and brought up on a farm.
Though in unfavourable surroundings, a burning thirst for
knowledge spurred the boy to the mastery of one branch after
another. He attended Marshall College, Pa., and graduated
in 1844 from Bethany College. While teaching school he
became interested in meteorology and in the subject of tides.
\index{Meteorology|(}%
In 1856 he wrote an article on ``the winds and currents of the
ocean.'' The following year he became connected with the
\textit{Nautical Almanac}. A mathematical paper followed in 1858
on ``the motion of fluids and solids relative to the earth's
%% -----File: 399.png---Folio 385-------
surface.'' The subject was extended afterwards so as to
embrace the mathematical theory of cyclones, tornadoes,
water-spouts, etc. In 1885 appeared his \textit{Recent Advances in
Meteorology}. In the opinion of a leading European meteorologist
(\textit{Julius Hann} of Vienna), Ferrel has ``contributed more
\index{Hann}%
to the advance of the physics of the atmosphere than any
other living physicist or meteorologist.''

Ferrel teaches that the air flows in great spirals toward the
poles, both in the upper strata of the atmosphere and on the
earth's surface beyond the 30th~degree of latitude; while
the return current blows at nearly right angles to the above
spirals, in the middle strata as well as on the earth's surface,
in a zone comprised between the parallels $30°$~N. and $30°$~S. The
idea of three superposed currents blowing spirals was first
advanced by James Thomson, but was published in very
\index{Thomson, J.}%
meagre abstract.

Ferrel's views have given a strong impulse to theoretical
research in America, Austria, and Germany. Several objections
raised against his argument have been abandoned, or
have been answered by W.~M. Davis of Harvard. The mathematical
\index{Davis, W.~M.}%
analysis of F.~Waldo of Washington, and of others,
\index{Waldo}%
has further confirmed the accuracy of the theory. The transport
of Krakatoa dust and observations made on clouds point
toward the existence of an upper east current on the equator,
